hX2_0QKKLqDdhrmTm1zt5Q.text: Went here with some friends and family over from Ireland. Great looking place, more of a dining experience than just going out to eat. Everyones food was good with the exception of mine, I order schnitzel for some reason, which was average, I was left feeling a little cheated by myself for ordering such a stupid meal. . . . but that was my own fault! Would go again, but, this time for breakfast as many other reviewers state.

3eZlQwWuHvyKF4I6JR9Wuw.text: Had lunch at The Wolsey last week. Was outstanding. The Sea Trout was the best I have ever tasted. served on a bed of samphire, mushrooms and peas. Chose roasted carrots, Lyonaise potatoes and salad to accompany. The cherry and pistachio tart with pistachio ice cream was heavenly. The cheese board top quality. Service is relaxed and friendly but highly efficient. The building is remarkable and atmospheric. the restaurant was full but not intrusive, great atmosphere.

kA_6D5j19qIICi_U_FaA8g.text: I really love this place for breakfast, brunch or afternoon tea and want to keep coming back time and time again! But it should be kept as a special place, otherwise it will probably lose its charm. The decor is wonderfully old school and smart and the crowd here are really interesting to sit and watch! I had afternoon tea next to Bill Nighy the last time I was here - I couldn't quite hear what they were saying (sounded interesting though!) and I didn't want to get noticed for earwigging! A brilliant place for Sunday brunch - but call up and book far in advance. During the week if you get here early and want breakfast, you don't need to book because can go into the little side room where they serve the same food. You need to book for the main room though. A lovely really English place that I always come out of feeling lucky that I live in London.

Al-8J1rWqzkMSWo4D9WVoQ.text: What more can one say about the Wolseley that hasn't been said before? The place is so grand, almost cavernous But marvellous atmosphere, a bit self-conscious what with the celebrities. I think it's advisable to go for breakfast or brunch, or even light lunch, but I find dinner disappointing, not least because the service is indifferent and the food nothing special. It's all about the atmosphere. The breakfast is lovely, every detail of it. A London classic.

sr3o_7hTxM98UqNLUvN6mg.text: Fantastic venue for business lunches, bustling but with the right ambience and excellent service, the food was really good too!

hVSJMV0Wok5ZbBiA_DpVMg.text: Solid London eatery - modern British and reasonable value. Service is a tad arrogant however.

YIEWoL6TEdDxZRcLfTTDUQ.text: I must admit, when I found out I was being taken here for brunch for my birthday, I did wonder whether I'd see any celebrities! Sadly no, but still enjoyed a wonderful and filling brunch in the most beautiful and striking surroundings. The decor was amazing, and the waiting staff were attentive and friendly. Not convinced that having a bottle of Heinz tomato sauce on the table would live up to my definition of posh, particularly surrounded by all the silverware though! Could have been decanted into a nicer serving dish! I had a pastry to start, followed by a full breakfast whilst my partner also had a pastry and Eggs Benedict, which he said was wonderful. The fresh juices tasted as though they'd been squeezed just 20 seconds previously. Not at all cheap, but for a treat it was a wonderful experience.

n0KVSL4Av_lgR9m_gSTN3A.text: Must've gone downhill since I went. When it first opened it was THE place to go - but sounds like the surburban bandwagon is stopping far too often! I went for dinner a few times, and always enjoyed the range of choice available - a kind of ultra-upmarket cafe/brasserie dining room. I didn't find the room too noisy, but maybe the chattering classes weren't in when I was there :-)

pBCOP6zDkqBQ-grL5kFqFw.text: What a fantatsic restaurant! Great place full of atmosphere and celebs. I took my girlfriend there for her Birthday and she loved it. We had thier own vintage wine as recommended by our waiter which was a very good red. To eat I had the crab and Kudu had the Foie Gras - which was amzing. FOr main I had the Duck pie - which is like shepherds pie and Kudu had the lamb chop. For desert we had the crumble. A great place for a treat, however a word warning - very, very expensive.

B7PhHqHY64QPo8_5obe3eA.text: food is ok, priced as a fee to enjoy the great spacethe service is randomly great and perfunctorythey do not rush you out once you are seatedif fatigue brings you to their door, then just enjoy itbut it is no longer, a great win-win with great food and great environmentsome dishes were like a mediocre cafeteria:  welsh rarebit was simplygrilled cheese on toastopen late and that is a pluscurious why they bailed on the big dish that was special for little entrees that do not inspire,maybe they simply changed management or something

ZnD7ffPGnq4egL1lo6j4gg.text: The Wolseley embraces all things quintessentially British from the doorman welcoming you in to the food on the menu. The building itself is something special (and old Bank Vault I think) and the food was delicious and not nearly as pricey as you cwould imagine. It is the finishing touches that makes this place what it is - silver teapots etc. Well worth a visit - but be sure to book in advance.

j_RjiFjbZxecEaPba7IaEg.text: Went for a business lunch but I have to admit disappointment. The food was very average and very expensive (i guess it is Mayfair). Fish stew was tasty but had quite a few bones in it, and the service was slow and waitress spoke very little English. I've been to better.

naxYg1I6uvCE4AcfjmHRgQ.text: I can't comment on the quality of the Eggs Benedict, as I went there for dinner. Having heard and read so much about the Wolseley, I was very curious. It really is a fantastic place - but more for the food than the surroundings which whilst surely quite impressive, I found a little disappointing (for example I found the lighting quite dingy, no, not intimate- dingy) But I was bowled over by the simplicity and classiness of the food. Also thought the service was brilliant, friendly, nice, modest, always there, but never obtrusive. So: a great place to go - you must try it out for yourselves!

XoCaLOBEb4loSWY03Lqr4w.text: There is little to fault here as far as I am concerned. The food is never outstanding but then it never aims to be and the wine list for what it is, is actually excellent and very well researched. Im not sure about the breakfasts only because those rows and rows of pinstripes make me feel quesy and also I think the patisserie is not as good as when it opened. But despite that it stells you all you need to know that it's still going strong. Londoners love to knock down their icons but they haven't bothered with this one yet.

2QgFLVaRugJSMv5JYH4L5Q.text: This is a great place to go for brilliant food, great service and people watching. It's definitely on the expensive side but the food is really good, coffee is great, and they do just about anything you could possibly want for breakfast or brunch. Everything is served in silver from the tea to the jams which adds to the sense of luxury. From the moment you walk in you're treated just as well as the celebreties you could be sitting beside and it's always exciting to walk through the doors and know you're in for great food and some good people watching.

vKRHgFJqdiKa08FcwnXy8g.text: A good place to meet for a business breakfast or sociable lunch but very noisy and very busy. The receptionist is never very helpful either.

EmAWdu_a5L3uqzrv-qYjWw.text: i'm reading various negative reviews of  brunch below, yet in the UK there exists breakfast, lunch, tea, and supper, which is why Wolseley has no brunch menu. besides assuming brunch is everywhere in the world, which it is not, what is the point of writing a brunch review?

DDDEzMCL83z-Y-ptZXuXGw.text: If there is one place you need to try a full English breakfast then it has to be The Wolseley. Stunning surroundings, great atmosphere, friendly service and good food. Definitely recommend that you book to ensure you are not disappointed but in saying that I have never booked and always got a table for breakfast. A super place and loads of fun.

Ukw68aL04jd_Hamy-qyl0w.text: If you want to have breakfast and are meeting a client then The Wolseley is a great place to do this. They have an amazing menu which is full of fantastic food. Located in a vibrant, posh area. The decoration and design of the building itself is really nice and the prices aren't as expensive as you might think for such an up class restaurant in Mayfair. They have very friendly staff and your order gets processed quickly. Overall, a great place to go for a meal, be it breakfast, lunch or dinner. The most affordable place in Mayfair.

ubHsEwyqxNdSS3ztZz7M9g.text: Couldn't be more central to London. The doorman in top hat already sets the Wolseley above my average breakfast experience. I have only been for breakfast or Sunday brunch. First time I had a superb Wiener Schnitzel with potato mash. The meat was so tender that I could cut it with my eyes; the fried coating so light and still tasty; the mash was perfection, the stuff of The man who ate everything, if you catch my drift.Breakfast was also very nice, with nice eggs, mushrooms, bacon and sausage and black pudding.Normally I wouldn't eat the latter; however at the Wolseley I decided to try and in fact it was worth: it's absolutely delicious, very delicate.The breakfast is also very very nice and worth a visit.The menu has many many more interesting entries that I could have possibly sampled.Service is ok in my experience. However upon booking you're told how long you can keep the table from when the booking starts; something that a lot of people might find off putting. For that kind of people it's recommended to avoid busy times, book an advance and arrive on time.

fRWR56TZFWlX43yK1MomdQ.text: I've had dinner at the Wolseley twice and each time the service has been friendly and I've enjoyed my time. It's a fancy place but the prices are not as high as you would imagine, and I thought it was reasonable for what you're getting. It's a good place to take your parents, the atmosphere is nice and the room is beautiful.  We had a nice view of the grand and pretty clock at the end of the room. The food is decent and overall it's a nice upscale experience with good service.I had the soup which was decent. My husband had the steak which he enjoyed and his parents loved the fish and were impressed with the place itself. I would say it's good for having a pre-show meal in a nice atmosphere before going to the ENO (English National Opera) which is not too far a walk from here.

qyUmXZfYyxkUIW9-qlmWLg.text: I dunno...I know it's a little hokey, and full of tourists, and a little over the top, but...it also feels like something that everyone living in London should do*.  At least once.  Do as Kate Moss likes to do: GO AND EAT AT THE WOLSELEY!  GO SEE AND BE SEEN!*it's also a good'un for visiting friends and famjamI've only ever been for breakfast and a late lunch, never for the much-talked-about afternoon tea.  That said:the venue is _beautiful_.  Truly.  It feels old worldy, and the service is excellent, the bathrooms have fancy little hand towels with "The Wolseley" emblazoned on them.  On point, Wolseley.Their all-day menu features a truly varied mix.  Chopped salads, eggs benedict, many seafood-y options (think: oysters!), a burger, croque madame.  A bajillion ice cream and pastry "viennoise" options.  Every day there's a daily special that is more hardcore.  Today's?  VEAL HONGROISE (I did not jump for it).What I *do* jump for at The Wolseley - in addition to the excellent service is...the smoked haddock omelette (the "Arnold Bennett").  It comes soft and creamy, with many chunks of fleshy white fish and a really fine dusting of chives atop.  Paired with a perfectly dressed side salad (not on the main cafe menu, but they're happy to accommodate) it's a great - indulgent, but not heavy - meal.Yelp notes:1. there is an online reservation system, as well as a call-in system.  I've done both, but also - just sometimes - lucked into a walk-in reservation.  Apparently they save some tables expressly.2. it can get NOISEY in that main room, with high ceilings and din of people chatting ON A MAJOR SUGAR HIGH.  If you're hoping for something more private, or a meal with parents who can find it hard to hear (sorry for outing you, Pops!) I recommend calling ahead and reserving one of the booths immediately to the right of the entrance, tucked away by the bar.  Much better, and much quieter.

g5fC7vZT3ECCH7_AJQNxTw.text: Afternoon tea should involve jaws dropping and a collective 'oooh' when they bring out the tower of sandwiches, cakes and scones. This was ok, and it was pretty enough, but not anything special. When I'm paying £36 for a Champagne afternoon tea (not including service) then I want something more impressive. Cheesecake, chocolate cake and eclairs are tasty but not inventive and you get one choice of jam with your scones - strawberry - which tastes like its shop bought.The location is lovely and the decor is fantastic (inside a converted bank with lots of 1920s style) but the service wasn't great. At 4pm, all the tables are taking tea so if you want to attract a waiter, forget about it. At times, I thought about running after one and tapping him on the shoulder to let him know I was there and that I would like more drinks.Go for breakfast and it's a different story but when it comes to tea, there are much better places in London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. The full afternoon tea

IeeUI8OFP5LZTQ8oW5WyWg.text: It's a 'scene' for breakfast lunch dinner and after dinner. Many white collar people coming before during and after work. The food is consistent but nothing too exciting! During fashion week you need reservation for breakfast. It is beautiful 'grand cafe' idea imported from Vienna and the ambience of chatter makes that idea more authentic.

FuFric95kxoux2Lk5XdPPQ.text: Ah, the Wolseley. Sophisticated yet unpretentious. Grand yet unassuming. The Wolseley had been on my list for a very long time, so I decided to finally frequent it a few days after my birthday, as a belated birthday treat. For all the finery and the fantastic service, breakfast is quite reasonably priced. The interior is even more impressive than its almost formidably grand exterior, with checkered marble floors, vaulted ceilings, and arched entryways. The waitstaff are all impeccably dressed and the menu is fantastically organized, inspired by European breakfast items (Croque Monsieur and Madame) but with chiefly English accents (Eggs and Soldiers). I, of course, had the Eggs Florentine. Definitely the best I've ever had, and I would know as that is usually my go-to breakfast item if a restaurant has it. I liked the extra sour zest in the Hollandaise to balance out the starchy muffin and the neutral eggs.  There are of slightly heavier items options, including muesli and French toast. In fact, I already know what I will get the next time I go. And there will be a next time. I will be having the Potato Rosti with Avocado, Tomato, and Hen's Egg. The thing I really enjoyed about this Ritz Hotel neighbor is the fact that it is actually quite relaxed in it's dining attitude. Though the majority of the crowd at 9am sharp were business breakfast bound, there was a younger crowd dressed almost sloppily and it seemed to usher no second thought in anyone. There was a complete blending, a warm buzzing conversational energy. It was just loud enough to have to lean in to speak but not so loud that you were left yelling at your eggs. Just a complete harmony.I am normally quite a hard sell, and would have veered on granting 4.5. But at the end of the meal, my lovely companion offered to pay for the meal as a birthday treat- at which point the waiter overheard and wished me a happy belated. He disappeared and when he returned, he had in hand an adorably packed item, which turned out to be a Danish with a 'Happy Birthday' marzipan accent. Sold. Lifetime customer.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

RQ7Tn_0FFDVxj-Vb4Kze3w.text: We went here for lunch. I wanted to love this place but maybe my expectations were too high. We ordered the smoked salmon hors d'oeuvre... and it was just smoked salmon. I thought it would come on a bread with some fancy toppings but it was just salmon... Souffle was wonderful and pork/bacon egg dish was delightful as well. Service was okay. Depending on the server, one had attitude, one was very nice and attentive (asked how spicy we wanted our Bloody Marys, while the other server never asked) and others were average.  Next time I would love to try their afternoon tea :)

1mMot57_iPdWMy5y7jnCog.text: Probably one of my favourite restaurants in London, and always a go-to for a quick breakfast or lunch while shopping or something more special for a special occasion. Let's start with breakfast, absolutely spot on every time. Great choice and variety, top quality as always and a really reasonable price. Eggs Benedict, pancakes and kedgeree are always a popular choice with my groups. Lunch is great too, can chose from the bar menu for more simple dishes, such as sandwiches, brunch dishes or burger. Or can go for the al a carte, with a great selection of seafood, oysters or a choice from the grill. I always find myself going for the croque Monsieur and a side of fries and a glass of chilled champagne when I fancy a delicious simple lunch. The afternoon tea is absolutely amazing too! Really good price compared to it's competitors, but personally, it's as good if not better than some like Fortnums. The cakes always vary; and you can request more of some or less of others if you fancy! The scones are always warm and fresh, and the sandwiches are divine. I think what really makes the afternoon tea is the very classical and relaxed atmosphere, in the amazing surroundings of an old car showroom. It's grand but accessible atmosphere, is on par with it's spectacular service. Very attentive and polite. The one minor problem is that as with many busy restaurants in London, there is a turnover of tables, so if you occasionally run over your 2 hour time period and they need your table, then can tend to start to usher you along, but still with manors and not throw you out! Dinner is great, again can choose from both menus, I'm sure they will pretty much do what you want there really, very flexible. There is a great wine list, and the cocktails are great! Overall, would definitely recommend for breakfast, lunch and dinner!  And tea too if you fancy!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Pastries from the Wolseley, available to take away and eat in the park or eat in!
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Croque Monsieur and fries at the Wolseley.

e1dQx3fPEQB_romz97U7Bg.text: Two of us had dinner here.  We didn't realise there was a separate vegetarian menu, they seem to have a lot of menus, so we had a limited range to choose from.  We had tomato soup for starters, which was delicious, in the same way a tin of Heinz is if you were to add as much butter to it as they did.Main course was fish for both of us, and it was very good but not really memorable.  We ordered some of the lower end wines and they were both very good.  Dessert was certainly the best course by far.  My friend had the passion fruit meringue pie, which was first-rate, perfectly done and my blackberry and apple crumble hard to criticise apart perhaps for the way it was kind of slopped onto the plate.That would have all been fine, it was all good stuff, but it came to more than one hundred quid.  We had a voucher that we received as a gift that covered most of it, so I didn't mind, but you are clearly not only paying for what they put on your plate:The service was fantastic.  Entirely friendly and helpful, just the right amount of it too, though they must still have the till system from when it was a car showroom in the 1920s because the waiter spend a long time trying to produce a bill.  And the decoration is lavish.  I really liked being there.  Their menu is quite interesting; I'd love to know if they can do a proper Wiener Schnitzel and the breakfasts look amazing.  In summary, I'm glad I've experienced it but the food was not quite good enough.  I hope to come back to try the breakfasts.

pzN6v3Na0SZ_V2iIWYz82w.text: Extraordinary experience for a champaign breakfast. Basket of pastries was mouth-watering delicious. Service is white glove. We enjoyed a bagel with smoked salmon and while I'm told the Eggs Benedict is their specialty (ham, Florentine and salmon), I had my guilty pleasures of haggis over toast (with fried duck eggs--which I skipped). Beware of costs--pricey and not a normal tourist destination. The inside of the building is just beautiful.  Wood, brass, dark marble. What a treat.

Fxtzw0UU7lvxQ1DtjqdmdQ.text: Scones were the best I've ever had. After eating them, it made me not want to purchase them in the US anymore. It is a pretty fancy place, but we were just in jeans so we were seated in a section clearly reserved for dressed down tourists! But, no matter- the food and service were great. Didn't love some of the tea cakes but other than that everything else was wonderful. Highly recommend for a traditional afternoon tea experience while in London.

hq3akDIYYdOOiayGl6bq1Q.text: Divine! Simply divine!! We stopped for afternoon tea and everything was so wonderful- the ambiance, the food, the tea...great stop! We'll definitely be coming back

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Chicken, avacado and bacon sandwich, raspberry and pistachio tart, and a pot of jasmine tea... YUMMY!

NyIXrZV3kcfr2R8fPS42KA.text: I really wanted to like The Wolseley - or at least the afternoon tea experience - but it looks like I sadly set my expectations too high. My friend and I had reservations for afternoon tea at 4:45 pm on a Sunday, and my first impression of the place was: wow. There was a doorman who kindly opened the door for us, and the reception was extremely courteous, seating us right away. I ended up getting the afternoon tea with green tea, and about 5 minutes later our tower/tea came out - so definitely a plus for the quick service. Unfortunately, it went downhill from here since the food - overall - was just not satisfying. The sandwiches were mostly bland, except for the celery one which was served inside a delicious tomato-flavored bread. The salmon sandwich was alright, too, but I would've preferred a bit more salmon to enhance the taste. The desserts weren't amazing either, with the exception of the New York cheesecake which was PHENOMENAL - the perfect creaminess and flavor. The other desserts proved to be less satisfying, especially the Battenberg which was quite dry and was coated with an artificially-orange-tasting marzipan. The tea was also pretty disappointing, as it did not taste fresh at all. It left a bitter taste on my tongue, which I found doesn't happen with higher quality tea leaves. Fortunately, I did at least thoroughly enjoy the scones + strawberry jam. The scone was warm upon being served and had a wonderfully fluffy interior. The jam though - oh my god - that was by far the best part. It tasted SO good - especially with the warm scone - and I probably devoured more than half of the jam they gave us.Overall - weighing all aspects of my experience - I thought afternoon tea here was just ok. The presentation and setting were beautiful, but the service felt a bit brisk and the food was generally disappointing.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea

uYeLPYG78S98GBTv6hEDoQ.text: Took some meetings here, really enjoyed the atmosphere. It's classy, yet comfortable. Staff was very attentive and the croissants were delicious.

3NlN5ppA4t2KSjh6Xdoy6A.text: The setting at this restaurant, especially at night for dinner is stunning decor. The other nice thing is that the room was full but not super loud, people even were arriving at 11 for dinner. Good was good, service was decent, only thing was that  it took quite a while for food to arrive between courses. Overall I would reccomend this restaurant.

MBVZRASJLnrvHPdOIMhccw.text: The Wolseley was a tad fancier than I perceived it on its other Yelp reviews, but that did not stop me from having a completely amazing lunch. I came in by myself with my briefcase to get work done (reviews gave that impressions) but either way the service was impeccable, good was divine, and the lamb roast was the best lamb I've ever had. I honestly felt bad because I looked a little out of place but they made me feel very welcomed. Next time  I will be dressed to impress with the lady!

UOJfPFLvAlNxRpDxARncsg.text: I have only gone here for drinks.  The place is amazing!  You walk in and you just feel like you are in a glamorous Parisienne bistro. There is a variety of drinks to chose from and the staff is very helpful and attentative.  The downside is that there isn't much room at the bar so it easily gets tight.

_azXeJ7yCaoBKDRN_fdkXg.text: The atmosphere, particularly the noise is like Cantonese dim-sum restaurants, but English style.Food taste and quality are nothing spectacular. Service is plain.

qHbUSIbomVOlxYhmDZUuMg.text: Fancy place my wife wanted to try, so we had afternoon tea.  The place was extravagant looking.  The service was fine.  The food was good.  The tea was ok.  Although a nice place to relax and do "afternoon tea," not my cup of tea.  My wife loved the place.  I would rather get a full sandwich, tea, and a dessert piece at Starbucks or elsewhere for a cheaper price.  This place also serves regular meals and alcohol.  Recommend you make reservations as this place is super busy.

TM-IMJBV8r4dPHJwtxhMcw.text: So my friend just popped back for a week from Hong Kong and she was raving on about the cheesecake from this place. We scheduled a last minute meeting for tea here, although we did try to book first. My friend was told that it was fully reserved but we can try to walk in.Lo and behold, counting our lucky stars, when we walked in at 430pm on a Saturday they found a spare table which they need back at 6pm for dinner, and we thought why not, 1.5 hours are quite sufficient for tea, so we were seated.The decor of the place is pretty grand but you are not charged extortionate prices for the pleasure, which was of course, very pleasurable ;) I opted for a cream tea which consisted of 3 scones with the normal clotted cream and strawberry jam and went for Darjeeling tea, and my friend asked for Earl Gray with a slice of cheese cake.The food was good but nothing spectacular. While I thought the cheese cake tasted pretty average, maybe excelling at being more smooth in texture than usual, I wouldn't really say this is a thing to die for. The scones were also pretty much what one would expect, although I really appreciate the place giving me plenty of clotted cream and jam to slather generously over my scones. Nothing like not enough toppings to go around to spoil your mood right? I have had a look at the afternoon tea which includes the sandwiches and also other desserts, but it didn't really strike me as that much more fanciful than other high tea places. Now if they were doing super cute themes like in the Landau (i.e. Valentines theme, Fashion week themed cakes/desserts), I would be more tempted to give this more stars. Service is good, the decor is good, the food is so so, therefore this place gets a 4 stars from me!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Lovely cream tea

kUYnMLgfaC-g4LOk8apG6g.text: This is the best option for breakfast on this street, don't waste your time/money at the caffe concertos and the other stores with the alluring displays on this street.Most people tend to daunted by the location and entrance and expect this place to be ridiculously expensive. The truth is the breakfast prices are reasonable but the same cant be said for lunch or dinner menu...The service couldn't have been better! We were checked often but not in an intrusive way. They always seem to be there when you need something but they never interrupt while you are in the middle of a conversation. As for the food i tried a lot of things from the menu but the pancakes with either berries or bacon are the best thing you can get there!The only disadvantage is that it is always busy, so make sure you reserve a table to avoid disappointment.Even if you cant afford or have time for the breakfast, it is worth going just for a coffee at this place and admiring the amazing interior!

FMEyjpaXjhV7s2z7VhVSFA.text: I love afternoon tea! I think the Wolseley is a good place because it is much easier to make reservations here than at places like the Ritz-Carlton or Brown's.Afternoon tea comes with a pot of tea, two freshly baked scones, five finger sandwiches, and an assortment of desserts. The scones were my favorite part, and I drowned them in clotted cream and jam. The price is actually not bad compared to some other places I've been to for afternoon tea.

sXWNG0lPhukYYUBmPgWdwA.text: The menu didn't seem that interesting, until we asked what a couple of words meant (pardon the lack of British vocabulary).  I had breakfast here. After an almond croissant, double-chocolate brioche, kedgeree, and minced pork with fried duck eggs...we were a pair of very full, happy eaters.  Get the fried duck eggs.  The pastries were also very nice - excellent texture.  Almost like a real French patisserie/boulangerie.Oh, and they let us share a pot of tea, which I thought was nice for such a potentially stuffy/inflexible venue.

bqPW1cRUvbgKDgFv1J2S0w.text: I've had numerous breakfasts here and have enjoyed them immensely on each and every occasion. If I had the time and the appetite I would work my way through the menu, I would even try the kedgeree. The coffee is wonderful and I'm assured by my wife that the tea is equally superb. The service and ambiance is second to none, fast, efficient and pleasant. I now ensure that I book a table every time I'm in London.PS: You must try the The Wolseley Imperial  coffee, it can set you up for the morning.

mfwiSlc4fqS3w9m3VUl5pA.text: This place never fails me for a good breakfast. I have been there so many times on various occasions, weekdays & weekends for breakfast, the customer services is excellent. They are very attentive, friendly and helpful.The first time my friend told me that we're going for breakfast at this really great place she knows, I thought of a good old greasy cafe. I dressed down (really down as I was tired on a night out the night before) so when I arrived at a place like The Wolseley, I felt like a tramp! =) They didn't treat me any different to the other well presented customers. I've always gone for the Egg Benedict. I've had others Egg Benedict in various different places but I have to say that it is incomparable to the one done here. The hollandaise sauce was perfect. It can't get any better.Their croissants & other pastries are very delicious too. Their hot chocolate is not made from syrups unlike many places I've been to and chain coffee stores. If you would want to try this place out, you should make a reservation online. You might end up having to wait in the bar until a seat is available as it does get busy. Fear not! They will still get you tea/coffee/fresh juice whilst you wait to be seated. There is a turnaround of 2 hours per table.I love this place! Great food, great customer services and great interior design. It is pricey but not over priced.

Io_J38u6KetWi83usOd7Eg.text: I was very excited to try Wolseley's spaghetti and they were really nice. The bill however was not very nice and wasn't what I expected

HAEOI-H4L4Xs_QTsiW9jVQ.text: The lunch we had last week at the Wolseley was amazing and surprisingly at reasonable price. We were seated immediately and I got to say the staff are very friendly.

yNSzybHrVAMI8_iJ6NbKMg.text: I reserved online for afternoon tea here at wolseley. It was pretty cheap for what you get. 2 scones, varieties of mini cakes and sandwiches. Scone was the BEST ive had in london. I highly recommend this posh but not so expensive place for one afternoon to have the experience of High Tea culture in England!

XSUjWQELM7ialLcsQMGFEw.text: hmm...old ancient and kind of cool in that respect.  i looked up brunch, and london and this is what came up.  I should have gone elsewhere.  It seems they are more concerned with appearance than actual taste.  first of all on a saturday their breakfast stops at 11:30am.  which sucks.  I would have gone elsewhere.  but apparently the eggs benedict are on their all day menu.  (btw the menu is confusing, some things are served all day, some just tile 11:30 am, some start at noon)...they ware blah, ok, have had way better.  the latte was amazing though, but the tray, design and little shot glass of water to wash down the bitterness seemed over the top...the chicken dumpling soup sparse and not very satisfying though cute because it came in its own pot. good if you are having a business lunch...but don't come here if you are craving a good brunch.

GRHTLkT2Ps74NndcON2ttw.text: The Afternoon tea sandwich is good, although the environment is noisy. But I don't like the pastries.

1QX5vpnt6r6Lk9YUT5o7Bg.text: Nice and classic, but seem a little tired around the details.I really wanted to love this breakfast. Gorgeous pastries on display, a menu with a great mix of dishes that are heavy on classical British. But they really fell down on the details. First, the good: the tea service was traditional and correct and delicious. Also, the preserves were fresh and really yummy. The biggest problem was the Eggs Benedict: the poached egg was badly overcooked and not at all runny. The service was also, at best, acceptable: not adequate for a restaurant like this.

dUcgTY_FaSncNcYAxceZjA.text: Breakfast on a Sunday at The Wolseley - perfection! Everything was great; my kedgeree with poached egg was superb and they poached the egg exactly how I asked them to to it. Loads of choice on the breakfast menu and the staff are really terrific. We'll be going back again for the lunch and evening menus! You may get lucky and get a table but I'd certainly say book.

yjVDrjtCnZxU0xv4lM97uA.text: The first time I was invited to dinner at the Wolseley, I had an image in my mind of a restaurant where people would greet each other using phrases like "pip pip you old bean", and that dinner would be occasionally be interrupted by a table standing up, pumping their first in the air, and yelling "huzzah."  The food is very British, but this is a surprisingly laid back place.  The staff might be dressed like they are serving the Governor-General of India, but they are all very friendly and the overall feel of the place is excellent.Unless you are craving Black Velvet and oysters, the only reason I'd really want to come here is because of the atmosphere and the decor, which is impressive.  Apparently this used to be a car dealership; if that's the case, they certainly don't build 'em like they used to.  I've been told this is frequented by celebrities, but I've never seen anyone I could recognize.  Then again I'm not British, I don't read the Sun, and I don't really care if the guy sitting at the table next to me was the bisexual midget from season 3 of big brother.I've been here twice now, and I don't think I'd choose to come back of my own volition.  I mean, £18 for wiener schnitzel, without any vegetables?  £9 for a Guinness and champagne?  Get real.  But if you get a seat in the main dining room, it can be a lot of fun.  Just make sure you aren't the one paying.

6jDzF2B8XlPWSkRuE9guZA.text: I love The Wolseley.  I go there a few times a week when I'm in town.  I think the food is terrific and the house wines are tops!  And reasonably priced, though tending on the high side.  HOWEVER, two of the last three times I've been there, my bill has been padded with additional bar drinks.  This is the kind of place where I suspect few people really look closely at the tab before they pay.  I'm one of them.  However the first time I thought it was an innocent mistake.  But that kind of "innocent mistake" should not be repeated so closely together.  I CAUTION EVERYONE to look closely at their bill and see if other don't find this same pattern.  It's unfortunate for such an iconic place.

qheZ7zZiowwBABhKRv93jg.text: We had brunch here on a weekday morning.  It was pretty bustling still, and the servers seemed a little rushed - but still nice.  The space is beautiful, and the food was pretty good.  The highlight was the mixed basket Viennoiserie that included a selection of delicious pastries. The food won't be the best you have ever eaten, but it's definitely good and worth it for the experience of the place.

NePUGSjvy8eB8jizvDFP_g.text: Nice place, good crowds. Good food, nice atmosphere, get a seat on the balcony if you can. I eat there at least once every time I'm in London. great eggs Benedict!

KgXqZB-kD2OxBzGCJvLulg.text: We had our first afternoon tea at the Wolseley and it was arguably the most unforgettable meal experience we had in London.  I was uncertain about having a tea because I didn't really understand what it meant.  Here is what it meant to us.  First the ambiance is pristine.  You have to appreciate the fine architecture, the vaulted ceilings, the dark wood, the stone floors, the granite and wood table tops and the white cloth settings.  Next is the impeccable staff.  Well dressed, well groomed, well spoken - this is a place for the truly professional waiter and waitress.   Our waiter was French and he was one of the best waiters we have ever had.  Incredibly gracious and he explained the tea service very well.   For tea we had the Tea for two and it was was perfect for our family of four, my wife and two daughters.  The tea comes with scones, finger sandwiches,  and assorted pastries.  It's all simply delicious.  The real beauty of the experience however is enjoying the meal, enjoying the surroundings, and spending time with your family in a place that seems to inexplicably bring everything together.   Thanks to the Wolseley for offering a truly great service - I hope you enjoy it as much as we did!

byUiALtygngNYidm0vCr0g.text: Like this place needs a review to show how good dining here is, but er I am on Yelp so here it is anyway. Ladies and Gents I introduce you to the pride of Piccadilly, the Wolseley. This is my third visit here, the first two for a spot of breakfast and now for my birthday luncheon. This restaurant is perfect to mark a special occasion, and serves classic British cuisine. The interior looks lovely and the building is Grade II listed. Once a motor showroom for bankrupt Wolseley motors, and then later a Barclays Bank, the Wolseley has retained it's beautifully high ceilings and Japanese lacquered style from the twenties.The atmosphere is great, the staff are helpful and not too pretentious. They did accidentally mix up my chicken soup with chicken salad, but all is forgiven as they were so apologetic and quick to rectify. They also gave me free chips with my yummy fish main-course to make up for it (I am blatantly so cheap to win over - probably should have asked for free champagne right?). The chicken soup was a nod to Jewish cooking with matzah balls, and to add to that you could even get it served with a salt beef sandwich if you desired. The soup was pretty good, but sadly not as good as grandma's.Fantastic place. It is quite pricey but if you order carefully and forgo the alcohol you can eat here without the need to sell off the silver.Best birthday evs.

DanbGnk-AL7pLUeSI9UVvg.text: One of the classic English Afternoon Tea place. Their afternoon tea starts at 3pm so don't get there too early.. although I heard brunch is good there too. My friend and I ordered some combo which comes with dessert and your choose of tea. the place is very elegant and classic. Price is reasonable.. the combo my friend ordered was only 20gpd ( typically it cost 30gpd-40gpd) for a place like that. Keep in mind this is a famous place so you may want to make a reservation in advance I had great experience here.. i think Americans should start this afternoon tea tradition too

n8HvC01hU76ZI28esLMy4w.text: My sister loves the Wolseley and I love my sister.When I'm visiting London, she insists we go here for brunch.  The brunch, mind you, is quite decent.  The coffee is excellent.  The brioche, quite tasty.  And hey, finding American bacon in the UK isn't easy to do... but there it is, available for all, at the Wolseley.The Wolseley isn't so much a restaurant as it is a place to see and be seen.  It is a scene.  My sister likes to point out famous English people that I've never heard of when we're there.  Boy George? Nope. Russell Brand? Um, nope.  An Osbourne or a McCartney?  Nope.  Seriously, it's people I've never heard of......Alas, it makes for a fun brunch out, some good (overpriced) fuel before a day of shopping.

kwM4QU9mA-hEQkT5yHGm7Q.text: Great place for breakfast. I'm particularly fond of their silver flatware.

WVQlbWwksUpgIkBhiFPygg.text: We loved this place so very much on our recent trip to London that we ate here 4 times during our 4 day stay! We had the pleasure of eating two dinners, one breakfast, and one lunch here and we were so pleased each time. Every single person from the servers, to the waitstaff, to the management, and especially the doormen (hi Lee and Ray!), were exceptional! The food was very well done and they even had many options for me for gluten free and dairy free choices. I will definitely be back and recommend everyone eat here when they visit London!

eiNqH68Rof7_MPPneAKjuA.text: We were here for their well known breakfast. The food was good, service was great, and room amazing.Visited September 2016

WARtskEfHVs47LodbC7yqQ.text: I'm prepared to pay for something special: the Wolseley is a treat - smart location, lovely interior, decent cutlery (tho' I think the "linen" table clothes are a bit rough and ready), and even monogrammed hand towels (disposable) in the bathrooms. You have to titter.We popped in for an early dinner, the son and I. Our hearts were set on one portion of Eggs Benedict and something salad-y for me. The W delivered !Delicious meal, followed by yummy dessert. The only thing I would criticise is the maître d's attitude when we walked in. You have to field the necessarily snobbish, "do you have a reservation?" at 6pm; but then his rather heavy-handed, "I will need this table back by 7:30 Madame" - I was all obliging smiles and courtesy, but HONESTLY!! Do I look like some sort of lothario who's going to sit in this little 2-seater booth ALL NIGHT, with my 11-year old son?? It's Monday people! Puh-leezI wish you could enjoy the ENTIRE experience. It's a small thing, but grace and kindness go a very long way when it comes to being hospitable.This is the hospitality industry after all.

fKLXyFOvo2Tixiz6xmx2GA.text: Such a wonderful experience of having afternoon tea at the Wolsley. It was recommended by a friend that lived in London.  What a gem!Highly recommend to friends and family.I walked in without reservations and the host was so gracious.

bPCNaO7VPyYyGtxBSSy9Ag.text: Honestly, this is my favorite brunch/lunch/tea place in London. I've been heading over here for over 4 years on my own and previously with my mom several years back.. and it never gets old. It's always such a wonderful treat sitting there and enjoying a hot cup of tea or coffee in the morning going down memory lane. I would highly recommend any of their egg benedict plates, although everything from their breakfast pastry selections, porridge, to the standard english breakfast dishes are absolutely fantastic. :)

2JkdgY2MbMCEt9P8nDXFDg.text: Attila attended to me in the bar area at The Wolseley which made my experience all the more pleasant. This place is always packed and sometimes it shows with the staff however Attila was warm, professional and kind. Highly recommend visiting the small bar room on the right before enjoying tea or a full sit down meal.

hGqQjoKv3jkoIugzkdjYmg.text: Amazing place to get afternoon tea while in London. Beautiful place just to sit, relax and catch up with friends. Tea and food were both delicious. Reservation is recommended to ensure getting a table. Great location with Green Park and Buckingham Palace nearby to help walk off the meal afterwards. The only negative part was our server disappeared on us so it was hard to ask for anything from anyone because the place was busy. It was a good thing that we were not in a hurry. Still a great place to check out and worth a visit.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

seBpDKFDzmSwPAbrdKNElA.text: The Wolseley has become a London "institution"! It's located in a historic building next to the Ritz. It is very popular amongst tourists and locals alike. We came here on a Friday night at around 930. The place still was packed and people still kept pouring in. We didn't have a reservation but they managed to give us a table. Decor is opulent, grand, matching the historic building. It is noisy an the atmosphere is buzzing. the crowd is totally mixed, you will see tourists in shorts and flip flops, but also women wearing evening gowns and gents in tuxedos. Service is good, knowledgeable, friendly and attentive. Even when it's packed they keep their cool.They have a nice wine list including a good selection of wines by the glass.The food served here is classic and traditional, concentrating on French and British cuisine. I was surprised how good the quality of the food was, ingredients were fresh, everything cooked to perfection. I will make sure to come back and make a reservation in the main dining hall. This should top the experience I already had.The Wolseley is sure expensive but worth every penny!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Mayo!
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Landaise
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Pommes Frites

SNYWMM0NffZYGIxVB7sgEQ.text: You can't go wrong with the Wolseley. Sure it is a london institution but that is with good reason. All is always right with the world at the Wolseley - better than Tiffany's! I am a big fan of their breakfasts. The menu is wide and varied - although I always order the same thing - smoked salmon and boiled eggs. The ingredient quality is fabulous so the simpler the better so the taste shines through. The biggest attraction here though is the amazing atmosphere and the big room itself. I always feel like I am in some fantastic 50s movie when I walk in and that Audrey Hepburn could be at the next table. The staff are always friendly and the service always good.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. It's all about the detail.....

0KvxgcaHUO_DNBzmRCL4PA.text: Pricy but tasty breakfast. The wait staff were fairly inattentive, it took us a while to place our order and get the bill. Also a shame you can't have cream tea, or at least a scone with clotted cream / jam before 3pm. They clearly have them, and most people enjoy a tea & scone, so why not serve them all day?

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

G2FuqGyc90dgLi0pVJm7nQ.text: On our last day in London, we asked our hotel concierge for a good brunch place and he pointed us to Wolseley.  The location is central and the decor is elegant and stately (very British).  We waited briefly at the bar before getting seated.  Service was good and fast.  The reason I gave it 4 vs 5 is that the food is just ok...nothing special given all the hype.  Check out the pictures and you can decide for yourself.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

77mxz8bitx51Fd3f1pIWHQ.text: Excellent tea time! The tea and crumpets were very nice. Beautiful environment. For a party of 2 I would only order one tower. If you walk in and put your name down it takes about 20 minutes.

BvSUnd2NXjhtJNbC5BnN7w.text: Place is lovely for atmosphere. The food was good but not outstanding. I had the lobster and my friend had the fish of the day. Service was great.

tyrNXJ_Y4nY91f6DtKrLcg.text: Went there for breakfast. Elegant ambiance and great service !!The prices were on the higher side . I liked the smoked salmon with the egg.

BtIDHY1DJO40NvSdhfec7w.text: I wanted to experience Afternoon Tea while visiting London and I'm so glad we chose The Wolseley. I've read mixed reviews about the service but our experience was top notch. I ordered afternoon tea for one with the Wolseley blend and my hubby had the Croque Madame. There was plenty of food and everything was yummy. I didn't love the pistachio/berry pastry served.  The resturant is beautiful and it was packed. Be certain to make a reservation and enjoy all The Wolseley has to offer.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Hubs ordered the bourbon cream filled pastry.
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Scone w clotted cream and a dab of fresh strawberry preserves
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon Tea for one. Happy Birthday to me!

OSeQFcGkrj3U_NZ4Yhw95Q.text: We had afternoon tea here and I'll remember the scones the most. Yum. I give it 3 stars as the waiter(s) were far from spectacular. The one who put our service ware was rude and had his fingers all over the plates along with dropping the napkin on the floor and not even bringing back a replacement one until we asked. Nice ambience in there with the high ceilings!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Yummy scone!

KXWESChfW8gmCNO1sG-lrQ.text: I wish we had stayed, in London longer, so we could have eaten here more.We only had breakfast here, but I highly recommend it.The service was good.The coffee and juice was very good; no instant coffee, like so many other London places. And, there are many fresh juice options, such as Pineapple, and Carrot & Ginger.My husband and son both loved the Haggis and Eggs.I loved that they had small (1 egg) and large (2 eggs) Eggs Benedict options. One egg is enough, for me, and I always feel so wasteful, or overly stuffed, when there are 2. The Eggs Benedict was delicious.It is a pretty place, to have a meal. There is a very relaxing atmosphere, although it is higher end.

jEUUqxsFTVd8D_CrfMjkBQ.text: Want an amazing breakfast in London? Look no further. Traditional English breakfast is available for the carni's. I had the eggs florentine. Small is one amazingly fresh English muffin with eggs perfect sauce and spinach. The restaurant itself is a tight ship. Courteous staff, clean as a whistle and gorgeous. Lots of local businessmen (and women) and some sprinkled in tourists.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Drink bar
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Tea

tSnayK9YXPQvDBuRHIHnYQ.text: Made a reservation for afternoon tea here. While the interior, service, atmosphere, and all of the small touches were perfect, the tea and food were just okay. I do appreciate the beautiful decor and nice ambiance (certainly a fancy place), the sandwiches were all pretty simple without much flavor, and the pastries were all slightly dry or too sweet. For such a classy venue, was hoping for better quality food.

mnaMFMitAwOcAy6C5CCQ-A.text: That was quite a treat for me by a friend which was really nice. We ate so much I felt near to bursting after all the little cakes and sandwiches and so much tea on top. Everything was very tasty and tiny but very good. It was quite noisy as well which I didn't really appreciate because I wanted to enjoy my afternoon tea without near shouting at my friend while small talk.Anyway, it was a very British experience but not comparable to the nice tea times you can have in Vienna.The cafe is only 2 min from Green Park Station on the Jubilee, Victoria and Piccadilly Line and 2 min from the bus stop Green Park Station served by the buses (N)9, 14, (N)19, (N)22, (N)38 and N97.

Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Which one to start with?
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

52XfhzjCTff2d_irEBMIYg.text: What could be more appropriate after a tour of the Buckingham Palace state rooms than lunch at The Wolseley?The grandeur of the place hits you the moment you walk in.  Black and white marble, gilded accents, and the chinoiserie.  At 2pm, the place was abuzz with chatter.  The staff were flitting about taking care of everyone's need.To start, a bottle of Chateau de la Mirande Picpoul de Pinet from the Languedoc, and Dorset rocks.  By this time, I had gotten used to calling oysters, rocks.  They were fresh and briny.  But also had subtle richness and creaminess, almost like slight hints of sea urchin.  The wine was the perfect complement with its minerality.  Next, soupe de poisson.  This is not going to sound good, but when I looked down the soup bowl, this dark and murky liquid stared back at me.  The first spoonful exploded with the taste of the sea.  This was one intense seafood broth, however unappealing it looked.For mains, Lobster & Dorset Crayfish salad, and Salade Nicoise.  Meaty chunks of lobster and crayfish in a light creamy dressing.  The potato salad at the bottom of the plate was just as good, and did not felt like a filler.  The Salade Nicoise was pretty classic.  There were grilled artichoke hearts that brought a nice smokiness to the dish.Why 4 stars?  The food here is pretty solid, just as you would expect from a good brasserie.  The atmosphere and surroundings scream posh and luxe London.  The service is top notch.  During our meal, there were no Madge or Gwyneth sightings.  Although, we did have a big Hollywood star in our midst.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. salade nicoise

SrfghbPJKFYLJyZFW8WX0Q.text: I love this place, everything we ordered we enjoyed. Great atmosphere and terrific staff. Try the liver if you dare, it's lovely.

kLzay8_mYmzutRbLC6DWRw.text: I had an excellent experience at The Wolseley and would absolutely come back if I find myself in London again.The location is prime -- right next to the Ritz and nearby Piccadilly Circus. This is the coolest interior I have ever seen in a restaurant; large, upscale and art deco but without being gaudy or intimidating.We came at around 8:30 PM and stayed until 10 or 10:15, and it remained bustling. Our wait service was fantastic throughout, happy to answer any questions about the food.My food was outstanding. I ordered the sea bass, which was absolutely delicious. For a fine dining restaurant, the portion was generous. Family ordered the gnocchi which was also excellent. My dessert was great as well. I left feeling full but not stuffed.

uvZF5habOFzKn-e3ccbe7Q.text: We experienced our best food and service experience here in London. Yes, it is a bit pricey but so well worth the price. We told our waiter Freddie that it was our honeymoon and he brought us a custom chocolate brioche dessert! It was so good! The manager then gave us a Wosley breakfast recipe cookbook. They were so sweet! Try the potato Rossi for breakfast. Great flavor!Great way to truly experience London! Thanks so much!

lFQKfvvz5EkmOsTXExSOpw.text: I think it's an absolutely beautiful place. The ambiance is a 10. The food wasn't very good. Maybe I'm not used to places like this but I do think it's rather odd that the breakfast menu is still available at night. I did sit at the best table though. We were right in this cozy little booth next to the front door where we were able to people watch, yet have privacy at the same time. Beautiful place, a little touristy, not the best food.

kFfR3dzix1JKH2cmNSGdzA.text: My friend and I had eaten here before the Trooping the Colour.  Since we were dressed up we decided that any old cafe just would not do.  Looking for something upscale the Wolseley was the perfect fit.  Breakfast was delicious and well worth the price.  Service was good, not great considering they were not terribly busy.  All in all I would definitely recommend the Wolseley for having a nice posh breakfast.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

Iuq5Ij6rYgOEhmjKzw1_Uw.text: It's a great place, with a feeling of Orient Express and Prague,  but is actually an old car showroom and after, a banking hall.......... It does a remarkable Job during the day to be everything for everyone. Huge choice and good quality.  Read some negatives talking about breakfasts can.'t comment as I haven't done that. What I can recommend is the best halibut tranche I have ever had, in fact I've even gone back to have it again ! Delicious door stop style char grill........My American friends used to tell me that there was a time that you couldn't get a good meal in London, but then came Chris and Jeremy............ It's a consistent winner...........

ZjZuLLbl_3jZgTnTMsPigw.text: This was my first experience having afternoon tea. We did not have a reservation and did a walk in with 4 people. We waited for about 30-35 mins which was not bad considering the entire restaurant and bar area was packed. Originally they wanted to seat us in the bar, but I didn't feel like sitting in the bar while having tea (the atmosphere felt too rushed), we asked the host if it was possible for the dining area and he was quick to say no. After speaking with one of the managers they were kind enough to seat us but we were told we had to be out by 6pm since that table had a reservation already (figured 90 mins was plenty of time to enjoy our tea). Our server was friendly and quick to serve us. We did not get the champagne and ordered the regular tea option. The scones and strawberry jam were delicious, the other pastries were not that great in my option. There was a variety of cheese cake and yellow looking cake with some chocolate mousse but they were too sweet in my opinion. The little sandwiches served was also good, but really anything extraordinary for what we paid but ok. I think I would of been happy ordering 2 types of 2 and just scones. Not to mention we ordered the Wolseley blend and didn't think it was that strong, next time we might just go with the Early Grey or think it was English Breakfast option. Again the experience was fun and the service was good, but a bit pricey for the food options I think, but then again it is London so everything seems to be overpriced. We payed around 75 pounds ($120) for 4 people.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Some of the pastries
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Variety of sandwiches-egg, cucumbers, ham, and chicken
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Warm fluffy scones

fl1QloQuskGn9T3L3VA_zg.text: I have been here for drinks/coffee but will definitely go back for lunch/dinner at some point.  The ambiance is great, it has a nice buzzy vibe and the service is impeccable.  The location is super central, so it is a great choice to nip in for a drink after a long day shopping or touring.  Great for locals and tourists alike!

TNDxRs6vQcEXNbOIGHb-Sw.text: We really like this place but getting a reservation is impossible and I am not sure why. We emailed a week out for any time on a Thursday or Friday lunch or dinner. We got a response there was nothing open. When we got to London we stopped in and convinced a hostess to give us a 5:30 dinner booking. As we had just arrived from the US that day, 5:30 was just fine.    When we arrived there were countless open tables and when we left nearly 7, there were still countless open tables.      Apart from getting a table, it's was delightful. The menu is wonderful, from Egg's Benedict to Mussels and Fries to Seven Hour Lamb. The food was good, the setting was awesome. He wanted a scone for dessert and as tea was over, the server made no promises. A few minutes later he was back with scone, jam and clotted cream. We finished with tea and a sigh.

C_UI4qCl1UVJnr-Z_hYV1g.text: Reviewing for both dinner and afternoon tea.Availability: We were able to get day of reservations for dinner on a Sunday, and were able to walk in around 3:30pm for tea on a Monday.  Maybe we were just lucky.Service: So excellent.  The staff were totally on it, but not pretentious.  Our waiter was very knowledgeable on the wine, and I was impressed by the recommendation.Food: Everyone seems to have a beet salad these days, but something about the lemon/goat cheese made this one of the best I have had in awhile.  We both loved our fish dishes.Tea: Just lovely.  Tea was lovely, service was lovely.

uSg17QrnmA7CNQLCKsVw_Q.text: Fourth visit to London and wanted to take my parents (their first trip) for some afternoon tea. Found the Wolseley on the Food and Wine Magazine website about London and had a great time! Right next to the Ritz and wayyyy more affordable and never felt like we weren't getting the real experience. We had one order of the traditional tea with the tiered platters, finger sandwiches, etc and the my mom just got a plain cup of tea. Dad got the cream tea which just was tea and scones. Plenty of food for all of us if not more than we needed. Great pastries, lots of tea to choose from, and great service. Which is hard for me to say when I am with my dad who expect everything to be perfect. Would definitely recommend to anyone doing it for the first time.

iqZYSY2Cp5p3qMZctFe3Aw.text: Despite having a booking, we waited 10 minutes in line to get to the welcome desk as the one woman handed coats over to one waitress and ushered people to their tables. There were about 3 other waiters just lulling about. The entire restaurant smelled like a damp kitchen. As for the food - the bouillabaisse was oversalted, the bread sticks were stale, the schnitzel was unfortunately nothing out of the ordinary and the creamed spinach arrived cold. Furthermore, the waitress was so concerned with getting us off the table after 1 hr 15 mins that we couldn't order dessert. Was I told that I needed to move on after an hour at any point in the booking process or at the reception? No I was not. At such a prestigious establishment, I would definitely expect better customer service.

roS4HU46ZwYeTQL9XuA6Og.text: Tea for two, and two for tea, just me for you, and you for me...Spent a splendid lovely Saturday afternoon tea here with a good friend at the Wolseley during a break from the hustle and bustle of London. It boasts a classy atmosphere and is located in a quaint part of town, next to the Ritz Hotel. Do come here with a nice friend or partner, have proper English tea, chat away and indulge in delicious cakes.Nice add for tourists: has free WiFi - ask the server for a code.

ZLsK3uOfmuIHf0nyx5uMog.text: Funny enough as an Englishman I've never gone somewhere specifically for afternoon tea, Just isn't something your average person does. I suppose it was about time.We reserved for 5:45 (last slot for afternoon tea). We were greeted very warmly and although we had arrived about 10-15 minutes early our table was ready for us. They offered a coat check, and a coat rack near our table however as we had plenty of space we kept our jackets with us.Our waiter, just to start with, was brilliant. I never caught his name but he was on top of everything and was great in all his services. The kind of waiter whom even when he is focused on one table is still looking out for the others.I decided to order The Wolseley Imperial (note: the actual menu is much more extensive than what is available online). It was delicious, sharp, chocolatey and decaffeinated all at the same time. It came with a chocolate and a very small glass of water. As my gf will definitely review about her experience I'll skip out on that, but I will tell you that the tea sandwiches, sweets and scones (+clotted cream & jam) that came with hers were all scrumptious and served elegantly. Our waiter was even nice enough to bring me out an extra plate when he saw I was sampling from her selection.Afternoon tea is fun.

EqK7VdX5N9YXY00W-f9yVA.text: i've been going to the wolseley for the past 5 years. i love this place. the food is well prepared and reasonably priced by london standards.service is correct and usually gracious. i went for an omelet with gruyere and herbs and asked for the eggs firm not runny. it came that way along with my added order of frites and green salad. yumbo.here is how a class restaurant treats a customer . my glass of champs came flat(it was mid day). the maitre'd returned with a new bottle and poured right in front of me.with a smile.

FGK5zf2r9BpgwdkjM6gY9Q.text: What a great place to take in the English tradition of an afternoon tea.The service was excellent, we were waited on by no less than 4 different servers taking care of us during our tea.While the actual tea we chose (the Wolseley Blend) was not really to my liking, everything else was exceptional.The traditional finger sandwiches (cucumber & cream cheese, smoked salmon/cream cheese, celery and a tasty curry chicken) were excellent and there were more than enough to go around.While the dessert offerings were tasty as well, I really enjoyed the scones with clotted cream and strawberry preserves.The scones were perfectly baked, firm, but airy.  I recommend making a reservation, which will guarantee you a table for up to 90 minutes.  Which you'll need in order to savor the food and atmosphere of this place.

fU_3vri8DUlWLD1o0jTw4Q.text: Wonderful Afternoon TeaExcellent tea, pastries and service. It's right next to the Ritz Hotel and the addresses are a little confusing. Once you find it, enjoy!

yFATVQ4IP3S9dyvODYCWHg.text: A highlight of my trip to London..!My girlfriend & I did afternoon tea at The Wolseley, and it was wonderful.  Love the ambiance above all, and the service was terrific.  We ordered the basic tea which came with warm scones, fresh jam & clotted cream.  Heavenly!  I didn't want to leave, and nearly didn't because it was raining.Don't forget to make a reservation; people were turned away at 4pm.

5onzgK2grz6Hm--Pa4eIag.text: I love it!  Cool vibe, fresh fab oysters, I will come back next time I'm here!  yum

Pxxe6qazZnE5T3tURoSJRg.text: So this is really a two part review. The first time I went to the Wolseley was for afternoon tea and I thought it was a five star experience.  Waiting in the bar before being seated eating the delightful cheese puffs and drinking champagne it just felt really fun and swanky. The tea itself was really good and I thought a great value for money.  I totally recommend going there for tea and when people come to visit this is a destination that I recommend. The second time I went was for dinner, it was an overall disappointment.  Probably because my tea experience was so first rate I had really high expectations, unfortunately the expectations feel disappointingly short.  I ordered the Sole, one of my favourite fish dishes, and it just lacked flavour.  Service was okay, but not super efficient, and to top it all off it really aggrieves me to pay a cover charge.  I totally understand restaurants needs to cover their costs, but I would prefer paying a little more for my meal than having a cover charge attached, it feels like a slap in the face. On the continent I am more forgiving of the cover charge, but to date the Wolseley is the only high end restaurant I've been to where cover attaches so it's not the norm.  I will be back for afternoon tea, but it is not a dining destination for me for dinner.

17KdM6wVQYxn9ucvLe2vmg.text: The Wolseley restaurant is located on Piccadilly street in the Mayfair District of London.  The restaurant is located in a fabulous building with high vaulted ceilings.  The patrons are hip, fashionable and upscale; the atmosphere is lively and vibrant and the food is excellent.  This is a great restaurant for Schnitzel (pork, veal or beef) and Fish and Chips; they have an interesting and varied menu with several appetizers, seafood and meat entrees.  The only problem with this restaurant is that a good venue is not just about food; it's also about the way you are treated and the attitude of the staff or front man / woman.  On this point, they are one of the worst restaurants in London to eat at.  It doesn't matter how well you are dressed, how often you frequent the restaurant or how much money you spend on wine; you will likely be treated with the same arrogant, indifferent and unaccommodating staff. It's not worth it.  Not recommended.

ot53_5J_NfEBN3ZrAa9zbg.text: Exclusive, quite expensive, but utterly beautiful. While dinner and lunch is good, The Wolseley breakfast menu is the bomb. You can get almost anything and everything is very tasty.

Jbnpea-OL7mZ4oFJ7pS4jQ.text: Great for celeb spotting and good food - Large portions. Beautiful ambience, I really recommend it. There is also a private dining room which would be great for a business lunch/ special occasion.

z1el67jEWQ9ubk7_9SlpJQ.text: The service sucks and food is average. It's seriously overrated. If you go once, it will satisfy the touristy curiosity.

GWXzG3et37oHoeHZt8jAQA.text: Beautiful structure and friendly service with lots of wine selections.. Just a must experience.  Enjoy it and don't miss it while in London.

YNEuUq5-HDBMS5_tH8FK9g.text: First off, the doorman David is just lovely! So cheerful and full of fun facts about London. Second, bringing a stroller into a restaurant usually invites many annoyed stares from the guests and sometimes staff, but not at the Wolseley! When the hostess realized my baby was asleep in the stroller, she actually asked two guests who were already seated if they would move to another table so as to accommodate us. We had afternoon tea and the pastries were amazing! All together a fantastic experience!

3S0m73fJ64GcPuqh07tytA.text: This review is for breakfast only. We made a booking here based on a friend's recommendation. Little did I know that she had only come here for tea, and not breakfast! On a Friday morning, the restaurant was bustling with businessmen (and women). We even saw one businessman whose secretary came in late but immediately pulled out her notebook and furiously started to take notes! (How oldschool)!Hubs and I really wanted to try some classic English breakfast food, so he had the English Breakfast and I had the Eggs Benedict (with ham). I ordered the large, and that was the typical size I'm used to, which comes with 2 halves of an English muffin, the poached egg, ham, sauce, and nothing else. I imagine the small only comes with one muffin. The English Breakfast was a bit more exciting and we both really enjoyed the black pudding, which we've never had before. Overall the food was pretty good, but very pricey with no "WOW" factor. They charge you the same, i.e. an arm, for an Americano (they don't offer filter coffee) or other espresso drinks, which is weird to me. The Americano was drinkable, to say the least. I should have had a latte instead so that the milk could help cover up the taste. I was also surprised that the service wasn't that great even though they charge pretty high prices. The servers really weren't all that attentive and we had to flag them down for everything. Another weird thing is that shortly after sitting down, one of the hosts came up to my booth, reached behind my back to grab my umbrella, saying that another customer had left it, and started walking away with my umbrella! I think normal people would ask if it's OK to look around the booth where I'm sitting and also ask if the umbrella is mine. How many millions of Londoners carry a black umbrella on a rainy day?!I probably wouldn't come back here, for breakfast or any other meal. I really don't like pay high prices for average service or less.

CSVsz0WBgaItYexTgjWM2Q.text: Please don't waste your time or money here. The decor and experience of afternoon tea was marred by the poor service and stale scones. Only one of our scones were fresh but the contrast it drew from the others that were hard as rocks was startling enough for us to request they be taken away. One of our party of 3 actually was a baker and an afternoon tea enthusiast and noted her scones only ever get that hard after they've been sitting be out for a few days. Beyond stale scones, getting the attention of waiters was nearly impossible and even when we finally did, it took a second request for hot water and another 30 minutes before it came. The automatic service tip included with the bill for such terrible service was insulting. The Wolseley seemed like a promising alternative to the ritz, which is next door, however, if you really want the classic afternoon tea experience, don't do it here. Spend the extra £10 and go to the ritz.

qej5y53wH-Du6vLQ8sgfIw.text: A lovely brasserie on Picadilly which is far more relaxed and welcoming than you'd perhaps expect due to its location, prestige and prices. That being said, it's a worth treating yourself to dinner or an afternoon tea if you have relatives in town or want to impress someone.You can wear what you'd like and if you just want a cup of tea and a bit of cake, instead of a full-blown lunch, well that's ok too. Don't be fooled by the look of the top-hat adorned door staff and swanky location, it's surprisingly relaxed.I had written this place off, but was taken here by a knowledgeable friend. It's now on my 'hidden up my sleeve' list.

GU7WiB4Q1zBLLQ_ZBgIP0A.text: I came here for lunch on a 11 hour layover at Heathrow.  The service was great and the food was good.  It is a bit pricy for what you get... but that may also be a result of the weak dollar!  All in all it is worth the visit.  I came toward the end of Afternoon tea.  I think I am the only person in the pace that did not have Tea.  I had the dumping soup and roast beef platter.  Both were very good.

drZf5rLu0siU9SKXg8oktw.text: One of my most favourite restaurants for Breakfast ... Wonderful atmosphere and welcoming staff.. Even with out a reservation the waiting area has a lovely bar where you can browse through the menu ... with The beautiful smell of freshly brewed coffee And perfectly poached eggs.. This is a must on your London list

1XZQWaglOdrbmwVFh039lA.text: Wonderful 'posh' breakfast here this morning.  We managed to sneak in a visit before they close for a 3 week refurbishment this afternoon.  I had a Wolseley fishcake with poached egg, I was planning on sharing the Viennoiserie basket with a friend later, but felt quite full after the breakfast and the divine hot chocolate.  The best thing about this place is the amazing service, you are well taken care of and attended to from the moment you arrive.  The food is faultless.  The price is very reasonable, on a par with any good café and is real value for money.  I can't wait to go back again!

8jA70iix4LDUuJ2Zp3iI3w.text: Does exactly what is says on the tin. Lovely spot for brunch in a beautiful setting. Perfect for marking a special occasion.

_2UQPA6ihJ2P0j-wrHOO6Q.text: The mixed basket of pastries was delicious as was the hot chocolate.  The service was excellent, too.  Although it is pricy, it was worth it.  Recommend it highly.

xVwwXSIaE9R70lGMXGNRPw.text: As Americans, we're perfectly aware that afternoon high tea is usually an "imaginary construct," designed to entice tourists into the mists of Downton Abbey-style nostalgia. Nevertheless, we were willing to pay the going price of 37 pounds for the afternoon champagne tea at this generally well-reviewed former auto showroom.The room is, as noted, elegantly appointed, aspiring to the grand cafes in Paris and Vienna. And after being graciously welcomed, we were prepared for the fantasy to continue. But this was not to be. We were brought down to earth almost immediately by the fact that for some reason, we were among the few tables that were left bare without a tablecloth. When we asked for one, it was dutifully unfurled, with considerable help on our part. We were also surprised by the presence of paper napkins when other tables were laid out with cloth. Again, our request was rather peremptorily fulfilled. Maybe it was a sign of superior staffing, but we found ourselves confused by the fact that we were waited on by at least four different people, though it was difficult to find anyone who actually paid much attention to us. Water glasses were left unfilled and teapots unrefreshed.  The food was fine and we were impressed by the beautiful tea tray and specially designed tea strainers.But frankly, for 37 pounds we expected much more attentive service. And a more enjoyable "afternoon tea" experience.

zXn4ajOI0e7OlObF0J16Cg.text: Lovely location for tea. Had the Cream Tea for 9.75 and it was perfectly nice if you do not want to spurge for the full tea. They give you three fruit scones, clotted cream and jam and a choice of teas. I had the afternoon tea blend and thought it was good. We booked a table a few days ahead of time and had a 3:30 Sunday reservation and were told we had the table until 5 which was a sufficient amount of time.

P95YtOG-90d_1tc0yz4tcQ.text: I had dinner here tonight with a group of friends, latish, around 9:30. Since we had not booked a table ahead of time, we had to wait, which was fine and what we expected. We found a space at one of the bars and had a very nice cocktail, and the bartender was happy to explain the details of the drink we chose, and yes, it was indeed quite tasty.Once we were seated, we were not quite as happy. Our waiter was slow in getting to our table, but once there, he was able to recommend a nice wine for one of my friends, and was quite able to explain the various menu choices.  Once he took our order, however, it was quite a while before we saw our food. We were not served all at the same time - one friend had to wait and encourage us to eat our food before it got cold, rather than waiting for him to be served. Once we were all eating, our drinks glasses got empty and stayed empty until we managed to flag down a passing waiter and get some more. The food we had was quite good, and we really enjoyed it. I started with the escargot, which was served too hot - but once it cooled down I fell in love with the garlicky buttery goodness of it.  I had the grilled trout, and it was delicious.  Two friends tried the kedgeree, and said that it was quite good. The fish special (it was Hake tonight) another colleague had was deemed OK but rather bland. But, we were very frustrated with the inattentive service. When paying top dollar for an evening out, we expected to be treated better than that. We actually had to go find our waiter to get the check so that we could leave. And that is the only reason I knocked their review down from 5 stars. I would actually have knocked it down to 3 stars, but.....they redeemed themselves with the dessert. DO NOT SKIP DESSERT! IT IS FABULOUS! I had the treacle tart, which was sweet, but tempered by the side of slightly bitter cream. Oh yum! It was so good. One friend had the "Pot of Chocolate" which he said was divine.  The chocolate éclair was exquisite as well, and don't hesitate to try their ice cream dishes. All wonderful.
