This made up in large part for the inattentive waiter.So - if you can put up with the poor service, this place is worth going to. Just go when you have plenty of time and keep on top of the waiter if he is too slow.On the way out, the doorman called a cab for us, which was a lovely touch, and greatly appreciated. I'd be willing to give them another try to see if the service improved - maybe we just hit it on an off night.

BVqPjktw-D23mJBQnDRXMg.text: As a fashionista with a 30th birthday to celebrate, I felt it time to demand someone take me to this fine eatery. For breakfast. I've heard this is a very 'London' thing to do. Fabulous.Located on Piccadilly, next to the famous Ritz Hotel, proudly stands The Wolseley. I was impressed instantly. Its a very grand, high ceiling, swanky establishment. which I felt, strangely, quite New Yorkesque. The staff were smartly dressed, uber helpful (even seated us though we were 20 mins early for our reservation). I strongly recommend booking. It was packed. It was a Monday morning but absolutely nothing felt 'Monday morning'. Everyone was glam, I sat next to a Hermes Birkin for heavens sake. Which leads me to say,seating is relatively tight but I felt it added to the ambiance and lively buzz. The food. I had two boiled eggs and soldiers. Which were cooked to perfection, obviously organic and large in size. Winning. Exactly the right amount of soldiers too. Was also well presented. Gush gush gush. Other half had a sausage sandwich with relish. He didn't speak whilst devouring it which always indicates he's in heaven. At the end, he declared 'it smashed it'. Great with words is my boy. The staff also brought over a birthday double choc brioche (mentioned 30th bday when booking). Epic. And obviously on the house. I will dream about that beauty for a long time to come. Yum.Now, the bill arrives. This whole jaunt, latte, apple juice and water,came to 20 English pounds. Including service. You'd pay more in a rubbish service station!!! Hubs will mention this fabulous priced meal to day he dies, as he loves a bargain (slight Jewish heritage). We will come back again. And again. And again. I want afternoon tea next. And then dinner....we looked at steak prices too...still really good value. Swoon.

5rXeLLEnKm2HWqjuIVp3Ew.text: I am so happy with my afternoon tea.  If only I could replicate the scones and finger sandwiches. Amazing service. Highly recommend. Reservation recommended.

yhm7zwj-q2Kk8JASg_vLwQ.text: Excellent breakfast, very upscale and classy establishment, would highly recommend to anyone visiting London.

6sNSoeUMVhOlEPIgbrM0Wg.text: Solid food but nothing mind blowing. I would not say this is a must try place. I've come here twice for breakfast this trip and both times I've walked away kind of meh about the food and experience. Had the eggs Benedict the first time - it was good, VERY fresh eggs! (Although one of mine was over cooked) Ordered the large which is the normal portion size but it's much more filling because the muffin they use is quite thick and heavy (didn't love it) - for sure could have gotten away with a small that day. Also had a cappuccino which was nothing great (TRAVEL TIP: go to MONMOUTH for the best cappuccino you may have ever had. They said best coffee in London but it may have been my best ever. It def. put up a challenge for even cappuccino in Italy!) The next visit I had the French Toast and my bf had the Crispy Bacon Roll with Fried Egg. Mine was just whatever - nothing to write home about but not bad. My bf really liked his sandwich - I tried it - it was good but again - nothing special. To drink I had the hot chocolate with whipped cream which LOOKED amazing but again, fell short for me. Also the second time around the service was kind of whatever. The first time was fine though. Both days we did not have a reservation, we were able to just go in and be seated.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Hot Chocolate (looks awesome! nothing special taste wise) I was disappointed.
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. French Toast (I had my bacon on the side)

oytVzYOYX4jGolUkI4yVFg.text: The Wolseley is a fine old building that apparently housed a car dealership many years ago. The place is grand, bustling and has  a great atmosphere to dine in. Good place to take groups. If you're looking for high gastronomy this is not your place. Found it expensive, but I found that everywhere in London.

Qv8jUHjxW_fXwUlj9QbquA.text: We read the reviews on The Wolseley and were anxious to try it. We had a party of seven and tried a variety of things: French toast, haggis, eggs Benedict, etc. each item that we had was delicious!!  Also the fresh juices offered were fresh and very good!  I would highly recommend brunch at The Wolseley!!  The only downside that we experienced was slow service at our table in taking the order and receiving the check but we did get our food quickly. We would go back if we had time on this trip!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

kLiRTgclkbacP8-oEsGlcw.text: Brunch here is a must on every visit to London. The full English and the Benedicts are great choices.

NZYkfewQkLjqNnu00pYndw.text: I went there because it's on my list of the 50 best London restaurants but couldn't afford a real meal so went for breakfast.I was a bit afraid they wouldn't let me in because I wasn't dressed nice, but it doesn't matter. That's what I like about those kind of places. Yes they're posh and luxurious but everyone can go in (I saw tourists with giant backpacks).The place is really luxurious, the waiters are over polite and the choice for breakfast was amazing: Traditional british, baskets of bread, viennoiseries cooked on the premise, all the eggs you can wish for...I had avocado mash on toast and a cappuccino. I am ranking those 2nd on list. They were delicious (but lacking feta in my taste). Coffee was a bit blend, but I like really really strong coffee.Overall a good experience, just a tiny bit pricey (my breakfast cost me £17, ouch)

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Avocado mash.

MfJMJtCM9wVroNizcLXpag.text: I came here for breakfast with some friends.  The pastries are fresh and the avocado open faced sandwich was my favourite. The eggs benedict is a great choice but portions are small.Tea time will set you back £25 or so.Lots of tourists and expats (myself included)

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Pastry spread

WFuCSbBN4hNFBn6b5LsyKQ.text: we had the full afternoon tea here, and it was a great experience. the scones, the pastries, the tea, the service, the traditional ambiance... all impeccable. i wasn't a huge fan of the sandwiches on the bottom of the high tea spread, but to each their own.our servers were all extremely attentive and refilled our tea just as soon as it was emptied. we took a fancy to the little silver strainer that came with the pot of tea, and our server did research on where we could acquire one of our own. if you want a traditional high tea in a classy traditional setting, this is about as good as it gets. mind you, there is a premium associated with the pomp and circumstance, but you aren't just paying for scones and tea, you are paying for an experience.

EZsCsPldWlp4Svl1j2M1_Q.text: I probably read over 100 restaurant reviews and asked local friends for their recommendations before deciding where to eat when I was in London in November. Hands down the #1 recommendation was always The Wolseley. Everything was impeccable from the reception staff who accommodated a table change, to the knowledgeable server, who never made us feel rushed, to the iconic and stately interior to the food, which was cooked to perfection.I had a large Salad Nicoise and my friend had the Wiener Schnitzel and french fries. Everything was cooked to perfection and washed down with a gorgeous bottle of Bordeaux. In fact, we enjoyed the place so much that we returned later in the afternoon for another bottle of wine.I would highly recommend the Wolseley and will make a point of dinning there every time I am in London.

Ge4CJScQvNS-_X7LFKwPdQ.text: We did not have a reservation so we were seated in the bar section and the service was not keeping up. Tea selection is limited. Food is just OK. Although we were several guests with the same order, the cake selection was different with nicer cakes in one of the plates and I asked if I could get the same instead of what I was presented with. The waiter was annoyed and got the cook to come and see me. He warned me that he would do it but only for that only time! The whole experience was weird and unpleasant. I would not recommend. It is better to spend a little more and have a really nice afternoon tea.

Xyra685SKP8jUolAeuIl8Q.text: Beautiful Architecture. Very Fancy! Enjoyed a wonderful dinner with my husband! On vacation and wanted a special place to celebrate.

H9T-TKKUazFb9ZntSAet7Q.text: I left London over a week ago and all I dream about is tea and scones. I absolutely LOVE love love The Wolseley.A couple friends and I had planned for afternoon tea after doing a few touristy things and shopping on Bon Street. Since we didn't make a reservation (the place is packed, I suggest you do), it was about a 25 minute wait for three. They asked us to wait in the bar area which was great for chatting and sipping on whatever libations until our table was ready. While small, the bar had great energy and was chill.By the time our table was ready, so was my tummy. We ordered tea for two even though there were three of us. If you ask, they will make your sandwiches vegetarian (no crust, because that's how they do). The earl grey and darjeeling tea were both sooo good, I couldn't decide which one I liked best. Presentation here totally makes the experience. Not only do you get three tiers of delicious noms, clotted cream and fresh jam on lovely china, but your tea comes in a silver set- completing the experience.The scones. I'm drooling just thinking of them. These scones are absolute perfection. Take one, cut it in half, pile on the clotted cream with a dab of strawberry jam, and take a small bite. I promise you will want to wolf this down, but don't. Savor the flavor, texture, warmth, and crumb. They also don't start making them until 3:00pm which means they are as fresh as you can get. After eating these scones, when eating others you will always seek the same perfection. Nothing compares!So now that I've told you about afternoon tea, I can also tell you about breakfast.The eggs benny with salmon was so delicious, I almost ordered a seconds! The English muffin it was served on was totally noteworthy. It remained fluffy even with all the hollandaise sauce smothered all over it. The hollandaise was so well flavored and balanced I've already recreated it at home! I very much loved the cappuccino with a touch of cocoa.I can't even tell you how many times I came here (I mean, I can if I look at my bank statement) and each time I left satisfied and happy. This place needs to be on the top of your list when visiting London. Let's just say I came here almost once everyday if not twice.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

U2sTOe55At2TZEkjBRBgVQ.text: Came here for lunch after seeing the guards at the buckingham palace. My friends and I found this place on yelp with high ratings and decided to give it a try. I was really looking forward to the experience, but ended up being quite disappointed from their food. To start off our meal, we ordered lobster bisque, it was cooked with cognacs so it doesn't taste good at all. Maybe just not what I was expecting. I also got the large benedicts which came with two eggs and ham to share with my friends. The bread that came with it was pretty bad. Super hard to cut with our knives. We also had the pork belly, which tasted a bit weird and was really dry, I think it was cooked with pear or peach so more of a sweet taste to it. We ordered their rib eye steak (medium), but it was raw in the middle. My friends also got their earl gray tea and black/breakfast tea, both were unimpressed. The meal was pricey overall, about 32 pounds per person and really not worth that price. I'd recommend going somewhere else and avoid having your lunch here, service was extremely slow and you get charged 2 pounds per person for cover charge.Maybe you'll have better luck trying their afternoon tea.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

5bTCxhnuTq_0wZnw-dhTcg.text: I had brunch there with my boyfriend. I  ordered  the  famous  pancake  with  berries  andq my  boyfriend  ordered  the  English  breakfast. Service  and food were  both  good  but  didn't  meet  my  expectation of  the  great  standard.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

YSZy7QawEcFFvcvwHs0d0A.text: I came here for afternoon tea with hubby & 8 month old baby. Staff were nice and accommodating. Food was simple but delicious. We had tea with pastries and scones and omg! They were amazing!!!Definitely will return for food when we go back to England!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

GgfFNeRs0dyGTRcvNU7IMg.text: Took my nan there for her first afternoon tea ever and she absolutely loved it ! The food was great and we had a  good time. My only issue was how noisy it was, which I hadn't expected as I booked it online. Would have preferred if it had a been a bit more quieter, nonetheless we had a splendid afternoon and both my grandma and i are not not going to forget it anytime soon.

K8nphWnmBlgIfjrlRO00sA.text: Gorgeous interior in a historic spot. Come for high tea and enjoy the pampering. Come as you are- it seemed to be a pretty mixed bag of people, but it looked like mostly tourists.High tea is 27.50GBP per person. Tip: if you're two people, just get one to share. Don't get two like us. It's nice because of the variety, and if you accidentally get two, you just get more of each item, which is not that exciting.High tea comes with:- 2 fruit scones, freshly baked with clotted cream and strawberry jam- 3 dessert pastries (ex: Battenburg cake, passionfruit tart, cheescake)- 5 finger sandwiches (chicken tarragon, egg, cucumber, smoked salmon, sundried tomato)- Choice of teaService is slow, so try to carve out some time to enjoy.Make your reservation online beforehand for no wait.

8ogW2MNhwcyyTeZBvZUbJw.text: Great food but average service. I ordered the French Toast and my sister ordered the Eggs Benedict both were very delicious and it was a good portion. We also ordered the hot chocolate and mocha which were both really good too. However, our server was MIA after our orders were taken and we could not get any attention from the staff. We wanted to get our bill and water and tried to call any passing waiters but they were either just too busy or ignoring us considering surrounding families were getting attention. One staff member apologized and got our bill to us quickly after that. There seems to be a big staff prescence but they couldn't help a table of two.

KvHlcUhDT8Ol6Whic3gAmg.text: I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!I am a classless American and came in not super nice clothes. If I had more control over my wardrobe (aka, not trying to pack a week's worth of clothes into a small carry-on), I would wear nicer clothes because this place is super cute. You won't be turned away, though! They even have a doorman who is SUPER nice! It would be easier if you make a reservation if possible, but can be on standby and still make your way in for high tea. I LOVED THE HIGH TEA. Boyfriend and I had this recommended to us by boyfriend's cousin, and we went all out on the full high tea: Tea, scones, desserts, finger sandwiches....love. It was so beautifully served and everything was delicious. The venue is lovely and beautiful and impressive. Service is nice as well. Everything is served beautifully, with lovely dishware to intricately made food. The scones are GREAT and the clotted cream...cmon America. You've been making terrible decisions lately (I mean, we just found out Trump is president...are you kidding me), but we can make 1 step of progress by bringing around scones and clotted cream. This was one of my favorite experiences in London. Do yourself a favor and check it out. It's a little pricey IMO (about $35 each when I went, which I understand changes with the exchange rates, etc), but 100% worth it!

_Gp9RBI2EpzvmPI2RRywsg.text: Came here for our anniversary dinner and was very special.The whole setting is beautiful and very smart. We didn't get a chance to go to the bar but also looks great.The food was incredible but very easy to get large and rich portions. I had the quail eggs (wow, just wow) followed by schnitzel with creamed spinach on the side. Delicious but filling! Luckily I also had enough space for the chocolate eclair.One of their meals or drinks (I can't remember) was also called the Lucian after Lucian Freud, who used to dine there, which was cute. Especially for my girlfriend who had read his book.Make sure you get a booking in advanced as it's almost always packed. We had a late dinner (9:45) and was still very lively.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Homemade (I think!) chocolate eclair

c2UCme0GWEkML9W-kw0lAg.text: I was waiting for a friend by the Green Park tube station and stumbled onto this place in the shadow of The Ritz and decided to have a peek inside. Beautiful space. High ceilings. Smartly dressed folks.I thought i'd try my luck at getting a table, though it looked full. There was a 45 minute wait without a reservation, so I put my name down. I was already about 30 minutes early to meet my friend, as i thought it would take a while to find a suitable restaurant for lunch on Sunday; she didn't mind waiting another 15 minutes, either.We ended up being seated right next to the entrance to the restaurant -- in the entryway itself. My friend told me that if she was on a date with me, i would have lost points with her. I think that getting reservations is probably a good idea, which makes this place kind of a gamble for the impulse diner... especially if you're entertaining a guest. Considering that I was dressed like a Levi's store mannequin, i'm kind of surprised that they'd want to seat me in such a visible location. i'd say it would be bad for business but the bill ran pretty high... so i think they did OK.We were about 45 minutes early for the afternoon tea menu, but managed to snag some incredible steak tartare and some of the most delicious shrimp that i've ever eaten in my life. I've been searching for a shrimp that compares since my visit here a couple months ago to no avail. I'm from a city on the Pacific coast, and we know our crustaceans -- The Wolseley knows them better.A great dining experience, with some good wine and interesting conversation. I'll be back for afternoon tea.

qONuxVfAsIRK0hUuwOSZog.text: In a hurry, so I don't have time to write a review that does this place justice.The room itself is stylish, upscale, and impressive.  At times I thought I was dining inside of a palace.  I felt way too schlumpy in my jeans and Patagonia jacket, but I didn't have time to change before dinner.I ordered the green risotto, which is made with a vegetarian base and had my taste buds doing the happy dance.  Best risotto of my life, and I am obsessed with risotto.  The mint in it was the PERFECT accent flavor.  I also had mint tea, which was the swanky london type of tea (mint leaves buried under boiling water).  Gorgeous presentation.  Delicious and refreshing.  I can't remember what dessert I ordered, but I remember it being incredible.  Something with apples perhaps?An easy five stars.  It was a smidge pricey for me, but it wasn't at all over-priced given the quality of the meal.  I can't wait to go back.

GBdoMs6g7ubWAqirxD624A.text: This has to be my most favourite restaurant for treats,special occasions whatever. Breakfast is wonderful, lunch iand dinner too.... In fact, if I could live here I would! Christopher Corbin and Jeremy King just succeed everytime, I cannot falut this place!

aKg4PxrNhadF7Spd3sLkpw.text: I am a huge fan- love it for breakfast and brunch. First time I went to try the Wolsley was for dinner; on their website they mentioned there is no need to call for booking, but when I went there I was asked if I have made a reservation and therefore had to wait at the over-crowded bar for over 45 minutes. the selection of food wasn't helpful that evening and staff were very distracted. I pass by frequently during morning times and find it very shinny and welcoming. it is queiter as well, so you can enjoy your coffee and newspaper. Love the place even though none of my friends like it :(

RV2MRScyaJh0fLHm9AAbwA.text: The Wolseley...my London Love!We tried to go somewhere else for afternoon tea, but they tried to shove us in this tiny table, so we decided to leave. We walked by The Wolseley on our way back to the hotel and decided to stop in. We were dressed pretty crappy (like typical tourists, hey, at least we were warm) and asked if they had a table for 4. They said we would have to be out by 6:30, which was almost 2 hours, plenty of time!We did the 19 pound/person afternoon tea, which came with a pot of tea for each of us, scones with clotted cream & strawberry jam (that was my favorite part), tea sandwiches (cucumber, roast beef, egg, cheese, salmon), and assorted pastries (my favorite was the battenburg cake).The atmosphere at The Wolseley is awesome, it used to be an old car showroom, then a bank, and now a restaurant. The interior is black and white kind of art deco style, but not. Very hard to explain, but very classy looking.We came back to The Wolseley for dinner a few days later and like before, the staff was very friendly, but the dinner food just wasn't as good as afternoon tea. I would highly recommend afternoon tea, dinner, not so much.I love The Wolseley, the staff is SUPER friendly even if you are dressed crappy, they will happily seat you. The afternoon tea is awesome and the food is just ok.

wJIgYwYhE8ew_ZVPu8Bq7A.text: A terrific place in the Mayfair area.  The decor is distinctive and interesting. It's a classic looking building that was formerly a bank and has a great feel to it. We came with a large group and the staff could not have been more accommodating. Our first meal was a late lunch and was great. Classic English fare, with modern touches as well. The Welsh Rarebit was delicious as were all our dishes. Breakfast the next day was even better. The classic English breakfast was just the right portion and the black pudding and bacon were especially good. Great service, terrific food and they even had the bag of guide books put aside that we had forgotten there the first day we ate there. The main room can get a bit loud but they have a quieter side parlor or two upper balconies as well. A lucky find.

8XnxezdOrrh0ksp_tb1jAQ.text: Went for afternoon tea. We were told we'd get a table in the salon but then were put in the small bar, not exactly the ambiance I was hoping for when splurging a substantial sum for tea, sandwiches & pastry. Service was brusque and unattentive; room was loud. Actual tea, sandwiches and pastries were good. All in all it was an OK experience but I wish we'd gone somewhere else.

b_M3hQ2cn08wnExaOX-XVQ.text: i love this place they have  very good service, i would recommend to anybody want to eat .

Bs2k0xsN8260ad390sIBfw.text: I booked an early pre-theatre dinner at the Wolseley on a Friday night and could not have been happier with my experience. From a friendly host to jolly barmen to a charming German waitress, the service was impeccable. I had a delicious lamb pot roast -- something I've never seen on any menu at home in the states -- and a delightfully tart summer pudding. With a predinner cocktail, glass of wine, and afterdinner coffee my part of the bill was in the neighborhood of 35 pounds. Highly recommended -- I will return on my next visit to London. (And-- free WiFi! Ask the barman to enter the code for you.)

NbTxHK7gZHzkwPcw_bWtfw.text: The price is good for a place like this. However, the food is OK and not very delicate.This restaurant has very fancy interior. If you want to sit in the fancy area rather than sitting at the lamed tables right next to the door, make reservation!!!

eteD8KyUBuxvodrf2RE0Xg.text: LOVELY! I came here for my leaving dinner in a large group of family and friends. The decor and ambiance of the restaurant is absolutely stunning - very stylish and art deco. The building used to be a bank in the 1920s, a post box and a stamp machine are still in the restaurant.We enjoyed multiple bottles of wonderful white wine and Prosecco with our raw oysters on the half shell. They were SO delicious, probably some of the most fantastic raw oysters I have had and were perfect paired with the white wine we chose.To this day, the Wolseley remains one of my favourite restaurants in London and I cannot wait to return.

u-iOci4pGcwaM1BDuhA-uA.text: This was a perfect spot for a chic, but affordable, afternoon tea.  The scones that come with the cream tea are amazing, and the atmosphere is great.

h2uFwGCcaJWbZRJyh5Iu2Q.text: I was hoping for something special at The Wolseley. I booked for brunch just to be sure. But the experience was a real let-down. Expensive, unimpressive food. Uppity and dismissive service (to the point of being unfriendly). Noisy, to the point of painful. Nothing at all special about the place.

yCCDlMicL3w87AvPPpmjZA.text: Have you ever been wondering to what the art nouveau decoration belongs to after passing Ritz. Well I found out about Wolseley when I worked for a designer. That Saturday we wanted to make some market/price comparison and we decided Bond Street, the street of the luxury labels is the place to start of with.But this did not happened before treating ourselves to a good breakfast. Especially when you get up on Saturday before 10 o'clock.I recommend to make a reservation ahead, as Wolseley is well liked by many early Saturday morning shoppers.We ordered porridge, boiled eggs and of course a proper English Breakfast. The table is nicely equipped an sugar, marmalade, honey come in little pots.I recommend the earl grey tea as breakfast tea with milk.The place is very light - and if you are able to get a table on the inside balcony you can overview the whole restaurant or simply read the Financial times week end edition. Not only have you already read up on the weekend news but also are ready when Bond street slowly wakes up.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. The art nouveau entrance
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. The Wolseley

uDOafzOMbbeFTOLOA8D5kw.text: I enjoyed the experience overall since it was my first night in London and it was close to my hotel. Waiters were frustrated and our order kept getting messed up, however, they apologized and it was fine in the end. It is a beautiful restaurant that is very lively and close to the Ritz/Glenn Park station. Worth a try if you are new to London and the brunch menu looks great.

CM93ao8h82No1AS8DMokQQ.text: as well as being in a fantastic part of london, everything looked and tasted amazing, the breakfast was delicious, we couldnt fault it, and the service was fantastic

S3Tr8vRYzeTVTp0YUeYkXA.text: The restaurant host today was very rude. We were told that we cannot sit in a table of four if we are only three. I never heard of any restaurant with such an unreasonable policy, but I would have kept my peace had they implemented this policy equally. Just after sitting on a table dedicated for three (on the back end of the restaurant just by the bathrooms) we noticed a group of three being seated on a table of four. The waiter however was helpful, when we asked about certain dishes which were no longer on the menu, he managed to get the chef to make them for us.

Umri0iNbLbFv7_P-Dk4yjg.text: The restaurant is quite stylish, upscale, and nice.  Though with the dark lighting in the front rooms, the table next to me dropped a plate on the floor.  Oopsies.I ordered the lamb chop and my mate ordered the 7 Hour Lamb plat du jour.  Both were done quite well, but the winner goes to the chop.  Cooked perfectly, with a yummy sauce.And that's all.

9D5xC1L3ZCOOiIUyhd7udA.text: this place is a gem.  my mom wanted afternoon tea before leaving london.  i recently had tea already and couldn't fathom eating another scone and heavy pastries, so the wolseley is the perfect spot.  you can order off the all-day menu or the dinner menu if it's close to dinner time.  since they serve tea until pretty late, my dad and i were able to order dinner.i got the salad nicoise, and my dad got the sunday roast w/ yorkshire pudding and a butternut squash.  the sunday roast is a DEAL and a huge portion.  it came w/ a huge yorkshire pudding and a side of green beans, potatoes, and carrots.  my salad was delicious as well.  my mom's tea came w/ a bunch of pastries that we were able to bring home for dessert.the tea here is a pretty good deal compared to those at the fancy hotels.

uxUoXnsNFGABlo5HXqBzXA.text: Of all the places you can go for afternoon tea in London, The Wolseley is by far the best.  Let me list the ways in which it reigns supreme in the realm of all things tea:1. The building is incredibly elegant, with high ceilings, beautiful floors and amazing ambiance.2. The service is impeccable.  We were sitting upstairs on the balcony.  They pointed out a little buzzer that we could ring for service at any time so that we wouldn't feel neglected, but that never happened as the waiters constantly came up and down the stairs to refill our pots, check our cream and take away empty plates.  The manager came twice to make sure we were doing okay.3.  The quality of the tea service is incredible.  They offered six different types of sandwiches, perfectly baked warm scones and an assortment of small desserts.  We polished them off as though we hadn't eaten in a week. 4. For all this you would think that the price should be outrageous, but it's not.  Afternoon tea will set you back £20 per person, but it's more than worth it for several hours of delightful chat and more than a full meal of food and goodies. In all my other reviews for afternoon tea spots, I've ended with "in a city known for its tea, you can do better."  Doing better is going to the Wolseley.  *Note: you MUST make a reservation, and likely more than a week in advance.  They fill up very quickly and it's next to impossible to walk in for tea.

x8RFCqP90dYBKKOOVB4IsQ.text: We had such a lovely breakfast here. Everything we ate was delicious and the service was wonderful. It's in a lovely part of town, Mayfair, right next to the Ritz. I had scrambled eggs and sausage (they were kind enough to accommodate this request during lunch hours), and my boyfriend had Eggs Benedict, which he said was perfect. My scrambled eggs were the best I've ever had at a restaurant. The con is the price. I knew it would be expensive, but 20 quid for scrambled eggs and sausage is extraordinary. As long as you're agreeable to the price, I couldn't recommend it more.

KwEP-wU2PzvrnHPcgCvb7A.text: --REVIEW FOR AFTERNOON TEA--I really, really wanted to love afternoon tea at the Wolesley. I had such high hopes given this place seems like the classic, high end English experience, but the food, tea, and service were all disappointingly bland. If I could choose an afternoon tea place again I totally would somewhere more unique that doesn't serve 1) basic sandwiches and pastries and 2) diluted tasting tea.The best food was the scones, hands down. Sadly we were full and asked the server if we could pack some jam and cream to go with our to go pastries, but this place is apparently too bougie to do so. Lame. Waiters were also running around, not very attentive. I guess my expectations were too high (have I been spoiled by good food and service? But this is a $$$ place with high reviews). Looking around and people who were eating dinner, their food seemed better than the afternoon tea menu.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea. Meh.

yhXEPaDecWi15HmrV0Fs6g.text: Breakfast at the Wolseley. After an early morning arrival into London I can straight here after dropping off my bags and a quick shower. I'm glad I did. The fondant hot chocolate is amazing. Hot but not too hot. Delicious dark chocolate that's not overly sweet. The fishcakes with poached egg was very nice. The fishcakes itself was excellent. It gets lost a bit in the hollandaise and poached egg but still very good. I would recommend the small portion as that was more than sufficient.

tPpUQJWs9lsx9CjxYR7Gvg.text: The dreams of participating in the ultimate Afternoon Tea experience were met at the Woseley! The restaurant is just beautiful, and the service is the creme de la creme! Everyone that works here wants you to have the best experience too, and it shows.We came in right before the holiday and were seated immediately! Talk about good timing. The place was absolutely FILLED.The Afternoon Tea special is about 25 pounds. It comes with delicious little tea sandwiches, bakery pastries, and of course, warm scones! The tea kettle dishes out 3 solid cups of tea, and by the end of it, I still wanted more!My boyfriend also ate the lobster bisque and was shoving it into his mouth like all the lobsters were going to die out tomorrow, which tells me he thoroughly enjoyed it!

9Vtep5yR_xQGh2nKPvg_6w.text: If you want a traditional afternoon tea in a great environment, go here. It's not cheap, but still reasonable for what you get. It can get noisy and you might be seated really close to other tables, but the food is great and the environment is beautiful.

p68pN_kuvR56p1eCcAU3nA.text: Just came for dessert. They have all the European classics. Lots of variety and not too sweet. Nice after dinner drink menu. If you find yourself in Mayfair with a sweet tooth then you have your spot. From what I can tell stays open later than everywhere close by. The seating and atmosphere is classy and inviting. Stop in.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

i9EJezpS6nY-XUFTSHs5PQ.text: I thought this place is a pretty touristy destination, however, when I came for breakfast/brunch, it was a surprise that there were many locals! Mostly business people. I guess tourists come here for afternoon tea? :PThe building structure and ambience is amazing, really has the old European feel. We ordered tea & coffee (the latte was also surprisingly good! Huge pot of tea, always a plus), eggs benedict, breakfast basket, fish cake, pancakes and french toasts. The portion was pretty huge, and I think it is nice that there are options to order a cheaper and smaller version (1 egg benedict instead of 2). I share the breakfast basket with a friend, and ended up couldn't finish my full portion eggs benedict (and skip lunch the same day). The fish cake had a very strong fish smell, so it wasn't my favorite even though it was recommended by a friend. All the food are decent and delicious, but the one with wow factor is the pancakes! They are thick and fluffy! I like the breakfast basket as well, all the pastries are small but with good variety.Perhaps they still have tourists problem, so our waiter informed us that they cannot help us take a picture, but we can take a group selfie ourselves? :P I did make a reservation beforehand--they have limited seating available for online reservation, but Wolseley is very responsive via email reservation as well! (Take into account of time difference). We got a more preferable reservation time via email. However, since it was breakfast and apparently more locals, the table changing rate is pretty fast, I think for smaller group (2-3 people) you might not need a reservation. In reservation they also mentioned there's a time limit (1:30), but they didn't mentioned it or ask us to leave at all.

hbKj2AY0ge5T17JehFdquw.text: Fabulous breakfast scene with delicious food. The restaurant is housed in an old car dealership and the design elements are appealing.

f7k8LNPei03jkjuzeLILjA.text: This months breakfast club ( there is only 3 of us, so not sure you can really call it a club hehe) was at the Wolseley. Our brief for the club is that it needs to be opened from 7am weekdays, and needs to be easily accessible to our offices. The Wolseley is definitely not somewhere I could afford to eat dinner at, but breakfast is super affordable. It is typical old style London class, with tons of seating, and surprisingly at 7.30am it is packed out.The menu is standard breakfast menu, with lots of options. You can pretty much add any extras to your meal. I had mashed avocado on some seeded crusty pasty thing (sorry forget the name) and added 2 poached eggs. My friends had food envy when it came out. Definitely the pick of the table. My favourite part of the experience was the coffee. Most places for breakfast give you the smallest coffee cup in the world, and I always end up having 2-3, but here they give you and entire pot to yourself, and a huge cup. So I was in coffee heaven!!! All in all the experience was amazing, and I'd go back again in a heart beat.

VEl1GzIXXUmvSs80f5ot5A.text: The food and service were both below my expectations for a meal at a properly English institution.

FWKkWx-cp1zaUvTgb6Lb1w.text: I came here to celebrate my brother's birthday. Seeing the menu provoked high expectations as everything was very expensive. Two of us had schnitzel, one had lobster and I had a steak. The steak arrived very small, nearly cold and was completely tasteless. The schnitzel had no flavour and there was very little meat on the two lobsters that were brought. It was very disappointing seeing as every item we ordered for the main course was over £25, in addition to the multiple bottles of wine that were bought. One desert was brought with plastic wrapped around it. The service is sub-par and the staff have a very irritating habit of bringing odd numbers of dishes to the table and then taking ages to bring the rest of them. The restaurant itself is beautiful, with a very busy atmosphere- but it is not worth the money. We waited for 2 hours to have one course. A far better meal could be had at any number of much less expensive places.

7g-wiv_52W_Zhbo7QJmB_Q.text: What a lovely place for brunch whilst on holiday.  The dining room is just gorgeous.The prices are typical Mayfair prices (just look at the price of breakfast next door at the Ritz!), so you have to be aware of that, however, the food is good and the service is attentive and prompt.

ReMbjOdItVRxPtXZbr11Jw.text: Enjoyed for high tea; breakfast was underwhelming. Overall it was a positive experience  but there are other restaurants I'd prefer to try rather than coming back for a take three.

oxbvqWP-kkGa0mygtHfnWg.text: Excellent spot for breakfast, although rather disorganized when very busy. The coffee is very good and juice is freshly squeezed. The English Breakfast with fried eggs is terrific. Service can be spotty, ranging from very good to poor, but of course this is a very English restaurant in the heart of London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

hlHwjzeMF0l5fKZjEzbd2A.text: My favourite spot for breakfast in London. The caramelised grapefruit is worth 5 stars alone. Everything is always spot on perfect at the Wolseley....from the excellent wait staff to the home made breads and pastries to the amazing food. Yes they serve the best pancakes in town here with crispy American style bacon. It's THE spot for your power breakfast.It's always a full house at the Wolseley, so be sure to book ahead or get there early (before 730 midweek).

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Pancakes with bacon

BtNSIzJw2fTTucYi7YHWSA.text: Many visitors know to come to the Wolseley for afternoon tea in London. I was a little skeptical about coming here, thinking that by now this place would simply be a tourist trap, but it was the contrary and even exceeded my expectation. We were seated quickly even though it was busy, gained access to free wi-fi without a glitch, and had great service. I was undecided about getting a slice of cake or the afternoon tea special (consisting of finger sandwiches, 2 scones, some small desserts/tarts, and a choice of tea), but our server was very helpful and suggested to split an afternoon tea special and get an extra  pot of tea. The server even gave us some additional sandwiches. The highlights for us were the warm scones with raisins along with clotted cream and strawberry jam. It was literally heart-warming. The tarts (we got passion fruit/meringue tart, pistachio sponge cake, and passion fruit macaron) were delightful as well. The finger sandwiches were meh, but the sandwiches are part of the afternoon tea tradition. No complaints about the English Breakfast and Afternoon Blend teas; with some milk, the teas were simply "lovely."Tourist or not, one cannot go wrong with the Wolseley.

7Dolk4NrewawJqU6TUWMDQ.text: The Wolseley is a great place to have afternoon tea. We'd made reservations ahead of time, which I highly recommend you do if you want to come here. The four of us ended up staying for about 3 hours and no one said anything to rush us. Great service, good food. What you get for your money is probably not worth it, but afternoon tea is one of those things you can splurge on for the experience.For about £22, it came with a pot of tea, finger sandwiches (egg, cucumber, smoked salmon, celery, and curry chicken), an assortment of cakes/pastries, and scones with clotted cream and jam. I remember a macaron in there somewhere. Everything looked fresh and carefully prepared. Presentation was exquisite. Although nothing was particularly unique, what they offered was well made.One last note... this is a classy establishment, but it's one of the few where you don't have to dress up. We came in jeans after a morning of wandering about, so it worked well for us. Other people around us were dressed nicely though, and this is by no means a casual place.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea (there are 2 ppl's servings here)

RJHKRvO2bBQcqNcaeq33cQ.text: Best place for afternoon tea.  Service was wonderful and the atmosphere was beautiful.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

uZRBQLXRUyyicr2KOWa7Cg.text: Came here for afternoon tea. Had a great experience and felt that everything was top notch. A reservation is highly recommended as we had to wait around 40 minutes on a Sunday to be seated and we were a party of two. Highly suggest going here if you're looking for a place with great service, location, food and ambiance. Didn't feel like the prices were too bad either for everything you get.

bfrAgd1h3Roy43uQ49IlXA.text: What can I say.. So much good food and location is just so convenient and service is great!! I love all the little spoons and place settings and how after each dish they bring out new and placed with dessert spoons on the exact right and dessert fork to left! Too bad we couldnt try afternoon tea with finger sandwiches. Will be recommending, but wait time is long especially if you don't have reservations!

T9rhFfj7oeEbFv4QZxII2Q.text: Thumbs up!  Great room, decent service, and pricing lower than what you might expect.  The food could be better, but you're not getting ripped off and the experience is more about the vibe and the crowd than it is about the food.  Fun place to take out-of-towners, and good place for a power breakfast.

GNzlwbarugqJ7Mtfj89qvA.text: Great breakfast food wad great and setting had a great atmosphere

JEiYeVqM8s6IuTJCklCcRA.text: This is a truly amazing restaurant and cafe. Lush surroundings in the style of grand-European cafes, the restaurant offers truly divine haute-cuisine dining and the cafe just as fine snacks and drinks. Come here for a 15 minute coffee (although you will end up here for over an hour!) or for a proper dinner, accompanied by an extensive array of wines. The Wolseley also has a small shop selling foodstuffs and branded nick-nacks. Situated less than five minutes away from Greenpark tube station, and in close proximity to the Royal Academy, Bond St, and many other attractions, this restaurant is a wonderful experience. But there is a price to pay, once you have payed the bill, your wallet will be considerably lighter.

MqXXSASKG9vPMcBQvsHdjw.text: What a wonderful place to have afternoon tea!  The scones, jam and best of all clotted cream is a "I've died and gone to heaven moment". The finger sandwiches and pastries are pretty good too!

yc5_0dRkbEm4tJwS8aSu-A.text: This is one of the prettiest restaurants in London.  It is a beautiful spot to eat, whether it is brunch, lunch or dinner.  The food is yummy, but definitely a bit on the old-fashioned side.  However,  you go here for the ambiance and the service, not the food so much.

Jt5RRXwl8amTpxpLnwZxgA.text: I highly recommend eating here. I had breakfast with a friend from high school. Had a delicious kipper - with mustard sauce and poached egg - along with plenty of toast and tea.  Loved it.

5gjrCEr_RgBQ_2yyMdAnqA.text: Loved this place. The food was superb, the service was great and the price was very fair. I will definitely go back when I am back in London.

HVQ4HYliGt_ZExkwE5-Vqw.text: I walked in and was immediately taken with the beautiful interiors as well as the energy of the place.  The place reminds me of Balthazar in NYC with a little more posh to it so I had relatively high expectations.  It wasn't stuffy at all, as one might surmise from the entrance..and the eye roll from our cab driver when we told him where we were going.    We had the crayfish avocado salad..which was just okay.  The steak tartare was delicious, although my friend thought it was bland.  I may not be the authority on steak tartare because I'm not a fan of mustard or onions so I prefer mixing tartares myself.  However, the Wolseley's take was already mixed, but not a whole lot of dijon mustard to contend with.  Very good.  There was also the chicken liver and foie gras terrine, which was an enormous bloc served with the thickest brioche I've ever seen.  Not big on the thick brioche, but considering how much terrine they gave, it was nice to have enough bread to put it on.  We also had the oysters which were fantastic.The bulk of my meal is always the main course and my roasted pheasant was sadly, very dry and quite bland.  Another friend ordered the same thing and was sadly poking her poor little bird while we eyed our friend's plate of calf liver.  It was definitely the tastiest dish on the table, if not a little heavy and over-bearing as a main course.My coffee was lovely.  They took enough care to shape the froth prettily and serve it on a lovely tray served sugary syrup instead of sugar cubes.  A nice touch as I really needed the coffee to gear up for a loooong night at Movida.I really want to like the Wolseley more, but I feel like we just didn't quite order the best dishes.  However, it is a such a pretty place with impeccable service, I would come back to have the afternoon tea everyone's raving about in the reviews the next time I'm in London.

N2_6V8r_O-8MrId1U_tmTQ.text: On my recent trip to England, I had the opportunity to get into London for a couple of hours on a Thursday night.  I decided to eat dinner at the Wolseley after finding it on Yelp.  Didn't get there until 10:30pm or so, but the place was still packed and alive.  It has a beautiful and open interior, which supported a mix of couples and some larger parties.The food was excellent, the beer was good (though I may have been the only person not drinking wine in the whole place!) and the service was very good.Even though the place is supposed to close at midnight, it was still alive when I left around 11:30, with people still walking in at that time.  Another great recommendation from Yelp!

0xMPF5kBi1GBmIE76xnCTw.text: Went there this a.m. to meet an old friend. The atmosphere was lively and pleasant. The service was excellent, attentive but never aggressive. The food was delicious from start to finish, we tried pastries, eggs benny, kippers, Viennese coffee. This is a new fave and I will  do my best to return whenever I'm in town!

-Cqvb_pNsf5Y1X7A4yDNDw.text: Delicious afternoon tea, didn't need a booking, even on a Saturday; Extremely friendly and accommodating staff. Of course, I'm a girl that loves a jam and cream topped scone. Go for the earl grey or the house signature The Wolseley.

crO-NRMducegjx7XaPWrkg.text: I absolutely love this place. The prices for the location and quality of service are amazing. The interior is beautiful and the food charming. I'd suggest going before 9 on a week day if you can. It's much easier to get a table and you can eavesdrop on rich people having business breakfasts.

B21RJKr1Gz4oWv4LgL9TnA.text: First, it was a car showroom, then a bank, now the Wolseley.  What a treat.  The interior is that of a grand cafe of Paris.  The staff was really nice, the food was over the top great.  It was afternoon tea time when we were there having lunch and the tiered goodies looked divine. I can't wait to go back the next time I'm in London.

G5BWSozmSKNeJen2TQ6wpg.text: i've seen the mixed reviews but i have to say this was the best breakfast ever. i had the traditional english breakfast, but i loved it. and i loved the ambiance. this would be first on my list for my next visit.

tXY_Bap3bLzWzxgx5mtsEg.text: I love this place-I've been here several times over the last couple of years, and it's solid goodness. It has a very nice, refined atmosphere, without any snobbiness. The cream tea is the best, and not too expensive compared to other fancy tea places in London (the Ritz is across the street). I've also had the Buck's rarebit-welsh rarebit with an egg on top. yum. I would highly recommend the Wolseley-it's a great place for a relaxing afternoon tea with a friend, or with out of town guests.

V5vIoBJchMNJt_UOoKUMXw.text: I went to the Wolseley with two friends for brunch on a weekday morning. (One of my friends was from out of town so we ditched work for a day. . .) While the food was good the service was horrible. It took forever to be served and then once we were served our crumpets they were cold by the time they brought out the jam. My friend did complain to the manager and we were given free drinks and new crumpets, but from a place as expensive as the Wolseley I expect better service.

Eo56FYJuSBZLvC07H1dACw.text: Great Breakfast in a proper British setting.I try to visit the The Wolseley whenever I visit London.  Yes, it's definitely a people watching spot, but I go for the coffee and the food.  This is London after all.  You can see famous people everywhere.  So don't bother them if you happen to see them at breakfast.   They like to eat too. On my last trip, I flew in from the east and so was up early after my first night in town.  I arrived just as they were opening at 8:00, so I had the place mostly to myself and service wasn't an issue as it sometimes is.  There's a wide range of choices for breakfast.  Start with the pastry.  The Croissant aux Amandes is my favorite.  The Pain au Chocolat is good too.  If you have been getting your exercise in regularly and your cholesterol is under control, try the Baked Italian Egg Florentine.  Yum!   The coffee is expertly prepared in the Continental way.  I guess they have just been practicing longer than us.  There are plenty of healthy choices on the menu too, if you are trying to be good.  I know they serve lunch and dinner later in the day, but I can't comment on those menus, everyone I know goes there for breakfast.  As I said the service can be a little off at times.  Some members of the staff, especially the non-English staff I might add, are a little haughty.  Don't let them get to you.  They are the ones working in the coffee shop serving you after all.Note to Americans:  You might think The Wolseley is a little imposing when you first visit with its proper British decor, the posh menu choices and the controlled chaos that goes on here at busy times, but give it a shot.  Most of the people are very nice and you just can't find a place like this anywhere in the states.

9jpgPpB58n5kWDmGMsi06A.text: The Wolseley is an enjoyable pastiche of the 1920s: ideal for lunch with a gamine flapper, bleary eyed from dancing all night at the Ritz and longing for a cigarette and a glass of champagne.  However, beyond the theatrics and electro-plated coffee pots the food provides a weak chorus line to overall occasion.

4EBjs2xQyRY1Cl37J5_bDw.text: As a self-proclaimed foodie, if a restaurant feeds me even one bad meal, there is little to no chance I will voluntarily return.  Such restaurant would have to make up for it with countless other excellent meals and dishes that are unfailingly consistent (such as a solid Eggs Benedict or Steak Tartare), an enchanting and buzzing grand atmosphere where you could just as easily run into a celebrity as a friend, a bar that serves powerful martinis to whet your waiting appetite and friendly waiters that come to your table bearing breadsticks - oh and it would need to open early for breakfast, serve a great brunch, lunch and tea and seat you at midnight (for those evenings you thought bar snacks would do the trick).    This is why I forgive the Wolseley that unfortunate plate of overcooked calf's liver.  I really do love the Wolseley.

wfdY9TjDcSDRTk3BiQKELw.text: I've only ever been to the Wolseley for breakfast, but oh my what a breakfast it is. The kedgeree is a particular favourite of mine. This is a nice place to take your mum and dad or any visiting out-of-towners as it really is a rather lovely building and pretty impressive meal. Of course, it really should be considering the cost. Still, I've only ever had good service and the countless friends that have gone report the same. Word of advice: don't bother making reservations, especially for breakfast. Usually if you just show up they have a set number of tables aside for walk-ins.

6Q4EtcPMEHSu8dfuAJ0uvA.text: I was somewhat excited to come to London and try all the different Afternoon tea locations that were recommend but this one was absolutely the worse.  First they couldn't find my reservation.  Than after being seating in the rear by the restrooms door, we were totally forgotten.  After being served the waiter kind of turned his nose up at us and offered sandwiches when i came for the afternoon tea.  He was very uninterested in serving us, didn't explain the menu, when we asked for a recommendation for a tea he was like well tea is tea.  After taking our order we never saw him again.  Another waiter saw how bad our service was and took over.  Honestly i usually don't recommend other locations on a restaurants review but  one is better off going to the afternoon tea at the Langham (Palm Court)  Much better.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Tea time

dXzZTSAxiRd8bwyFPsHJxg.text: A very nice and classic cafe in London, pricey but the decoration and the food worth it!I came here for Breakfast with my mum on a weekend morning. We loved the art deco and oriental atmosphere. The breakfast menu is big, classic with some original meals.We ordered cappuccino with grapefruit juice for the drinks then, a pastry basket and a caramelized grapefruit to share. My mum had the crispy bacon roll with fried egg and I had the french toasts with blueberries. It was really good and well displayed. We had a lovely time there. The pastries were delicious and my french toasts were perfect !My advise is to book a table for breakfast because the place is really trendy and you may have to wait if you're walking in without reservation.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

qJgUSWYgOUUTvJ10rgG3Xg.text: High tea at the wolseley is exactly what you'd expect. It's posh and walking into the building with sharp dressed staff surely gives that sense of "class". The building and interior are beautiful, no doubt. The entire experience overall, however, doesn't quite live up to the hype. Some of the staff have a sense of entitlement and I got the "oh you're American" vibe. Some of the staff were amazing. The tea was neither amazing nor horrible. It was pleasant to drink. The food as well was pretty good overall. Would have liked to get a macaron on our tray but what can you do. We wanted to do an all out tea while in London and this was what it was. Great venue and decent fare but I'm sure there are just as good high tea options for a fraction of the cost.

zW1blGD8XLt0Ecfn4QbPYQ.text: The pastries at the Wolseley are absolutely delicious - i had the battenburg cake, the chocolate cake and tea and i was extremely proud of both my choices!I was there during the Holiday season so it was rather busy!

UUw42RrtmZmhuYaRa6qqlw.text: I had a bittersweet experience here. I came around 2pm one afternoon and was served by a lady who was rather rude. She was very uncommunicative and gave very condescending and snappy responses. She kept informing me I could not order the high tea before 3pm. I said I needed some time to decide what I was going to order. I then waited around 10 minutes for her to come back and take my order and she never did, so I ended up leaving because I got so fed up of waiting. However I went there for high tea later on that day and everything was fine, so I guess the quality of the service really depends upon whom you get as a waiter.

fr7G4WAmGwa3dB4wmX12uw.text: We booked a reservation for afternoon tea here several months in advance.  Unlike the Ritz, here you can order afternoon tea or something else from the menu.  This works well if some in your party want the afternoon tea while others don't.  The tea set is served in a traditional 3 tiered plate setting.  It comes with several finger sandwiches, scones, mini pastries and a pot of tea. The tea was very good and was served in a large pot.  I ordered the earl grey tea and wow, they used so many tea leaves!  The flavor really comes through.  They also give you a small strainer so that when you pour out the tea, it strains the leaves.  Our server refilled our pot with hot water (complimentary) and the flavor was still strong. The scones were to die for!  It was so buttery, flakey and soft all at the same time.  They were not dry like the scones I've had in the US.  The pastries were good too.  Our server didn't mind bringing me more after others in my party "stole" my pastries!  I also enjoyed the sandwiches though they were very small.  We also ordered chicken and dumplings soup.  Don't get this.  It was a bowl of broth with some dough.  There was no chicken or anything else in it.  The flavor was really weird too.The burger was cooked very rare even though we ordered it medium.  We sent it back but it still came back soaking red.Overall, I really enjoyed the afternoon tea here.  The earl grey tea here was the best I've ever had.

iyHJCAWzVW3vW5WPgNneFg.text: Beautiful, iconic place graciously hosted a networking breakfast. Were very accommodating, took orders promptly and even permitted each of us to settle our individual bills separately - this should not be taken lightly - there were 15 of us! Had the Mashed Avocado on Toasted Foccacia which was generously sized and well priced. Loved all the pure silver on the table from the tea pot, utensils, and more. Felt like a royal spread and enjoyed the people watching - the regulars here are true characters. Class act all the way and will return for future events.

w3ohsJKyoMBKUCTvdAeeSQ.text: Subtle differences arise between the Traditional English and Irish breakfasts, and from locale to locale. Some add the mushroom, some forego the tomato (I always skip the beans). In addition, when you leave Ireland for England, you'll leave the razzers (Irish bacon - it's like ham and a really thin pork chop had a kid) behind, and find something much more like American bacon, also known as "bacon." Over our ten days in Dublin and London, we saw a full gambit of interpretations of what is sold as "traditional." The biggest range was in the black pudding dept., and The Wolsley wins that battle. Absolutely best blood sausage in the Isles! (Well, of the half a dozen that I tried).The Wolsley is also the only place I've ever seen watermelon juice offered, so of course, I had to order it. Yep. Watermelon juice. Tastes like watermelon.This place is fantastic, and absolutely the first place I'd recommend for breakfast in Piccadilly. It's like eating in the foyer of the Chicago Field Museum or some city hall or courthouse or something, with all the marble surfaces and the cold and austere but elegant design motif. Very formal service, five star presentation, and of course, great company made for an awesome dining experience.

l78SZQo6nvGNqOl7j-Uhnw.text: I don't do many five-star reviews, but this place hits on all cylinders, and then some. Food, atmosphere, location, value and maybe most of all, servicethere was a situation (not important) that happened in the restaurant the night we were there, and the management personally took care that every single patron was satisfied and taken care of. all the waitstaff were amazing. the food was amazing. I highly recommend the pork chop, three of us got it and we all loved it. perfectly cooked, thick and perfectly cookedwine list is very good, and reasonably priced compared to a typical restaurant markupit's beautiful inside. I will be spending a lot of time in London this summer and plan to come back here every visit!

RXW47LNYvosyseyvZKBTvA.text: Excellent high end breakfast. Food was delicious. I had the Kedgeree (curried rice with smoked fish and a poached egg), which I had never had before. Very good. Also, the egg white frittata was very good. My kids really enjoyed the pancakes. Excellent service.

ykS1g8Tjij2CYeWJqobDVQ.text: Beautiful dining room. Came early and luckily seated quickly.  Avocado toast, eggs Benedict and black pudding were lovely. Breakfast tea put some pep in our step. Would return.

6JeVsHLHXyzgyir5q5SHyw.text: My family and I had a wonderful afternoon tea experience at The Wolseley! We split 2 full Afternoon Teas between 3 people, which was more than enough, given that the servers generously refilled our scones and sandwiches at no extra cost. When I asked if our leftover sandwiches could be packed for takeaway, the waiter gave us a new set of sandwiches. The food itself was tasty, especially the scones and the sandwich with tomato bread. The ambience was classy yet relaxed, so even as tourists in relatively casual clothing, we felt very comfortable. Overall, I would definitely recommend The Wolseley for afternoon tea despite the higher price point, as you will get your money's worth!

ZsBipM9M5qMvn-Yd6xyLaw.text: Great afternoon tea spot with spotty, slow service and reused placemats. The sandwiches and biscuits we're delicious but the service left much to be desired.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Used placemats given to us, go green I guess

BNLLlUsYIs56DXZRnD8XfA.text: Loved this venue! Elegantly casual, if that's a thing in this posh neighborhood....food was delicious and service was top-notch...

e32HgdPUe9itrXA7lB8rEg.text: Breakfast in London was A-OKMr chose the cheese omelette & it was delish.  Very fluffy & a ton of cheese ( in a good way! )I chose the French Toast.  It was crispy on the outside, soft on the inside - almost like it had been deep-fried......and saturated in a sugar syrupCoffee was god awfulService was incredible - very friendly & joking, even with the posers who were sitting beside us & putting on makeup at the table, ignoring the waiter while he tried to speak with them, demanding dessert when it was not on the breakfast menu.....he handled it like a pro!Overall?  Did not hate breakfast & would come back...... but would probably try somewhere else first.  And skip the coffee!!

PbSNZsSt67Az3VYhN5GL7Q.text: My absolute favorite place for breakfast in London, hands down. Eff your diet and get the pancakes! You won't regret it.

mAT3rcJAItphEbPgkEmRkQ.text: Went to the Wolseley for breakfast and tea on my first day in London. It definitely set the standards high for everywhere else I went. I would come here for breakfast, lunch and dinner if I could. Recommend ordering the Eggs Benedict with Salmon.

rDHR9wafV22Gnmyd49-r3g.text: Nice room, decent bistro-style food, but the service was aggressively rude. We were mostly ignored by our waitress, but when she did show up, all of our (very ordinary) requests were treated with the utmost disdain. On more than one occasion, she walked away from our table and immediately began gossiping with the other waitstaff, laughing and looking in our direction. This type of bullying behaviour made for a totally unnerving and humiliating experience. When we finally expressed our displeasure, the manager was quite apologetic and had someone else take over. However, we then had to deal with the waitress continually walking past our table, muttering under her breath and glaring at us. Deplorable. It was a miserable meal.

tItHCNkNMnu6SUz-xJpddg.text: We had high tea here when we were visiting from the states and it was a ton of fun. It's definitely a traditional style high tea with cute pastries and sandwiches. They were able to seat our large party all together which was also really great!

NjTuMq4PpL8rEFwLUG8ndw.text: Great atmosphere and charm. Pancakes were dense.. but that seems to be a London commonality. Coffee was perfect, my avocado toast was amazing.

iTHqSmoAxSPbGNOUcAR4FA.text: Best breakfast in London. Buzzy.. Classic.. Fantastic food. Too service. Worth every penny.

NnOKyyMiKmmA5ZnxkbyExg.text: I have always enjoyed the Wolseley. It most certainly is the crown in the Corbyn and King empire.

a3ypSwgMHsnxyZNx1Waw7g.text: I booked the restaurant a few months ahead of time trying to make a special family night, as this would be a first London trip for my kids. Whist the food is good, not exceptional, the service is a big disappointment. Service is sloppy, un-attentive, borderline rude. Not likely to return.

OmGSIQYnfmJqh-Uf9EQYXA.text: Went here for a weekday early lunch.  Service was very attentive and the food was fine.  Nothing special really.  The bloody mary could have been better. Potato Rösti with Avocado, Tomato and a Poached Egg - this was the best thing we ordered.  Perfectly seasoned.Eggs benedict - meh. Not worth the price.

GYIKf4oMOa9WHCD4IHPNKg.text: Top class service...amazing breakfast and afternoon tea! Especially the omelette and croissant! The place is very high-end and it is right besides The Ritz. Very delicate European style decoration!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. LOVE the afternoon tea set!
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Special omelette with double onion and cheddar cheese!

OFzlJIo6GbnpPhHtB25lFQ.text: Nice breakfast and beautiful building.  Great for a business meeting or business brunch. Service was impeccable. The space is beautiful.

DgYfGr0mpmG_vSm5WzWR-w.text: Felt a bit disappointed with this place because the food and the afternoon tea felt a bit pretentious. I think Harrods afternoon tea at the bottom floor is better and more relaxed. This felt very classy and a bit pricy. Glad i tried it but not my cup of tea

tKGuOLUDyh-wF0uArU6bVA.text: This is hands down my favorite restaurant in London. The cocktails and the food and ambience are brilliant. Don't forget to look at the beautiful floors in the bar area. Absolutely gorgeous!!!!

uctQxUiqY64cq5ut9p8tWw.text: This review is for breakfast/brunch only.  As a SF Bay Area resident visiting London, the Wolseley brunch was nothing to write home about. No one does brunch like California (except maybe NYC), though the Wolseley made an effort. The lavish, beautifully appointed dining room is a lovely experience, and the service is top notch.The food however, is quite underwhelming. We ordered the benedict (which several people on Yelp claim is the "best benedict they've ever had") - tasty, but really nothing special, with slightly chunky hollandaise sauce (and hollandaise sauce really ought to be perfectly velvety and creamy), the fish cake plate, which was more like a seafood cake with bits of shrimp and other unidentifiable mashed up sea creatures and smelled VERY fishy, and the 'crispy bacon roll,' which we imagined to be something like a flaky, dreamy pastry with bits of bacon in it, but turned out to be just a pile of American-style bacon and egg on a hamburger bun.Honestly, I had rather elevated expectations of this place since it's such a traditional London institution, and all the other reviews are so positive. However, once you get past the beautiful atmosphere, and compared to some of the more amazing brunch experiences available in other big cities, the Wolseley is really average at best.

t1-2TVXRNw5Ox1RdKkrKIA.text: I've eaten here on many occasions for breakfast, lunch and dinner. We've even enjoyed afternoon tea here. The food is consistently delicious and the pastries for breakfast and tea are delectable. We have spotted celebrities on numerous occasions and were treated just as well.  Delicious coffee and teas served as well.

oMewq-X4E8vn3YtcToKPqg.text: I love the Wolsoley and its sister restaurants (bar Zedel) for all meals, but it really shines at breakfast.My lox and bagel was the best I've had in London, partially due to the taste, but moreso because of the finishing touches; the lox was served as a beautiful roll, the lemon was wrapped in muslin, and the perfect dollop of cream cheese was draped in a few thinly sliced pieces of chive.  I mean, a good bagel, cream cheese, and smoked salmon is a hard thing to ruin (though the bagel factory has had some success), but elevating it to a gastronomic ceremony is quite impressive.My wifes bowl of hot chocolate served with a toasted baguette is a truly luxurious indulgence, as was the beautifully sectioned grapefruit served chilled in a sterling bowl.  I understand why people have standing breakfast and lunch reservations here.  There are few places I'd rather spend the morning reading the paper and taking early meetings than a private stall in the front room of the Wolsoley.

U-mXUQQ-JlwnfgOV8LyPxw.text: One of the highest establishments in London. I go regularly for dinner with friends, but it is famous for its high tea, which comes with their own blend of tea, sandwiches, scones (jam and cream) and pastries. If you're visiting London, and want to experience what British culture is really about, head over to the Wolseley for high tea and sit back, relax and absorb the atmosphere of this wonderful place.Dinner is also a great place. Reservations are recommended, but if you don't have one, they reserve the Salon for non-reserved diners who can arrive and wait to be seated. While doing so you can get a superb drink from their exhaustive bar. I usually get a Vesper, one of my favourites. They make them perfectly, great balance of sprits and vermouth.I usually get the quail eggs and hollandaise followed by their signature Ribeye, which is to die for. I usually end up comatose afterwards. Try the treacle tart or apple strudel for dessert, served to perfection with abundance of flavour.N.B.: For anyone who doesn't eat unpasteurised dairy products, their cheeses are made from unpasteurised milk. But they do taste amazing!!

jcjuih4TUaIBdTQEredi0g.text: Bad and superbly slow service. Our waiter's English left much to be desired, he barely spoke any! I ordered the smoked salmon and scrambled eggs and 'twas the saltiest dish ever made to be eaten by a human being. Ordered the mixed pastries too, some were hard some were edible, none were great. I'll never recommend this place to anyone, especially to the tourists as your time is far too valuable to be spent waiting and waiting for such undesirable and way too expensive food. What a massive waste of my sunny Monday morning!

vLwPkrc9pLN4yRIzEYB_Yg.text: Went for late brunch. The service is great, very attentive, and the fix is good, except I would skip the tartar, far from great. The tartar brings it siren from five to four stars for me.The salmon with eggs was awesome and also loved the side of mushrooms, in butter.Best belini I have ever had, so soft and not too sweet, perfect!

BrnzZfblTKp9_SKQnp8FhQ.text: The Wolseley is one of those restaurants in London that everyone knows about. It has timeless decor inside where you are transported back in time. Originally a prestigious car showroom commissioned by architect William Curtis Green turned now restaurant. They have breakfast, afternoon tea, lunch, and dinner. I've been here for dinner now a few times. Everyone in my party seems to order oysters and steak tartar and love it. I'm vegetarian and they have a special vegetarian menu that you can request with additional veggie options on it. If you want to find out your options in advance just e-mail the reservations department like I did as it changes. The bill here can add up but if you are coming here for dinner it's probably going to be a night out you don't do too often. The service is always excellent. Only con is that the seating downstairs can get quite loud and you feel too close to the next table sometimes. Tip: They have a few tables upstairs that are more private and uncrowded. They even come with a little button to call your waiter/waitress easily as you are sitting upstairs to make sure you have good service. They may not always be available but if you are offered one definitely sit upstairs!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Tables upstairs are equipped with service button so you can receive quick service as you are sitting upstairs.

-az4lYDwGmqPTaUBu1hXgw.text: Really great place to enjoy brunch but more preferably the evening dinner.  I was taken here for my birthday and had an amazing time.I had the caviar and rib eye steak with frites, (not at the same time) which was amazing.The building used to be an old car dealership, which has now been turned into this gem.  It's pretty huge inside and reminiscent of an old bank.  Huge high ceilings and decadent black and white decor.The desserts are also super.  I've been back a few times and seen the odd celebrity too!

DwtZXlDRVrf2Sx_nVGrd3w.text: This is one of the best places for brunch in london, it's effortlessly classic, without being overdone. I't relaxing and delicious. It embodies everything you want in a brunch. THe restrooms are a little hard to get to, down a spiral staircase.

prFDmTIxCxmP0lcu7hXWSA.text: I guess the Wolseley is one of the places in London you cannot ignore. After a spontaneous little shopping spree around Piccadilly I decided to make the best of the early evening and treat myself to a dinner at The Wolseley. I was given a place immediately and got a table in the salon. A nice little room that is separated from the bigger dining room.I decided to order duck à l'orange, the main of the day. I started my dinner with some nice bread and tasty butter. For drinks I got a glass of Grüner Veltliner, an excellent Austrian white wine.My main was very good, a delicious succulent duck in a great orange sauce. Definitely a dish I would order again. After I had finished my duck, it was time for dessert, so I briefly looked at the menu and ordered the petit chocolate pot. And yes, it was kind of small, but it was very good with a strong chocolatey flavour.Throughout my entire stay, the waiters always topped up my water before I could even think about asking for more. I call this brilliant and attentive service. For me, The Wolseley lived up to its reputation, I had a very enjoyable dinner and there is no question that I will visit this place again.

XidanLA45f8EqieAWbU-Mg.text: Came here for lunch to celebrate 2 of my friends' birthday. It was probably cos I had too high expectations for the decor that I was less than impressed with the interior. Also, even though it's supposed to be a classy kind of restaurant there were people from all walks of life and it didn't feel too intimidating like The Delaunay. Brought a birthday cake to celebrate but the restaurant host told us that they only serve their own food. That was fine, so we requested for them to keep it. Somehow or another, one of the waitress brought it to the table where the birthday girl and boy were sat to confirm that the cake belonged to us. Well, that ruined the surprise we had kept for our friends and we were utterly annoyed with her lack of decency to keep things discreet. I ordered the soupe de poisson and salad nicoise - both were fish-based dishes. The soupe de poisson was exceptionally "fishy" and the salad nicoise had slightly too much tuna. Confit of Duck was good, but my friend didn't like the lentils (personal choice). Another friend loved her Loch Duart Salmon where she took a particular liking to the lobster cream sauce. Besides this, the Pot-Roasted Welsh Lamb and Grilled Rib Eye received no complaints. A slight annoyance was the missing steak knife when the steak was delivered. But the waiter delivered it promptly when asked. After that we ordered dessert where the vanilla millecrepe & banana split were satisfactory. We liked that our server was pleasant enough to interact and crack jokes with us. The highlight of the lunch was Wolseley's complimentary macaron/strawberry tart dessert to celebrate our friends' birthday. That took our friends by surprise because they did not expect anything after the blunder made earlier by the waitress. So even if we could not have our own cake, we managed to make the lunch special and memorable.tl;dr: we loved the food, ambience and our pleasant server but the ditzy waitress with the cake was the blip to an otherwise memorable birthday lunch.

H9nkA0hJdNQK1JOsfARfXg.text: We went for high tea and had the best time. It was fun and exactly what you want for tea in London. The best scones with jam and clotted cream and a really great atmosphere. You really must go if you are visiting London and want the real tea experience. We loved it! We got the full tea for two with the finger sandwiches and scones with desserts, it looked like not a lot of food but was very filling and delicious.

9deCFW4bCHCCmBhaYekxSA.text: I went to the Wolseley on Sunday for lunch with my fiance, another couple and their 1 year old baby. I had heard wonderful things and I must say that I was a little disappointed with the experience. The service was fabulous and the ambiance was really lovely although not as cosy as I had expected - a little cold and hectic. My main issue was with the food which was not up to par in my opinion.
