Way too basic for what you are paying for it. My friend ordered an omelette and she literally got just an omelette on her plate not even with a garnish of any sort. I ordered the tuna nicoise salad because I figured in a place like this they would serve a tuna steak with the salad, not canned tuna. But, they served it with canned tuna. I really wanted to love this place, but I'm not sure I would go back. I would rather spend my money on lunch or afternoon tea at Claridges or the Dorchester, if I'm looking for a special luxurious 'British' experience.

ixsoyEZCiOZH6Ykc8J05EA.text: Ok food (but excellent breakfast and afternoon tea), ghastly premises and staff attitude. Not a patch on the (very) nearby Le Caprice. Disappointing, considering the expertise of the people behind it.

A2JwvWTnO8Ia3v7hDpZRaA.text: We spotted David Walliams as soon as we got in, which was nice. Deliberated over the menu quite a bit and asked lots of questions, our waiter seemed to be new because he wasn't very knowledgeable about the food, although did say the lemon meringue was very good. We both settled for the burger and fries, which were very good. I went to the toilet and my friend was asked if she had decided on her pudding. We didnl;t think this was right, and from pudding onwards felt quite rushed, puddings were very quick, felt like they had come out of a microwave because of the speed but were very delicious, our coffee arrived and then we were told at 8.10 that our table was booked from 8.30 and we could finish drinks in the bar, we said ok, and our bill arrived less than a minute later. We felt that we were being watched and rushed, we eventually left at 8.25 leaving half a bottle of wine behind and half drunken coffees. Overall the food and atmosphere were good, and the staff polite - but we felt very undervalued - we had two courses, wine and coffee each so they made £85 from us - we deserved a little better treatment, wouldn't rush back...5/10 or 2.5 stars out of 5

jIRgquKsV1stULz00Ucqlg.text: I genuinely can't say enough about this place. From the food, to the service, to the atmosphere... I still crave the steak and chips with hollandaise sauce. The drinks were perfection and the wine list vast. Definitely make a reservation and be ready for a wait- but I promise it's worth it!

NpogeNxz6y90V65d8dBRyg.text: Only managed to have high tea here last week. Place was stunning and the service on point! it's a 5 star tea and service review. Looking forward to updating this before years end.I will be back

S3Fr-uf0V_uGJmxKFIrzeg.text: #537 To truly experience any country, you should avoid simply glancing over its sights and settling into a nice McDonald's restaurant for your meals. Instead, it takes focused and deliberate attempts to steer clear of the typical offerings a tourist would partake in to appreciate a country for its authentic character. So, for a guaranteed excellent experience with afternoon tea in London, the boyfriend and I decided to forgo the typical option of patronizing The Ritz and, instead, booked a 5:45PM reservation for 2 at The Wolseley. Reviews on Yelp assured us that we would not have to deal with unnecessary snootiness and their menu seemed just as (if not more) quality-controlled as The Ritz's. The establishment is not difficult to find and it's located on a high-profile street (Piccadilly) in the city. We were approximately 10 minutes early for our reservation, but the host so graciously welcomed us with a bright smile that we knew it didn't matter. He offered to coat check our belongings, but seeing our hesitation, he quickly suggested the coat rack several steps away from our table instead. What a gentleman. Our table was already ready for us and the host delicately adjusted the table so I could slide into my seat without any problems. He then pulled the chair out for my boyfriend. Seriously, the service was impressive. Our server gave us several minutes with the menu before popping over, but because we weren't ready, he quietly slipped away. I assumed I was simply going to go with their Afternoon Tea, however, their menu proved more extensive than the sample available online. In the end, I decided to go with the Champagne Tea instead, while the significant other went with the Wolseley Imperial. Once our orders were in, we were treated to a ringside view of an argument between the couple sitting to our left. We were perplexed as the woman angrily (and shrilly) berated her boyfriend, yet apologized profusely, at the same time. Her counterpart, however, sat there sipping on his tea and looking at the table. Suffice it to say, we breathed a breath of fresh air when they left. Our drinks arrived rather quickly and I was impressed with their silverware and teapot. The Wolseley Imperial literally came out on a silver platter with a piece of chocolate and miniature glass of water. I commend the bar staff's attention to detail! My green tea was perfect, with a crisp air to it and heavy caffeinated finish. Unfortunately, they brought it out boiling hot, which burned my subsequent cups. But, I found that the strong flavor contrasted the sweetness of my cakes well. Speaking of which, all of their food offerings were delicious. My order came out with five different servings of finger sandwiches (egg, chicken, celery, cucumber, and smoked salmon), but my favorites were undoubtedly the egg salad and the smoked salmon. If only we were allowed to put in requests! As for the cakes, I was satisfied. The boyfriend, however, enjoyed them much more than I did. The marzipan-coated multicolored slice of cake was a treat, while the macaron was a chewy, almond delight. Unfortunately, I found the rhubarb tart to be sickly sweet, so I pawned it off to Adam B. to devour within seconds. The real winners of my afternoon tea, however, were the two delicate and chewy scones that topped my tower. They came with thick clotted cream and strawberry jam, but I could easily have done without just to enjoy the full flavor of my fluffy scones. Once I finished off the food, I was stuffed. I had already sipped my way through 4 cups of tea and a food coma washed over me quickly. But, the saving grace was the champagne that our server promptly brought over once he realized we were done. The champagne woke me right up and we were off to dinner. Of course, we were happy to tip the compulsory 12.5%, but we would have tipped more if it weren't already added to the bill for us. I definitely recommend The Wolseley above all other places as I'm sure you won't receive any haughty behavior here. Wolseley, you'll always be my first!

Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Champagne Tea (5 finger sandwiches, sweets, and scones)
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. The Wolseley Imperial

3QoSy5ZetBrnTiEY6Au-4g.text: Beautiful "old European" style restaurant that's a bit expensive and maybe a tad touristy (it is in Picadilly Circus, after all). The food was good but not extremely memorable. Great looking place with a romantic atmosphere though.

c0LlClom1qONqByoagqPGw.text: Looking for a place for a great afternoon tea for a friend who was visiting London for the first time, I remembered hearing about The Wolseley a while ago. The restaurant looks fabulous, quite impressive the first time you get there.The place was surprisingly busy (I'm not sure what I was expecting...maybe something quieter?) but our table was ready on time (had booked online couple of weeks before). The service was great and all the staff were lovely. When we ordered the Afternoon Tea for two, they explained us right away the food in more details and what was available for refills.The finger sandwiches were nice ( salmon + cream cheese, chicken tarragon, cucumber, and I can't remember the two others, sorry!), and once we were finished the waiter asked us if we wanted refills (of course we did). We didn't have to wait too long before the second round arrived =).The scones were delicious, not too big, not too small and not too dense either. The jam and the cream were very good too.As for the mini cakes, my only disappointment was to not get 2 of each to share with my friend. We ended up cutting them in half so we could both try them all.Needless to say, we were (very) full after munching of all of it.

6EU9RuJHSTW4lY6u7sw68g.text: A good friend of mine who is a friend of the owner was able to book a table for me on my birthday, lucky me! So fancy and over the top, but it was a gorgeous dining experience. I took one of my best friends with me and we dined like queens. Food was glorious and I felt so spoiled getting a banana split after two courses, but it was my birthday. I don't usually frequent posh places like this, so I tend to feel a bit out of place, but the service was excellent and they treated us like we belonged there.As we were leaving, the manager gave us macaroons to go as our drinks were supposed to be covered by my friend who booked the table for us(she didn't know that we don't drink), so they sent us home with goodies instead. We also walked out the door at the same time Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Burton did. So, it was a pretty cool experience over all. Brilliant service and delicious food. Definitely recommend for tourists and locals alike.

cjW0jVy6rzzOML2eFdgHDQ.text: Every time I visit my experience exceeds my expectations. The place, the atmosphere, the service is top notch. The food is perfect, every time. The Eggs Arlington is superb, the pancakes are thick, and the latte is made to perfection. Can't leave the place without having the pink Caramelized grapefruit, it's a must.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Caramelized pink grapefruit

Ndh1UGL8ykCp_m0CJaFXvQ.text: I am mixed on this place...We had an excellent tea experience on July 4. Randomly ran in and had fabulous scones, great tea, and excellent service. It was so good that we went back for dinner tonight.The food was okay, expensive but tasty enough that it was almost worth the $$$. What really did bother me was the very poor service - not enough waiters to go around - and more importantly, the very strange 4 pound cover charge that appeared on our bill out of nowhere. "It is for 2 people to be able to make a reservation so they could sit in the main dining room" was the explanation. So I pay to eat food but I also pay to sit in the restaurant? Very strange. The waiter took it off, which was nice, but I doubt I'll be back when there are SO many better places to eat in London.Bottom Line: Go for tea and sit in the bar area, otherwise you'll be assessed a dining  room fee!

1wiIJbcDfUJW1OKvWk6pUQ.text: Lovely building inside and out, right near the Ritz London and not far from Buckingham Palace.  Nice 'smart' casual brasserie... Came here for dinner and service was friendly and a bit formal, as seems to be norm for London compared to SF or NY.  Had the ribeye steak and pomme frites which was normal sized (vs crazy huge American sized) but still more than I could eat along with wine.  I would come here again.  If they try to put you in the little corner room to the left of the entrance, definitely insist on a table in the main dining area so you can take in all the pretty architectural details/decor.  That's what we did and we had a drink at the bar while we waited.

4MRrQDFsKtTqeIvKriEvcg.text: Always a pleasure to go to The Wolseley.  Ambience is best ever the layout is great staff are wonderful and the food is good too!

hi-b38C-NcMcchb1THmbUA.text: I came here on a beautiful summer weekend after a walk through the Kensington Gardens and Hyde Park. Conveniently located near the heart of London's main attractions, it's a great place to go for afternoon tea!The atmosphere inside the venue is incredibly elegant -- I sort of felt as if I'd been transported back into history! Certainly make a reservation, though. It's quite busy otherwise. The afternoon tea selection was brilliant (their finger sandwiches were amazing -- an interesting arrangement of flavours on good-quality bread) and I especially liked the scones and strawberry jam! The assorted pastries are also quite nice -- while they're small and may seem insignificant, each bite still has an intricacy to its flavour. I do hope to someday return either for a cocktail or for their normal dinner menu. (They have all the classics and their extended menu is rather impressive.

6jVNjzV5Vcl1eGiuNu2A_Q.text: Probably one of the top 3 places for English Afternoon Tea. Very quaint and old world. When we went the service was exceptional. Recommend booking in advance.

03YCTf0LeFKawj8Wfgg_ug.text: Dude. One of my favorite experiences in London. Being a London noob, I was told that afternoon tea is a must! Not wanting to shell out 70 pounds pp, I decided to book a table through opentable for me, my brother and my dad at 4pm. A little bit on the later side of afternoon tea, but boy am I glad I picked that time.After a semi-stressful Barclays bike ride around Hyde park (stressful because finding a place to return your bike almost deters me from the experience entirely) we walked over to the Wolseley. The doorman in a top hat graciously opens the door for you and your eyes set on a charming black and white interior filled with servers bustling around with tiers of scones and tea sandwiches in their hands.We were seated immediately and selected our tea options and desserts. The service was attentive and prompt, and the food delicious! We loved each sandwich, scone, pastry, jam, cream they had to offer - and the portion size was very generous!! This was meant to be an afternoon snack, but we left feeling very full.I hope you caught up on my foreshadowing earlier...but because we came relatively later, the dinner crowd was coming in while we were finishing up our tea and GUESS WHO pops in with his two daughters? Clive freakin' Owen. I'm pretty sure he is as close to British (movie) royalty I'll ever be seated 5 feet away from. Our humble family of 3 did not want to disturb him during his dinner so we inconspicuously pretended to take photos of each other only to focus on him in the background. Unfortunately, one of his daughters caught us in the act but Clive just turned around and flashed us a smile!Honestly, I would have given afternoon tea at the Wolseley 5 stars anyways but the fact it was teeechhhnically afternoon tea with Clive Owen...I would have given 10 stars if I could!

xIYqgW0jRVNlunpd-WMzig.text: I have been here a few times, and all times have been brilliant!The food is absolutely amazing, especially the steak. Great selection of wines and champagne.The ambience is brilliant and the location perfect!

tsAG5Its-inCRUwv7Wbp6Q.text: Had such an incredible breakfast experience here when I was down in London last month. Probably the best eggs Benedict I've ever had - and I've had a lot! But at £14 I'd expect a certain quality. Luckily they followed through. I had just arrived in London after an 8 hour bus journey where I slept for half an hour, and as soon as I stepped off the bus at Victoria (well, as soon as I picked up a triple shot drink from Starbucks to wake me up), I checked Yelp to get some good suggestions of nearby breakfast. After a one stop tube journey, I walked past The Ritz and into The Wolseley. I did feel slightly underdressed, but the staff in no way made me feel this way. They were incredibly lovely and welcoming, and I was shown to my seat right away. The eggs Benedict came out around 10 minutes after I ordered them, and they were incredible. Definitely the best I've had. The staff were so lovely and kept asking if I was okay, and my entire visit was lovely. I'd definitely return here, maybe not for dinner if breakfast is £14, but definitely for breakfast again. If you're looking for somewhere to go for breakfast/lunch/dinner in London, I'd definitely recommend here. Go!

HwfgJGUIaQICCBENAlfseA.text: Great fun to come here. All fake glamour and history done really well in what used to be a car showroom. Food is fantastic, staff friendly if a little run down by the obnoxious Mayfair clientele. Perfect for a treat.

1G0bUbDkr3arTHhDSAO2IQ.text: Many years back, I read an article in Metro about best restaurant in London. The Wolseley was awarded for Best restaurant for breakfast! This is how I come across knowing this restaurant. It was a last minute plan on a Sunday evening that we decided to go for afternoon tea. I called to reserved a table but it was fully book for the day. The waitress advised me to walk in and wait for table. We went there with my baby and buggy. As soon as we walk in we were impressed by the ambient of the restaurant then follow by the friendly staff welcome. Staffs were very helpful, they were trying their best to seated us with a table that have space for us to park our buggy beside. I was desperate to get a  table, I told them is ok I can leave the buggy and carry my baby or put her in baby chair. Then the waitress check on my baby and said "she is sleeping I do not want to wake her up. Let me try" I was impressed. So we waited for a while and we got a table at the left side corner table of the restaurant. It also less noisy compared to the inside middle part of the restaurant.I ordered a set of afternoon tea with a pot of their house blend tea. My husband not a dessert person so he ordered a rib eye steak from the dinner menu. As usual I started my afternoon tea from the bottom, what I remember there were the usual cucumber sandwich, smoke salmon sandwich, egg sandwich with cress and ...... Then 3 pieces of cakes at second trey and 2 scones at the top trey. Overall I grade their afternoon tea is for sure better than Fortnum and Mason(from the cafe) but below Dorchester and Ritz. Average but very happy! Lovely time there!!The steak was perfectly cook for my husband as he wanted medium well. Juicy and tender. I would recommend this. Overall I rated 5 stars because I was very happy with their service and food. I will for sure come back for their breakfast but I have to remember to make it there before 11:30am!

Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

eRFDNTEpbp0JZ-tZIQVDcQ.text: A lovely lunch. Polite staff and good solid food. My wife loved her lobster cocktail and her bagel with cream cheese and salmon. My burger was good, too.The service is slow, so plan for a leisurely, lovely lunch.Because the atmosphere is so nice, you won't mind the wait.

DG32p4Qmsucwpc4uEiUMFA.text: The Wolseley is a magnificent restaurant, located right on Piccadilly next to The Ritz.  I found the interior to be absolutely stunning, very high class with a modern feel.  The finely dressed waitstaff added to the experience.We arrived around 9AM last Saturday morning and, though it was busy, we were seated immediately in the small cafe-style dining area off to the left.  The first thing we noticed as we walked to our seat was the small table situated in the center boasting delicious pastries and croissants, just asking to be eaten.  We sipped on tea (loose leaf), brewing in a fine silver pot, while we waited for our English breakfast.  The small tables are situated somewhat close to each other, which meant there was a little bumping or brushing from the waitstaff as they served the tables on either side of us.  Service was quite good - we enjoyed the formalness of it all - albeit definitely slower-paced as is typical here.  Breakfast was excellent.  The usual suspects: egg, beans, bacon, sausage, black pudding, tomato, and portobello mushroom.  Well-prepared, high quality and delicious.  The black pudding was very rich, almost decadent (if you can call sausage decadent).  Very filling, too.  We were still full even by the middle of the afternoon.Definitely not to be missed!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. The Wolseley, from across the street

cM_LK1KBjpFnBpVvTAgGkg.text: I designated this place to experience my English afternoon tea. It's located on a busy street and you might miss it if you don't look closely, although they do have a doorman.  Afternoon tea for 2 on a busy Saturday afternoon wait was around 45 min, not a big deal, as this place was super busy and from the Yelp reviews, seemed very good.  Staff was friendly and decor was very classy. however food was not good and very underwhelming.  Their Afternoon tea consisted of two scones, 3 small pastry samplers and 4 finger sandwiches.  The scones were pretty good paired with their jam and amazing cream.  I put that cream on everything, it was so delicious.  Their pastry samplers and finger sandwiches seemed like a filler and weren't that good at all.  It was just so plain and disappointing.  Tea was tea, can't really go wrong with it.  Overpriced for an afternoon tea experience!

GpPDka3xrdhKhAhuhVS6pw.text: Very nice place for Afternoon Tea.The scones were very tasty, great with the creme and jam.As for the sandwiches, they were good too especially the chicken with tarragon. There was an egg sandwich as well as three other flavors.The assorted pastry were good and sinfully rich. The service was absolutely fantastic as the staffs were very helpful and attentive. The cost is about £30 per head plus service charge. We would definitely do it again if we ever in town again.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Top plate - scones with raisins, middle plate - assorted pastry, bottom plate - assorted sandwiches.

kQamSNo9efmogOwhHOQeXw.text: The Wolseley is a wonderful atmosphere for any meal, but an early Sunday morning breakfast here seemed an especially appropriate way to start the day.I started with a flat white coffee, which was exceptional. I ordered another. The French toast, pancakes, eggs and sausage were all good, not exceptional. I had a Bloody Mary as well, which was just okay.Atmosphere: 5 out of 5 -- one of the best settings for an early Sunday morning brunch that we've experienced.Food: 4 out of 5 -- coffee was exceptional. The rest of the food was good, not great.Service: 3 out of 5 -- there was a change in shifts/table assignment during our meal. Our table got lost and we were left unattended for a solid 30 to 40 minutes, until I finally caught the eye of another server.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Delicious flat white

Rauq-1ynwPE3TdwDi8wDWg.text: London sure has their food right and the wolseley is a great place to have breakfast. I did some yelping in the area and found this place, I didn't realize how fancy it was until I arrived there, I knew my meal was going to going to cost me a bit but hey, I was on vacation. When I walked in I was immediately greeted even though they looked busy. I had to wait a few minutes for a table and while I was doing that I was looking around, the environment really makes you feel like you're in a high end fancy restaurant which I'm not really used to. I was started off by a nice waitress but then I had different waiter that was very short and would only say 2 words to me. The food was excellent, I got pancakes with a side of bacon and I gotta say I haven't had great breakfast in a while so this definitely topped it off. Great place to have breakfast if you're in the area or a tourist if you're willing to spend some money! Only small complaint would be that the servers could be more involved with their tables.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

XUWqBZ0DsTJLE_BBY866SQ.text: I came here for breakfast and the restaurant, decor, and service was great. My only complaint was that breakfast was somewhat over priced for what you're getting (I ordered the full English breakfast- didn't come with toast). But other than that I enjoyed my meal there.

ELnsjctKJ5huv77XHscBRw.text: Great place for breakfast!! Went there with my friend and enjoyed eggs Benedict, fishcakes and pan cakes. This place is trendy with the young and affluent people of Mayfair. We'll definitely come back again for more !!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Cafe latte
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Pan cakes
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Eggs Benedict

P3RVuri92Ars4MvccceT6Q.text: This was an example of expectation battling with reality, and coming out mostly to the good.   The expectation of a grand environment was more than met.  However, at the risk of seeming snooty, people were more casually dressed than I would have thought.  There were a lot of t-shirts and jeans, sort of a tourist vibe.  The food was very traditional and well executed, though not perfect.   My eggs Benedict were slightly underdone, despite specifically asking for otherwise.   Overall though, we were both very happy.  The only thing that failed the expectation game was the service.   It ran on the slow and slightly aloof side, owing to the fact that the place was utterly packed and the tables were very close together.   They certainly don't leave any pounds on the floor, so to speak.

mj-rScIP4K7UstknJNUZ0A.text: One of my friends visiting from Los Angeles had heard about "The Wolseley" and suggested we do lunch there during her visit. We did not have a reservation but being a Monday afternoon were quickly seated for Lunch. They said we had an hour and half for lunch before they need the table.  Being vegetarian, I looked at their vegetarian menu- I ordered the chilled heritage tomato soup as a starter and the spiced puy lentil and chickpea cake for the main course. The tomato soup was just about ok but the puy lentil cake was a different story;  wholesome and bursting with flavors with every bite. I thoroughly enjoyed it and if I do get an opportunity may just go to the Wolseley to try their Puy and chickpea lentil cake.My friend ordered a desert - one of their specials-I tried it but the Puy lentil was still my favorite. Overall was well worth the trip especially for my friend who had heard so much about the place.Service : Excellent, warm and helpful staffAmbience: lovely ( very British- old feel), high ceilings, chandeliers, Large room, comfortable dining space Food: above average to very goodMust Try (Vegetarian): Spiced Puy lentil and chickpea cakeRecommendation: Definitely worth trying for the experience

Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Spiced Puy Lentil and Chickpea cake

0pU8zU5LrEUt2Jx3B2AieA.text: Came here twice because once was not enough. The best cappuccino I've ever had.  Seriously best. The food is wonderful and so is the atmosphere alongside decor. Having fresh avocado with salad was great starter to lunch. Schnitzel with extra toppings of anchovies, fried egg and capers was totally worth it if you like egg. The chicken liver reminded me of my moms where had perfect texture and herbs of dill and seasoned perfect with salt and pepper. Egg Benedict was perfectly cooked and nicely rich hollandaise sauce. All was good and I hope to return.

Yl7Kw-UHer-RtNP5gtc3jQ.text: We wanted to sit for afternoon tea,The Wolsely looked great, so I made a resy.Yet the service, the food, and the cakes were subpar,So I cannot advise that you come from afar.The scones were the standout, served with clotted cream,But the rest of the meal left me wanting to scream.That much money for this? What an absolute waste!I've been fleeced, and I'm leaving with a foul taste.So I can't in good conscience advise that you spend,Your money on afternoon tea, my Yelp friend.

2YzVd9cDNr88tBkAdYJOGQ.text: The service was so appalling (even by London standards) that I won't go back, despite having had some great meals there in the past. No amount of good food makes up for the poor treatment.They are famous for their breakfast.  We had reservations for 10:45am and were seated promptly and offered coffees while we waited for our companions to arrive.  The rest was downhill. Our waitress pretty much disappeared.  We flagged someone down to order a bottle of champagne - it took 10 mins for it to arrive. It was much too warm and the cork exploded out, with a considerable amount of fizz spilled on the table.  The waiter sloppily poured our glasses, and came back to only halfway wipe up the mess that he made.After 20 mins our waitress finally reappeared to tell us we needed to order in the next 2 minutes as they were going to stop serving breakfast. Seriously? Maybe if she has come by the table sooner this wouldn't have been an issue.I wanted pancakes with fruit but no blueberries.  From the other tables it looked like it was a mix of strawberries and blueberries, but she claimed they only had blueberries and no other options.  They were advertising "apple and blackberry compote" as an addition to yogurt, so after a confusing exchange she finally relented to letting me order that as a side dish to the plain pancakes.The food did not all come out together.  Eggs came without toast, pancakes with no compote. When we inquired about the compote and my friend's croissant, someone returned to tell us there were no more croissants. (Why did they wait until all the food was on the table to tell us this? It was the only thing she had ordered!)  The "compote" turned out to be an ice cold dish of cheap applesauce with some blackberries thrown on top.  I suspect this was improvised and either the waitress didn't place the order properly or they had run out.Throughout this experience we had to constantly try and flag someone down for everything - syrup for the pancakes, butter for the toast, the bill, the credit card machine to pay, etc.  This was supposed to be a special occasion and at best, we were treated like an inconvenience. I won't go back.

GPlO3FePN_1CjES_meq4Lw.text: This place is great if you're looking to have brunch. The food is amazing. I had the eggs benedict and my sister had the french toast with bacon and we ordered a hot chocolate and a mocha. While the food was good, the service is not. You'd think this place would check up on you or refill your waters, but no. Despite having so many waiters walking around and checking up on other people, it's shocking to see how careless they can be. Especially since they seemed to pay more attention to the older families than to a pair of teenagers. Although by end of the meal, one of the hosts realized that we were just waiting for them and he apologized profusely so props to him for noticing.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

4omWUTu3d3NVRxuHQWM8EA.text: Pretty interiors. Tried the fishcake but it has a bit of "fishy" smell. The yoghurt cup was such a pleasant surprise though. It was really nice and refreshing. The English Breakfast was great too :)

X7jjiz9R_UB10dj6hIcMJg.text: Ehhhhh skippable.The Wolseley is known for their afternoon/high tea, but if their breakfast is any indication of their afternoon tea, then DEFINITELY pass on this program.I was interested in the history of Wolseley, my family has a thing for history and cars, and this used to be an automobile showroom in the 1920's, which is pretty cool. The 2000's refurbished Wolsely itself is nice to look at but strangely unmemorable. If you do end up going, you may see what I mean.We made 7am breakfast reservations before my flight back home. We arrived a few minutes prior and were seated by a host that greeted us, who then dug into his computer - without saying another word to us. We awkwardly stood there before he decided that it was okay to seat - or look - at us. Their baked goods are made in-house, from croissants to brioche, it's done here. They are set in tables in the middle of the rooms - to showcase them. In a place that charges for butter, then it better have something to look at, right? Oh, you read that right: they charge for BUTTER when you order TOAST (which does not come with any meal, and is a cost by itself.) And the marmalade/curd/chocolate spread for the toast (or baguette, in our case) was an ADDITIONAL charge. I was surprised that they didn't charge me for the napkin. For the record, I wouldn't say that I throw money around but when it comes to food.... but I'll admit that's where I spend my money. This, was a waste of money. My husband ordered coffee with milk, and I ordered an Americano. The Americano came out in a pot, which was unfortunate because the coffee was bitter (?) so I had a lot of bitter coffee. We looked through the menu, him choosing the gruyere omelet (zero accoutrements like bread, fruit, or starch) while I chose the Florentine (spinach) eggs benedict for myself (again, no accoutrements.) They have two sizes, one regular and one large, ￡12.50 and ￡20.00 respectively. Dang, I thought. That must be one helluva benedict. I ordered the large one, not really sure knowing what it meant.I'll save you the suspense and tell you what a large benedict here is: It's whole untoasted room temperature English muffins (not cut in halves) with the poached egg, spinach, and hollandaise sauce on top -- making it way too bready on each bite. The hollandaise was good, as was the egg and spinach.The service was robotic and charmless. Not formal/informal/rude/polite -- literally robotic in manner and voice.I'm bummed that this was my last meal before leaving London. As I told my husband: I chose poorly :( 55 GBP I'll never get back..

Hue21AKvY_ypl-uSS56vfA.text: Came here super early to avoid the queue and the food is very underwhelming. Price is pretty steep while food is just mediocre. Service is rather slow as well.Definitely another overhyped tourist trap. Wouldn't come back again for sure

nL3_tntgo8x03Z_h4fViAg.text: The Wolseley sits atop the list of timeless London restaurants. Located in the heart of Piccadilly, this European café is known not only for its classic menu, but also for its lavish Venetian decor. Here, you can order pretty much everything from a simple bowl of yoghurt to an unnecessarily extravagant caviar omelette. Because you pay a premium for the ambiance and dining experience, food runs quite pricey. Reservations are recommended, even though they're open for basically the entire day. Just goes to show how popular this place is.// Eggs Benedict (£9.25 small / £18 large) - 4 starsIf someone asked me what a quintessential eggs benny looked like, I would use a picture of this dish. You have your perfectly poached egg, creamy Hollandaise sauce, fresh ham slices, and toasted English muffin.// Bavette Steak (£19.50) - 4 starsOur waiter mentioned that this steak is only served with medium doneness. Although the flap is generally a pretty tough cut, I thought they did a good job of preserving its tenderness. The béarnaise sauce added a nice rich flavor as well. Served with a side of pommes frites and gem heart salad.

Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Bavette Steak (19.50)

NLszgrh2_s0ziKDS9kVesQ.text: I was absolutely delighted and impressed with the afternoon tea service at the Wolsley! My friends and I had made reservations months in advance to make sure we got to experience this place during our stay in London and we were not disappointed!This is one of the quintessential places to go for a classic tea service. The ambiance is elegant without feeling pretentious. The service we received was excellent and professional, our server took time to explain recommendations and made sure we were thoroughly enjoying everything. We had so much fun dressing up and sharing delicious tea, scones, tea sandwiches, and mini pastries. To top it all off we had champagne and a chocolate dessert.I only wish I could have tried their breakfast, lunch and dinner offerings!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Tea and champagne

hXd058_7Bh_XjS9Kzr14ng.text: One of the more affordable afternoon tea venues in central London. Their afternoon tea packages are about a fraction of the ones at the Ritz around the corner. Their tea sandwiches are awesome, along with their sweet pastries. Tea was wonderful as well.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

spC8pSVC6h8F36uqvjmIpQ.text: My last meal in London at the Wolseley was an absolutely delightful experience.  One thing I wanted to try during my visit was a "Full English Breakfast" - and from my research, the Wolseley came highly regarded as a London breakfast institution.I woke up early just so I could make the trek to Picadilly and be there right when they opened.  I was seated immediately and was impressed by... well, everything.  The servers and hosts were all extremely polite and carried themselves professionally.  The interior of the restaurant was posh, elegant, and refined.  The atmosphere was casual, yet formal enough for both tourists and business people alike to enjoy their Friday breakfasts.  It just felt so... well, classically British, I suppose, haha.I ordered a green tea and the "Wolseley Full English."  Again, service was impeccable.  The tea came out in a special silver serving platter with its own tea strainer.  Fancy!  The Full English breakfast came out soon after and I couldn't wait to tuck in.As an American, we hear tales of the legendary "Full English breakfast" - hearty, heavy meals meant to be enjoyed at a local greasy spoon after a late night out rather than in a fine dining establishment.  And maybe that's true.  But the Wolseley version blew me away.  I didn't think it was possible to really "elevate" eggs, bacon, and sausage - but they did.  The scrambled eggs were uber rich and creamy.  The portabello mushroom was perfectly grilled and absolutely juicy.  The sausage was meaty yet tender, with a nice subtle sweetness to it.  My favorite was the black pudding - I'd never had this before and was eager to try it, and I loved every bite.  It was rich, flavorful, and sweeter than I imagined it would be - but it worked perfectly.  I wish more (or really, any) breakfast establishments in the USA had black pudding on their menus, because I would order it every time!Despite the heaviness of the meal, the Wolseley version of the Full English somehow felt "light."  I'm not saying it was a healthy meal - after all, it had bacon, sausage, and probably an ungodly amount of butter and cream in those delicious scrambled eggs.  But it's a credit to the Wolseley that I ate that whole dang plate and still felt pretty good about it after.OVERALL: 5/5.  I see why the Wolseley is so highly regarded.  Excellent atmosphere, service, and an amazing Full English breakfast.  I'm so glad that I had the chance to experience this during my trip to London, and the next time I come back I will definitely return again.

ICC1rYOMFUpD0_1W--yhrQ.text: A lovely room but... boy was the Sunday roast blah. The medium rare slices were brown on the edges, not from the roast, but from having dried out. Served luke warm, it would have been okay with a hot gravy and even hotter roast potatoes. But the potatoes had to be sent back as they were ice cold. The reheated once were barely edible.Sorry to say a partner's Welsh Rarebit didn't fare much better. No next time here.

myMEEGAENx9aFRGzOT1HKw.text: I think this may just be my favourite place in London. I'm a huge fan of avocado toast and don't mind paying for it. I've spent more $ in America on avocado toast and let me tell you, if you do decide to give it a whirl here, it is DIVINE. Perfectly seasoned, a piled high on a really soft base. I love it and I miss it dearly. It seems ridiculous to write a review based on one dish but that is how much I miss it here. My sister also enjoyed her breakfast and tea. I can't recall what she had but it was a lovely granola or something of the sort. We also couldn't take our eyes off the spectacular details in the room. The decor is so beautiful and the service was honestly outstanding. Everyone was so kind and amazing in general. We would gladly return. Our only regret is not going back again before leaving London.

in-_cy_xkv1_0EglQTN9UA.text: Absolutely fantastic avocado toast. The pastries at 10:30 weren't incredibly fresh. The eggs Benedict was good. As usual there was hustle and bustle and they really try to get a quick churn sometimes at the expense of fantastic service but still somewhere we enjoy.

FppA0FicSYsm_ylR3uoHXw.text: Amazing location and service. Bit like stepping back in time to the roaring 20s, but with a wonderful modern menu. Good place for people watching too.

FoDC-c4RiMTTaNoBF8eJNA.text: Great breakfast place in an elegant setting. Safe bet for a quality British breakfast. The building is gorgeous.

AO30DSrRoXqmBuFYIl23Ug.text: Love the egg Benedict! Old school but classy, service also great! Would definitely go again and try the seafood.Only tip: Better not use the toilet.

BxxPiAGOQ5lEP93z9zpOpA.text: Wolseley is such an institution in London and I have been looking forward to having afternoon tea there since I moved to London. Finally, I booked it for a friend's leaving do. As soon as we walked in, we were informed that we only have 2 hours for the afternoon tea. We were sat on the small upstair area, which was cool that we had a good view of the whole restaurant from above. However, the services up there was bad. I had heard great things about their services, but we didn't have any of that. I had hoped that there would be some special Wolseley twist to afternoon tea since it is so famous, but nope, there is really none. Just plain old over-priced finger sandwiches, scores and desserts. We were kicked out at the 2-hour mark and frankly, I didn't want to linger.

k1yJo8nJhm3Coq9Ai0xzpQ.text: First off, the tea and scones, sandwiches etc were great! My problem with this Establishment is the service.My Fiance and I came here for Afternoon tea which starts at 3:30 p.m. We got there early at 3 and put our name down...we were told it's early but we are first in line for afternoon tea so we hungout at the bar. Service at the bar was great. About 5 mins passed and the hostess told us we will be seated soon and the tables were being cleared off. We thought okay great we will be seated early!  Almost half an hour later, other people are being seated and we are still waiting! Then the hostess comes over to tell us it will be about 5 mins because she's waiting for a table to pay and leave. Umm what??? You told us a very long time ago that the table was being cleared! How is it that you're now waiting for another table to get up??? We were pretty upset and I didn't even want to eat there anymore but we already waited for 45 mins. Soon after we complained we got seated...Our waiter greeted us and I asked him a question about the tea menu to clarify something and he mumbled and I thought maybe he didn't hear me so I repeated and his response was "you just order whatever you want" and shrugged with this annoyed reaction. I was so freaking mad. Having to wait so damn long, then to get a waiter with an attitude, completely ruined my first ever Afternoon Tea experience. Very disappointed with this place. Only good thing is that I saw Russell Brand and he said hello.

0fsJXwp_rDmq41vienI0Dw.text: This is place a beautiful breakfast place in the heart of the Piccadilly Circus.

6aqKlvfmUZgVK2DxYfl3lQ.text: Always a stop while in London. Lively, beautiful space and friendly service. An old institution still standing and keeping up with the trend and food.Strongly recommend.

Qqv1oochOGPOUMCkfYErzA.text: When cars were the ultimate luxury, the Wolseley car showroom was an emporium of European inspired beauty to show them off in. Fast forward nearly a 100 years and it still feels so very decadent, albeit now for speedy lunches rather than speedy motors. But posh cakes, posh cars, same same aren't they? Their afternoon tea service team may as well have been a motor sport pit crew, fast acting with well timed finesse. Their afternoon tea is truly an art form. Every attendant cool as a cucumber sandwich, the team highly choreographed like a Bob Fosse flick on the stage of this impressive  set with high ceilings, slick marble; once housing a bank, now a dining hall and this really does feel proper fancy.I usually could care less for afternoon tea; cucumber sammiches, macaroons and such likes are not really my thing, but this was really special. You can also bank on the effort that's in the exquisite delicate flavours. I loved the chicken and tarragon finger sandwich which was rather lovely and the scones, oh my, light light light, all the better to butter them over with heart clottingly cloying fresh cream and strawberry jam. After gallons of tea, as they kept topping our pots up with hot water, I finished this date with a Pimms sorbet, decadently topped with prosecco, not much mind, but enough to transport me with a sugar and caffeine high, out on to the pavements of Piccadilly feeling like a right lady muck.

pBdNKlniR7N8LfLfePSrhQ.text: We went in for afternoon tea but ended up ordering dinner.  Tea is definitely worth ordering.  Food was great.  However it is a bit pricey for dinner and presentation is plain for plate such as an omelette.  Service was great and there was a dinner cover charge that we didn't know about.  I had the lemon tart for dessert and it was delicious.  I would go back again but this time for tea and scones.  Place has lots of history and prides itself on service.

PuvUgL5hiIcbuaABO9o6kw.text: Came here for Afternoon tea while visiting London from the US.  We had to e-mail the restaurant for a reservation, as the restaurant said it was booked online.  They promptly (and politely) replied and got us a table.  The tea, service and food was excellent.  We did two afternoon tea + one cream tea and was enough for our party of 3.  Beautiful space.  We did not feel rushed out of the restaurant, which was great, as in the US restaurants try to push you out pretty quickly.  Had our table for about two hours.  I would make a point to make it back to the Wolseley on our next trip to the UK.

fk7jAss7D9qngD2miWN6rg.text: Our first Afternoon Tea experience. Considering none of us have tried Afternoon Tea ("High Tea") before, it was a must-do while we were in London. The Wolseley seemed like a decent choice with good reviews and it was not too pricey. Making a reservation on their website was quick and simple, too.The Wolseley is a fancy restaurant and it looks nice inside. It would have been fun to sit at a table in the little dining area upstairs, where you can view the whole restaurant from above. I would have requested that had I known about it at the time of booking our reservation. We were not able to find out whether there was a dress code as well, so we went for smart casual just in case and it was fine. (I was surprised to see a couple men in jeans and Converse sneakers.)It was a busy Wednesday night and it was quite noisy, surprisingly. We had 'afternoon' tea at 5:30 PM because that was the earliest reservation available (we were a bit last-minute in making our reservation). The service was all right, but it seemed like the servers kept changing on us which, I thought, shouldn't have been the case being a classy restaurant and all. For our teas, we chose The Wolseley Afternoon Blend, English Breakfast, and Assam. I liked all the teas, but my friend thought the Assam (a black tea) was not as strong as she expected.When the food came, we all thought...that's it? (It was our first Afternoon Tea experience after all.) But the food was surprisingly filling.The best part was the fruit scones. They were so fresh and so good with the clotted cream and the strawberry jam. It was delicious! Out of the five sandwiches (smoked salmon, chicken, cucumber, celery, and egg), the smoked salmon was my favourite. The chicken was decent, too.Unfortunately, the desserts were disappointing... Out of the seven different kinds of pastries, only the chocolate éclair, the fig tart, and the cheesecake were all right. I was expecting the desserts to be good, if not, really good...By the end of our meal, we had a little bit of everything left so we got it all packed to-go. The server showed up with a bigger box than expected, and he told us he slipped a few more scones and pastries inside. That was quite nice of him, since we loved the scones!All things considered, I don't think I will be coming back to The Wolseley for Afternoon Tea, but I do want to give their breakfast or brunch menu a try. As for Afternoon Tea, I definitely want to see what The Ritz and Fortnum & Mason have to offer in comparison to The Wolseley. Sadly, that will have to wait until the next time I visit London!

mNVBRULsouwMs2_uzOAjUA.text: Was here for brunch with friends. All of us chose the egg Benedict and no surprise that all of us enjoy it! Really the best that I have ever had. The soy latte was good as well, served with a piece of dark chocolate and some water. The decor is very nice and in British style. Good for friend catch-up in this warm environment. Recommend to book the reservation to avoid waiting with hunger.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Egg Benedict

ve59PVBFM9V4AMsNMbweJg.text: Items ordered:CoffeeAlmond CroissantCanele DuoBlack PuddingPan fried fishcake with poached eggFrench Toast with Fresh Berries and Pure Maple SyrupWith one o'clock reservations in Bray anticipated for the past two months it was after another riverside run that I hopped into the tube en route for 160 Picadilly, home to the ever fashionable Wolseley and a breakfast that would finally deliver on the full promise of its star-studded menu.  Appropriately described as "a café-restaurant in the grand European tradition" with soaring ceilings and stellar staffing overseeing the meals of men and women in suits it was just moments after 8:00 that I arrived at the hostess stand and offered a table up front, away from the hustle and noise, I gladly accepted - the next ninety minutes absorbed in free Wi-Fi and five plates from which only a slightly soft croissant suffered in the least.  Obviously higher priced than much of the competition but befitting both the quality of the cuisine and the status of its clientele it was with a large pot of coffee paired with two Parisian quality caneles that my meal began and slowly savoring the subtle custard of each as I picked intermittently at the croissant it would not be long before my server noticed the pattern - a replacement pastry immediately offered and proving better by far.  At this point entertained by a stream of e-mails I'd neglected for the past three it was not long before a full pitcher of amber arrived hinting at things to come and with two savories plus one sweet comprising my 'main course' it would prove difficult not only to decide where to start, but later to decide which was best - the fish cake a veritable Brandade Benedict, the caramelized French toast strewn in fresh fruit only improved by a healthy pour of pure maple syrup, and the smooth black pudding by far the best of the trip.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Almond Croissant
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Canele Duo
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Canele Duo

E5YzKT4ik0HUcHBgLy_ejg.text: Came at about 4pm and the place was packed. We waited about 15 minutes and they gave us a table near the bar.  The restaurant was beautiful and the hostesses were exceptionally courteous and proper.   We came because we wanted to experience the "afternoon tea".  We were originally planning on having afternoon tea for 2 but the waiter had suggested that if we weren't very hungry that we can just order tea for 1 and share. This was a great suggestion and that's what we did. It was a good thing because the actual pastries/sandwiches was extremely underwhelming.  the Sandwiches were "wonderbread" typed bread with a slice of something in between and the crust cut off. So one was a slice fo salmon, one was a slice of cucumber and can't remember the other. The salmon and cucumber slices in between the bread was cut paper thin so you only get a very subtle taste.  then there was 2 pastries, can't remember what they were. and 2 scones. The scones were pretty good but i think what made it spectacular was the clotted cream they gave you to shmear. The tea we had was the "wolsley blend" which was quite floral and tasted better than my expectation. The tea pot also was quite unique....it was big and reminded me of genie's magic lantern.  In all, it was a good experience and we had a good time. it came out to $42 so we were glad we only ordered for 1.

7Sl2NaW73UoRnXY0ekJ9dg.text: First breakfast was fantastic two years ago but recently we had a most disappointing brunch. Service did its best to explain away some tired food. Maybe a one off for such a famous venue

UAmuIOfeyNN3tHzhAymeNQ.text: The atmosphere was amazing and the ambience was nice, but my food (Eggs Florentine) was only average as the spinach was overly mushy and overwhelmed the rest of the dish. I also ordered the broccoli as a side, which was fairly flavourless.Furthermore, the service was not great, as our waiter kept missing us.

1s_9G93-kXvjCXTuTG2odg.text: I went here for a work event. We had the private room upstairs and a set menu. The staff was incredibly accommodating. We had a full time server who took care of every need. The food was very good (salmon starter and roast main). A classic menu with a classic ambiance.

bhZ5sA07AXUXOjEFZbBtwA.text: The food was awesome, I had the lobster and the atmosphere was gorgeous and relaxing.

hRUAYj0us4fFVVp6UTem1Q.text: A rather posh place to go if you want to treat yourself to a good brunch. Good menu selection served by a distinguished staff. Very presentable and excellent service.

5Oku6yan5jo0z6qv_CcNMA.text: Hands down my favorite place to dine whilst in London. Our previous visit in 2016 we dined with my sister & her family. They're members so we got a choice seat & there was plenty to look at (ahem, Joan Collins at 12 O'clock). My memory is a bit vague on what I had but I did LOVE the endive salad. This time around & since it was a short distance to our hotel we opted for breakfast with my niece & her fiancé. This place is super busy during breakfast as it is a very popular place for breakfast meetings. I suggest making reservations. We were seated promptly & again loved the table. I started with Earl Grey & H decided to go with The Wolseley Imperial which just about had everything in it: mandarin napoleon and cognac, long espresso, hot milk topped with chocolate and whipped cream served in a schmancy glass. I admit it was very tasty! For food, I ordered the large Eggs Benedict (you can order just 1 which is the small) because I knew H would want to have a bite or two since he ordered the jambon & gruyere omelette. The food was delivered piping hot & OMG the best benedict I've had (and I've lived a very long time). Two perfectly poached eggs sitting on slices of ham, topped with hollandaise. All this on top off a scrumptious muffin. The muffin was so soft, pillowy, & toasted just right. Hmmmm. I'd fly across the pond just for the benedict.As usual, the service was stellar even though the atmosphere was frenetic we felt like we were the only diners there. And huge shout out to the really kawaii girl at the next table that not only polished off the large portion of EB but also a serving of waffles with fresh berries. Have no idea where she put all that food.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. The Wolseley Imperial

YCPufbz9t0ssmExnxc01wQ.text: A tad pricey for what you get but if you're looking for an English breakfast place that's adorbs, check The Wolseley out!  You can even get afternoon tea! (albeit it's a bit more pricey than some places).It has an upscale feel, and it won't disappoint unless you're boujee af.

cEBmeTbd87HQ-MMs6SADuw.text: My first high tea experience was here, and it has set HIGH expectations for all future tea visits!!We came here on a reservation and were seated almost immediately. We had a group of 8 people with two reservations of 4, but they were kind enough to accommodate us with adjacent tables. My table ordered the afternoon tea that came with unlimited food and tea. The tower itself was quite the sight to see (and eat)! The first tier was finger sandwiches, second was assorted cakes/pastries, and the third was scones with clotted cream & jam. I ordered the earl grey tea for myself. Food and tea were all delicious, and we came out of there with an intense food coma.What a lovely, memorable London experience!

hlYMMgub1nHhCbZy_1G9eQ.text: Blah, got off a red eye and needed some food while we waited to check in to our hotel. Slow inattentive service, poor quality food served cold and not worth the price.Wish we had breakfast somewhere else.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

JkdI80xUdjPV4ipesF296w.text: We were convinced by reviews and recommendations to visit the Wolseley for an "authentic" English breakfast. We found it to be extremely over priced. £21 for coffee!!!! Really? The service was also "stuffy". They forgot our toast (which putting on butter would have cost an extra £1). Ridiculous. The food was good, but not great. Very commercialized. My advice to the staff is at least give a level of service that the patrons are paying for. Maybe then, you'll get the reviews you're looking for. We call this a "tourist trap" in America. Beware. Ciao.

6ImqdjhrWkFZ619Y9pvplg.text: We were only here for a quick lunch so I can only comment on that. We arrived about 5 minutes before lunch hour ended, so the host quickly rushed us to our seat and our waiter stood there as we received the menus waiting for us to order. My sister opted for some kind of superfood salad and I had the schnitzel. The food came out incredibly fast and I have to say, I was a huge fan of the schnitzel. I was not, however, a huge fan of the service. It seemed that other tables were getting reasonable amounts of attention, but the waiter that took our order actually never came by our table.... ever again. No one offered us water, and no one came close enough that I could flag down (or would make eye contact with me) to check in at all after our dishes were served. I had to flag down a waiter walking by at the end JUST to get the check. I'm not sure if there was a weird handover since it was just after lunch hour, but with a place as nice and classy as this one, I would have expected significantly better service. It's unlikely that I would return again for lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Schnitzel
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Super food salad

FRNi9S_4Q_n9UUA9wUf8Bw.text: We had the afternoon tea for 37.50 pounds per person (+ 12.5% of service charge). It came with a choice of tea, small sandwhiches, 2 raisin scones and some pastries. The tea was excellent and the food was good, although some of the pastries were a bit too sweet for me. The service is great. The waiter and the staff were very friendly and nice. The place is clean and is located on picadilly street, near the buckingham palace. I found it a bit pricey for what it is, but it was a nice experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

y9xK5FYXzjrsuOAwKzk8kw.text: My husband and I came here for dinner. Food was okay but terribly overpriced for what you get. My husband was hungry two hours later. The service was good but still not worth the pricetag.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

7QegvNsB08QcBrDSPdOSUg.text: I was craving a good hot breakfast just about everyday I was in London because of how cold it was. Ricky found this place and made reservations for us on the last day we were in London. Located on Piccadilly... right next to the Ritz....this place is packed on weekend mornings, make sure you have a reservation. The architect William Green originally constructs this place in 1921 as a car showroom for the Wolseley Motors. After it was a Barclays bank, and then a Chinese restaurant "The Orient at China House". Lastly in 2003, it was reopened after restoration and renovation as an upscale restaurant by Chris Corbin and Jeremy King. When you visit you can see and feel the history. It is just remarkable and beautiful. I was personally of course quiet fond of the Asian pieces located throughout the Wolseley. This place since 2003 has won multiple awards and been one of the highest profitable restaurants in London. When we arrived it was December so the interior was decorated with Christmas decors which was a splendid sight. It brought a joyful ambiance to the place. When we arrived, we were seated immediately due to our reservation. Thank goodness because I was starving.Immediately after bring seated, we ordered as we reviewed the menu in the cab on the way over. Hubby and I both ordered French toast with berries with an order or smoked salmon and eggs to meet macro protein daily requirement (even on vacation lol). It was good. It is quiet hard to mess up breakfast food in our opinion lol. Oh and we ordered coffee and OJ of course. It was delicious breakfast. Breakfast here feels upscale, but fun/youthful/laid back which really is a lovely way to start the day. Not like the Ritz next door where it can feel kind of stiff and quiet (I do prefer that for afternoon tea though- relaxing and soothing time). And during the holidays the festivity bring a fun and romantic bounce in the air. I highly recommend paying a visit here.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

1jCNdTyUT0CjDvDSYVM5XA.text: Lucky to have been here twice. I love it. Love the tea, love the sandwiches, & love the ambiance. The service is great. The scones and clotted cream are delicious. I left the airport during my layover just to come here.

7Mbw0q_5fJYMrbrXbdv_oA.text: I had such a great time at The Wolseley! This was my first time having high tea in London, and everything was top notch! Service was impeccable, food was good, but the tea selection could have been a bit better, as there was only one choice for non caffeinated tea. I absolutely loved the decor of the Wolseley, from the front entrance to the bathroom! It was such an experience, and I truly enjoyed myself. While researching places to experience high tea and trying to make reservations, we were unlucky because most restaurants charged upwards of £60 per person and were oddly booked on a weekday. We got a recommendation here, called about 2 hours ahead and were able to be seated, and seriously we enjoyed ourselves! I've told others who visited London to come here as this is the premiere high tea experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

lFdcLM6w7ksW-rWE8kAD4w.text: This is one of those iconic London brunch restaurants I've been meaning to come to for ages. We came on a busy Sunday morning and to be honest my initial thoughts were a bit underwhelming. We walked in. Staff seemed busy and not particularly interested in our arrival. However, we were shown to our table quickly. Dining room was grand but had a feel of a busy brasserie, with quite a casual vibe.Service actually wasn't great, which is shame because I'd heard such good things. All our waiters seemed a little indifferent to us and not at all friendly.However the good - the food! My eggs arlington (their version of eggs royale) was brilliant with beautifully creamy hollandaise. We also shared some french toast which was really delicious. So ultimately the food was great. But it was quite pricey and service was poor which does let it down a bit as it undermines the whole experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Frencg toast with berries

AarTXtdDhmCpkuT1B-or5g.text: Really amazing experience overall. Wonderful service and very British feel, with great vibe. Don't miss the avocado salad, escargots, and burger. It's a must stop is you are in London. The bread and Butter are excelent for those on the low carb diet....

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

APMKHiZMnfTsoCskysQEOw.text: Everyone says breakfast is the most important meal of the day. In London, English breakfast is a must.The Wolseley is a very popular and impressive spot to get a lovely English breakfast in the morning. It's highly recommended that you make a reservation here. We were able to get a table as a walk-in, but we came almost as soon as they opened on a Sunday. By the time we had finished our meal, the restaurant was packed and couples and families were crowded around the main entrance waiting for their tables. My BF and I both ordered the English and the Wolseley English breakfast tea. Our tea came out first. Since we ordered the same tea, we got a big teapot. The tea was full-bodied and rich. Although I typically do not like taking sugar or milk in my tea, English breakfast goes very nicely with these condiments. The English comes with your choice of fried, poached, or scrambled eggs with bacon, sausage, baked beans, tomato, black pudding, and mushroom. Everything was delicious! If I wasn't so full, I would have eaten a second plate. I only wish American breakfasts were served with proper baked beans, black pudding, tomatoes, and mushrooms. It really enhances the overall meal and creates layers of flavors. This is a pretty traditional English breakfast - no frills.One downside is that they charge for toast. Also, the service is very perfunctory and somewhat slow. It's not too unexpected given how busy this place gets to be, but it also makes the experience stiff. The price is also pretty steep for breakfast.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. English breakfast

VbKwSePcMdz2mUVBpNDKeQ.text: In an old car dealer showroom of the same name years gone by, a great example of London's repurposing existing buildings. Lunch at this icon is not to be missed. Excellent food, a sharp crowd, beautiful flatware and table settings, one of life's pleasures. I ate too heavily with a chicken Kiev , but should have opted for a main coarse salad which looked great. Would certainly return to this wonderful London restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Curried rice with a poached egg
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Delightful salad
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Kiev, enough for 2

u434dGjdXaT6LXrlHhtLMg.text: 3.5 stars The Wolseley isn't gimmicky or "themed" like some restaurants that serve afternoon tea. The decor is timeless & sophisticated. You could just as easily have a business meeting as you could a first date here. The sandwiches, scones, & petit pastries that make up Afternoon Tea service was absolutely filling. Halfway through our meal, our waiter asked if we wanted any more sandwiches or scones; we balked at the thought of more food. A few of the sizable finger sandwiches contained heavy cream cheeses, & though the pastries were tiny, they packed a rich, decadent wallop (think: cheesecake, marzipan cake, chocolate cake, etc.) Hearty & a bit overwhelming at times for a meal that is supposed to be quite dainty. Would not return for afternoon tea, but would come back for breakfast. My decaf earl gray tea was fine, though I wish there was more of a decaf selection. £37,50 per person. Outstanding service, sat us promptly for our reservation, & checked on us frequently.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

W3o43Tmxnzgbt7QSVgD2zQ.text: The Wolseley is a classic and stylish English establishment. We hoped to walk-in for breakfast/brunch at 10AM on a Saturday and were in luck - they had a table for 3 people, though a bit after we were seated there was already a 30 minute wait. I ordered the English breakfast tea and the two eggs with toast soldiers. Everything was beautifully presented and tasted impeccable. My meal, made of the simplest ingredients, was such a delight! The sourdough toast was perfectly chewy and buttery. My companions' meals were also beautiful. The ambiance was grand and classy, and there seemed to be a nice balance of locals and tourists in the clientele. Though the experience was a bit pricey, I thought it was worth it, especially as a treat for our last meal in London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

x7YKhoMpTPP8-1leEE_nqA.text: The best place for brunch in London. The Wolseley is really romantic and elegant,and food here is also amazing. The pancake is really delicious!!!

Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

ny7VLHcK7aOUnr0A2Cl59A.text: Had afternoon tea. Service was great. Their house blend was good. The sandwiches were tasty. The cake/pastries were a bit too sweet for me.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

U3_KjRL5yNvM6TMVN2UNJA.text: The English here is quite simply the perfect breakfast.  Quite busy at 9am on a weekday morning, but there wasn't a wait.  Service was professional and expedient.  This will be a regular stop for me when I'm in town for work.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. The English

FZS-w8VLNEmTUivbV3Gdow.text: On my last day in London, I decided I wanted a full on English breakfast.The black pudding was delicious, the service was top notch, and the restaurant itself is simply beautiful.I loved how formal the tea setting was, and was VERY happy with my food.Fantastic and perfect!

oTHzWTHpdL69p10qH-ahLg.text: I'm a fan ... sometimes.The first time I went to The Wolseley for an alumni brunch with my university, I had to-die-for eggs royale and the freshest of orange juices ... it couldn't have been more perfect. The second time? We were crammed into a tiny table (six of us, that is), my chair was knocked with every passing customer and staff member, and my potato rosti was lacking in flavour ... and everything else. To say that it was a disappointment was an understatement. The avocado had simply been sliced and dumped on the plate, along with a grilled tomato and two giant mushrooms. No seasoning whatsoever. My dining companions' pancakes and fruit yoghurts didn't look that much more impressive. And in an extremely competitive brunch market (I could have opted for nearly any little establishment in Dalston or piled-high waffles and pancakes at favourites such as Granger & Co., for example), this experience simply didn't measure up. Not so much a waste of money, as a waste of time.

YwBNKmlKEmSvDf0oEDSLag.text: Planned an after-work dinner and we had no idea what a night was in store for us.  After ordering dinner, a fire alarm went off and the staff asked everyone to exit.  The staff and management were professional and provided updates while outside with firemen and trucks surrounding the restaurant.  Thirty minutes later it was all-clear and no fire and the staff invited anyone left outside back inside.  The whole team picked up where they left off while the manager apologized to each table for the event.  The dinner was prompt and delicious after a crazy interruption.  Thanks to the staff!

rJMLzTQw4WFu8vELEUmurw.text: Blah. We heard a lot of good things from local friends about breakfast at the Wolesley. And while the full English breakfast was good and my wife's eggs benedict was tasty, I can safely say that we won't be coming back here. Really, this place is for power breakfasts. Everyone around us was dressed in suits of the banker's variety. Everyone was conducting business (we even saw a secretary taking notes!). And that meant that the waitstaff knew that people were not paying attention to them, allowing them to take shortcuts and make mistakes. Our orders were taken quickly and we were served with equal speed, but we were forgotten after that. Whenever we did want something (sugar for the coffee, or jam, for instance), we had to tell the waiter twice in each instance to get the desired item. Unless I have a client who insists on it, you won't find me at the Wolesley.

CrjJ8MU-dwU1O-gAXt-i1Q.text: Had a wonderful afternoon tea here with some visitors. Because I was already quite full, I went for the basic afternoon tea menu, which just included tea and scones with jam and clotted cream. Everything was fantastic. The scones were light and fluffy, and the jam and cream were amazingly fresh. The portion is pretty generous for the price, location, and the style of the restaurant, so generous I couldn't finish my order! But a pleasant surprise was that they just gave us extra scones and instead of just putting in our leftover jam and cream into a container, they just gave us the nicest containers that were filled up with new jam and cream. The packaging, from the box to the containers to the takeaway bag, were exquisite. Definitely wouldn't hesitate bringing others back here for a classic afternoon tea!

Nsuf5oAG8qrXb4zMAH1zhA.text: This place was such a fantastic experience for me, and I must thank Yee Gan O. for recommending and taking me here! When Yee Gan asked what I most wanted to do in London, I said, with no shame, that I wanted traditional English afternoon tea. I am sure somewhere in his head he groaned a bit ... but hey, when in England ... you must!Luckily we got in without any reservations (although the place is very busy usually) and got into one of the last seatings for afternoon tea around 5pm. They have many different sets to order from, and we ended up just ordering one set between the two of us because we had dinner plans later on. The tea was served in a very nice silver tea pot and our dessert / food / sandwich tray came out quickly after. I love all the gadgets they use to serve tea and all these cool things you rarely see in the US because we are not a tea culture there.The treats were delicious although I think my favorite was the little green tea mousse thing! Highly, highly recommended, I had a wonderful time. Thanks Yee Gan O.!

1tkZCGbNIt1Xm3tpSHqY0g.text: I originally reserved a table on August 15th (via email) at 8:15 pm for dinner for both me and my mother. We couldn't make it. I remember being crushed because I really wanted to check off this quintessential English restaurant from my short three-day stay in London. Wasn't meant to be I thought.On our second day, we went to Buckingham Palace and decided to cross Green Park to make it to Piccadilly Circus. I had forgotten that we would pass the Wolseley! And I'm glad we did. Without a reservation and in need of something to eat, we were greeted by a nice doorman. We got a table for lunch. Not in the main "eating area" but in a side room. I ordered the classic Egg Benedict (the small portion), which is basically a fancy version of an Egg McMuffin from McDonald's. That is not meant to be a stab. It was amazing and went well with my cappuccino. My mother ordered a steak that came with a salad and frites. She said it was her favorite meal in London.P. S. The bathroom is impressive. It's underground and below the enormous clock.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. The Classic Egg Benedict!!!

DW0V_dQCkgtO9IPpIM8MCQ.text: The reason I give it 4 stars is because .... So I called this place the night before to make a reservation, they told me it was full.Even though in their website it wasn't. So I ended up making the reservation online. My friend and I wanted a true English breakfast for our last day in London. I have found this place on yelp before I got to London. We had breakfast on a Sunday, right when It opened the place was packed. Everything on the menu looked really good. I ordered the English breakfast.. Since I am a vegetarian, I told them to give me more mushrooms beans and eggs and take out the meat. I've fell in love with baked beans ever since I  landed, and their baked beans were really good. I also love how fluffy the eggs were! The rest was just whatever's. Maybe I was just not really in to veggies in the morning.Go try this spot out when you get a chance, they are kind of pricey though.And don't forget to make a reservation, it's usually packed.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. The English, without the bacon and sausage!
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Green tea

gKhMR769IPGgOAa8Cjs8dw.text: I'm a tourist and had a lunch here. The service was horrible , waited for long time to serve me, the waiter and other servers have no smile at all, RACIST!

8kwYSPhvRLLQK2wFp-pblw.text: Breakfast starts at 07:00 on the dot from Monday to Friday (and from a gentler 8am at the weekend). All the Viennoiserie is made on the premises with the Mixed Basket containing a selection of mini; croissant, pain au chocolat, danish, amandine pain sucré au beurre normand, cannelé bordelais (£8.50) being the star of show.There's a great selection of dishes on the breakfast menu to suit all palettes, including granola, fruit salad, fish cakes, potato rosti and kedgeree as well as The English with a choice of Fried, Poached or Scrambled Eggs, Bacon, Sausage, Baked Beans, Tomato, Black Pudding and Mushroom (£16.50).Antonia decided to have the Potato Rosti with Avocado, Tomato and Fried Egg (£8.75) which was really good value and beautifully cooked. I had The English, which was certainly a good fry up but equally certainly not worth £16.50. The black pudding had a very crumbly texture to it, which I can't say I was a fan of I think one sausage is a bit stingy when you're paying that kind of money.

MDDqKsmDhDi-y4JCrmerGw.text: Visually stunning place to have a lunch in the space of a former car showroom. You'll need to book well in advance so hopefully you're not a spur of the moment diner. Sadly, the service was a little spotty, we kept having to flag people down and were never asked if we wanted any coffees or anything after our main plates were cleared. Food was all good but to be perfectly honest, not spectacular as I've immediately thought of a few better versions of what I had ordered that I wished I was eating. It's actually a good value for money unless you go for something like the caviar omelette. I think there's a time and a place for the Wolseley, and it's something you should do if you're in the market for treating yourself but don't let the fact that you haven't been keep you up at night.

7EGKYknLBjULfWnmSr7AKw.text: One of my favorite experiences in London.The Wolseley was recommended to me by a Londoner when I mentioned that I was coming to the city for the first time and wanted to experience Afternoon Tea. All of my expectations were met and exceeded here. I quickly learned it's best to have a reservation. Although their dining room was booked up, they seated me in one of their two parlor rooms, which was very lovely and suited me just fine. The staff was gracious, and paid attention to my tree nut allergy, which I appreciated very much.When my three-tiered tray arrived, I was in heaven.  Everything -- the food, the decor, the staff -- was excellent, and worth the £23.75.  Should I find myself in London again, I'll definitely return.
