HU-ADXktqetT0MEfYvTNJQ.text: What a fun place to have breakfast. The food matches the fanciness of the setting. I had The English breakfast and it was the prefect start to my day. A plus was having Ian McShane a few tables away.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. The English Breakfast

qKbrNMKwC_l8ofIyA-SpUA.text: A very nice place for breakfasts. The Eggs Benedict and Pancake with Berries are very very good, must try. We came here two days in a row for breakfast on our vacation because we enjoyed it so much. We didn't enjoy the Eggs Arlington as much as the Eggs Benedict as the salmon made it a bit too salty for our taste. The omelet with jambon (ham) is nice and solid on the outside but very soft inside. The decor is very unique and the people at Wolseley were also very nice. Will come here again for sure next time we are in London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Eggs Benedict
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Pancake with berries

s7swL35x_Bc2KIcGoHn2Qg.text: As others have stated, it's very beautiful inside.  If I visit London again, I'd love to make a reservation (we waited about 45 mins for a table) and try to sit in the main dining area.  Afternoon tea was a lovely experience (my first).

wqy71S5TCE5if5SYTswzfA.text: Overall a very classy and fine dining experience. It was busy so the service wasn't the fastest but still acceptable. Great wine list and very decent grilled filled of steak. The fries were mountainous.

rhHN1Es9m4lp8PEQUvFTgQ.text: Food is good- everyone having lunch at my table was pleased with their food.Service was good and was attentive.Noise level is high**Extremely difficult to reserve seating**Menu is very limited**

ehsf4GqFWYGEPu2RnINzpA.text: Once again, thanks to my visiting Yelp Elite friend Lorrie M from San Jose who gave me an excuse to treat myself to the 'tourist in your own town' experience  when she visited London last weekendOne of the must do experiences on her list was to have afternoon tea. To be honest, it's a ritual that I had never considered - my Chinese Thrift Gene won't let me pay £42 for tea at the Ritz when that could get me a great proper meal elsewhere, However, when in Rome with a tourist........... heheLorrie had a scary amount packed into her 3 day visit and her small time window for tea on Sunday afternoon actually made it easier to organise by cutting down the optionsThe Wolseley has a colourful history, having been a car showroom and a bank but since opening its doors in 2003, it has attempted to retain an air of a grand European dining room and you will see diners dressed up in their finery to partake of grand British classic dishes, which makes it an ideal to enjoy a quitessential traditional English afternoon teaDespite its air of grandeur, it's nice that you can dine in here in casual clothes without feeling out of place, while being able to enjoy the cultured ambiance, They also serve afternon tea til 6.30, which is later than most placesWe were seated without much delay despite not having a reservation. As we were due to have dinner in the near future, we shared one afternon tea between us, which turned out to be plenty, especially as we were offered a free refill on our sandwiches.I think Lorrie enjoyed the tradition of the 3 tiered tray with sandwiches (crusts cut off of course) on the bottom, cakes on the middle tier and home made scones on the top, served with clotted cream and strawberry jam. The tea was also served in a nice traditional teapotEverything tasted lovely in an afternoon tea sort of way. The egg salad sandwich was my favourite sandwich but our favourite item was the fluffy scone - I showed Lorrie how to split the warm scone and slather it with clotted cream and jam. It's yumminess which makes you want to break out in a verse of Land of Hope and Glory!For visitors to town, the Wolseley provides a chance to experience a tradiional afternon tea in a splendid surroundings without breaking the bank

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon cream tea
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

S9Kw4mSlUSgZO20NQT099w.text: Perfect place for a nice Sunday lunch!  The setting is very grand and elegant -- feels like you're taken back in time.  I had the Sunday special which was roast rib with Yorkshire pudding, and it was delicious.  The meat itself was of good quality and well prepared, but I actually enjoyed the horseradish sauce the most.  It was the best I've had, and went perfectly with the beef.The only downside of dining at the Wolseley is that it's very busy (at least on Sunday afternoons), and because of this, service can be lacking.  The staff are all very friendly (including the old-school touch of having a doorman), but it feels like they're very rushed and sometimes it can take some effort to get their attention.  Still, for the food and the ambiance, I'd certainly return for another visit.

tp7TAIibbCrBrjYobgEopA.text: Ambiance gets an A.  Service was great and for how nice it looks, the prices were not crazy.  Food was a B+ but exactly what we were looking for.  Cocktails could use some work.

wo5tpvhIo4mb5O0oFdDQLA.text: I'm a great admirer of Chris Corbin and Jeremy King and what they did particularly with Le Caprice and J Sheeky were textbook case studies in the London Restaurant market. Their comeback to the capital probably post the end of a non compete period is another story. The Wolseley on the other hand is probably closer in execution and positioning to another of their great success stories , The Ivy. The common theme here is that the food at both is no great shakes in fact for me the food at The Wolseley just does not cut it. Hand on heart I cannot recommend anything on the menu and say it is good or even average be it the Salade Nicoise, Steak Tartare, Salt Beef, Hamburger, Weiner Schnitzel, Steak Frites or any of the deserts with the possible exception of the Banana Split. If the food is not the basis of your decision-making when selecting a restaurant in this price bracket then you may find that you can have a pleasant evening in another David Collins Architects restoration.

Vn42nieb3l5030tpHn62Gg.text: You come here for the very British atmosphere, the food was nothing to rave about. Although I came here for lunch and I suspect afternoon tea would be a much better option (as other Yelpers seem to suggest).

8NZTTIV0a6LF-xGoszTrrA.text: A great place for business breakfast, great menu and an incredible buzz at that time of the day during the week. Less good for lunch or dinner. Staff tends to take themselves seriously but less so than at the beginning when they first opened. Excellent eggs benedict. Very central and great space with super high ceilings and an interesting deco. Interesting people watching too with the mix between the media, fashion and finance crowds.

oOctEMGKb5vTlD-ErDTuoQ.text: Another one of the places that you should not be using for business meetings. The incredible buzz Frederic describes just makes it hard to talk. The place has a certain grandeur to it, they also do a nice viennese Coffee: The Einspänner.The history, if you care to check the website is quite interesting. Originally designed in 1921 as a car show room at Picadilly for the Woleseley Car Company (Picadilly seems to be still en vogue for this, the Audi car show is just opposite from it) it was after only six years converted into a bank. It opened as a restaurant as late as 1999. Grand, not cosy

nGnbTBAsHTmAeV_OisAaMQ.text: The Wolseley is a good place because it is open from breakfast to late at night. It's very busy , so booking essential just be sure you are not ''up the steps'',there's a wide range of food, at just over mid range prices. And while many places have these attributes, the Wolseley has a certain buzz, so you feel you've been 'somewhere', it's difficult to pin down, I guess it's attention to all the details.Not all meals are great value, I remember a 'Cassoulet' which had a lot of beans but not much meat. Breakfast is very good.Quite a celeb haunt, on my last visit Michael Winner was in.Service is pretty efficient , but not always friendly.

4BvMW1lS82UqcqchuelA_A.text: A bit trite but generally pleasant. Good for business meets and coffees. This place is terrible at the weekend: full of women from Surrey who think they're going somewhere "classy".

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Wolseley

zZGx-hSs9Fxl7SHQIFibSQ.text: Standards have dropped quite dramatically, both for breakfast and dinner. Will not be dining here again!

wqxsE6qxFgqMTpBKkAmMDQ.text: Went here twice in two days. Once for dinner and once for breakfast. Service was good, albeit a bit rushed for dinner (they were quite busy). Breakfast was the more enjoyable of the two meals. Fair priced for the area (which is quite pricey in general). Can get quite busy so try to arrive early.

fWlHcOm20mQo3T_qtZV1iw.text: quick note as to why i'm not giving it 5 stars: the server misheard our order and we got the small afternoon tea instead of the large afternoon tea (= we didn't get sandwiches and pastries, iirc). which i guess was fine, really, since i don't understand how you can eat so much so close to dinner time. (damn yankee!)my friend and i came here for afternoon tea on the suggestion of (and in the company of) her friend who frequents the wolseley for the same. a wonderful space that isn't stuffy but harkens to a bygone era of sleek style and class. incredibly friendly service, too! the clotted cream was so yummy as was the strawberry jam, and the scones weren't dry at all. and, of course, my earl grey was oh so yummy. as melanie k. said, apparently you do see famous people there, but umm, i had no idea who they were. apparently we were in the company of someone who owned a soccer team [err, football club?] or two. great location -- get off at green park, head towards the ritz (the building with the flags sticking out) and go past it a block or two. easy-peasy.p.s. umm, they seem to not really have a strict dress code--i spied a guy in there in a sleeveless shirt (tho, to his credit, he was wearing chinos... O_o), which is kind of disappointing. i hate dressing up, but i say at least put a little effort into it! (guys, a nice button-down and jeans would be fine, imho)

dpXURB3EB4oNi1rPATUKTQ.text: Can't go wrong here.  Great atmosphere, good food, excellent service and a cool history.

Dte_Zd0INUkQ5LXZqjgvTQ.text: Well I love the Wolseley, especially for breakfast. The architecture is great and the service is pretty good. I went in the first week it opened and have been many times since.I don't live in Surrey.It is a great place to take people for breakfast if they are visiting London, the building has a real sense of ocassion especially with it's location on Piccadilly.I really like the antique teapots and the full English 'aint bad either.

DZ_Ef3wqXFBkOPHXk8Sp3w.text: This place is utter perfection. From the minute one step in, it's like stepping back in time. From the delightful service to the delicious coffee, the Woleseley exudes a grand atmosphere and is a feast for the eyes. One cannot go without donning a lovely outfit (it would be bad manners). Put on a dress for the lady or your favourite jacket for the gent, and head there for a meeting or date - it's sheer bliss. My recommendation? The cream tea is an absolute treat. Divine!

-TGRhB70qrWQSQH0HDoiyQ.text: This has become my favourite place to be for breakfast in London. we popped in out of the snow for breakfast on sat, and were immediately greeted by the lovely waiting staff, who found us a table within minutes. The service was exemplerary , the staff were professional but completely approachable, and we felt very much at home. We were suffering slightly from the excess of a night at Ronnie Scotts the previous evening, and so ordered up a hair of the dog in the shape of a couple of bloody marys  these definitely hit the spot and were a great accompaniment to our eggs benedict. Service works like clockwork, which you'd expect with the number of staff, but it's also the little touches in details, such as the silverware, and the way food and drinks are presented that make a visit here such a great experience. We loved it so much we returned the following day for brunch  and were not disappointed. We tried the croque madame and the fishcake with poached egg, and the fresh juice of the day  all were exceptionally flavoursome and well cooked. We're spoilt for anywhere else for breakfast now

KluDE19Rcvadfmb6hgSF1w.text: People are beginning to complain about The Wolseley as just being a place to be seen. That may be the case for some shallow folk, but I've never had a bad meal there (but then again, I've never had to pay the bill, so I would say that!). I'm yet to eat there in the evenings, but the breakfast and afternoon tea has always been superb. The haggis with duck eggs was probably the most fantastic breakfast I've ever had the good fortune to eat, and the selection of croissants were gorgeous as well. With regards to the afternoon tea, I have no comparisons, but that doesn't mean I don't know what makes the elements good. The sandwiches were lovely, and the scones were pretty much perfect. The design and layout was great, be it on ground level or the balconies. Plus it's not even overly expensive! (Cost is obviously subjective for must people, but relatively speaking it's worth every penny)

KMhDUQhJjhh-NgPmR0oOZg.text: I've been here for an 'ordinary' evening out and also for a celebratory anniversary meal and both times have had delicious food. The setting is beautiful - the decor make it feel like a really special place to have your meal. It's also a great place to star spot, if you like that kind of thing. But, the last time we came here mistakes were made - extra bottles of wine and deserts that we never had appearing on our bill. Which wasn't a surprise as our waiter, although a happy chappy, was also a fairly inattentive one.

RwCBhFJVKw891opmcN_78g.text: These period tea rooms close to the Ritz Hotel on Piccadilly are a great place to visit. Its a fantastic period building, originally commissioned as a car showroom in the 1920's, and was then a bank and Chinese restaurant before being restored and refurbished to reopen as the Wolsey in 2003. Food here is as you might expect expensive but because the menu focuses on snacks rather than meals its very feasible to visit and enjoy light refreshments without too much damage to the bank balance. Also hot water refills for pots of tea are free (unlike Starbucks and Costa Coffee etc) so for tea addicts its probably quite good value! My friend had her last birthday get together here which was very good fun. Prebooking is recommended to ensure you get a table.

giAhdWpGm3F-wxaFMwoZ-Q.text: Feels like a buzzy European bistro set in a stately bank with extremely high ceiling. Not cosy but not fussy, either. Unless you're a regular, you won't get the best people-watching tables but the service is brisk and the menu is simple with something for everyone - like many other establishments founded a few years ago, they specialise in new British International cuisine, which is a euphemism for upmarket comfort food. I have always enjoyed the Wiener Schnitzel. They also do an afternoon tea in a more congenial, less lugubrious way than some of their colleagues in the neighbourhood (The Ritz, Dorchester, Browns, etc). Still, if high afternoon tea is what you want - and nothing else - I'd recommend the Dorchester or Claridges, because they are more glamorous without all the pretension (of the Ritz).

qItL096f_2IEQULk38H9sQ.text: Anytime I am visiting London eating here is a top priority. Their breakfast is so tasty with teas and coffees served in silver pots (I've only ever gone for breakfast which I think is reasonably priced). Very old world. It's also in a great location with Bond Street only a short walk down the road. However it is always very busy so booking ahead would be advisable.

4IJhlXqeNzW9mq8KBTUiaQ.text: While everything on the menu sounds delicious and actually is delicious, the atmosphere is overrated and service is quite appalling, especially given it's reputation. Although the actual space is quite beautiful, the acoustics are somewhat reminiscent of a very large canteen. And sadly, due to it's location, it's full of tourists. Let's just say i don't find trainer-wearing, rucksack-carrying tourists easy on the eyes. All that said, I still I might go back for brunch or maybe the treacle tart... but only if coerced.

Ufq478DiZoo6j32bhABDVg.text: We walked in with no wait on a weekday afternoon for a bit of afternoon tea.  The scones jam and clotted cream were lovely, as was the view out the large windows facing the street.  Classy but still casual.  Bonus - free wifi!

Jf9PdyCrGUTmUDBXBzkIew.text: Great food. Great pastry. Love their Earl Grey. Light but elegant in flavor.

X1jdxNhHTKUOwBxG0P0EtA.text: Coming in off the street, one is calmed by the lowered noise level of this quiet room. Greeted and sorted and led to a table or booth, a menu is presented. Nice food offerings, prompt service. A moment after I came in some tourists came in dripping cameras and stuff. Even they were sorted (into the bar area) and the calm returned.So nice a place to grab a few minutes of peace before plunging into Piccadilly. Enjoy!

slaRre9jQjhaCkOzecZffQ.text: This review comes from an American visiting the UK for the first time: I found myself in the middle of Piccadilly Square after a long day of sightseeing. I was tired and hungry, so I decided to Yelp! a place for dinner. This place came up, it looked good based on positive reviews. I walked in and asked for a table; the guy took my request and asked me to wait. I stepped off to the side and a couple of minutes later another guy approached me and started telling me that they had a really long wait. He told me that I would have to wait beyond half an hour, but despite that he couldn't guarantee me a table. Then, he started giving me some bullsh*t story about how they are reserving tables for people coming from another restaurant that had to close due to some bullsh*t problem they had today. I noticed a couple of things pretty quickly; 1. pretty much everyone in this place was White (except the one guy they sent to talk to me) 2. since I had been walking around London all day, I was dressed casually (jeans and tennis shoes) everyone else NOT.I got the hint, so I walked out. I still felt tired and hungry, but now I also felt discriminated against. My suggestion if you decide to go here is to call ahead, make a reservation, dress up and maybe, just maybe they will serve you... but, no guarantees!!

h819euTHhIcDlBptU9Hlxg.text: I just don't get why this place receives such good reviews. I've been here twice for breakfast and have been disappointed both times. It really is very pedestrian. The food is unimpressive and the service more so. Turn it back to a car showroom I say.

UmensJbVqSkzrBOqCNurow.text: I was left pretty disappointed with The Wolseley. The interior is, of course, beautiful and I understand that the sheer privilege of dining explains the high price point. However, I didn't think the food was up to much - my friend's bacon was burnt and my eggs were fairly tasteless. As a sidenote, I'm usually one who is willing to pay a premium for organic juice. However, at £3.50 for 250ml (a large, by the way), I'd expect the apples to have been sourced from the Garden of Eden!The service had its bright spots (extra water volunteered for the tea, friendly banter when paying the bill (oddly enough)) but, generally speaking, staff traversed the line between surly and apathetic. One almost stabbed me with my own fork and carried on as normal. As sad as I am to say this (since it's such an institution), I won't rush back.

4VV0evnB2EsjY399Qus8ug.text: can seems a bit posh and suity.....well it is just a couple of doors away from the Ritz (the area is more posh than funky), but posh accent aside I looooove this place......for a nice dinner, great breaky and a delish sundy roastI even hear its a great place for celeb spotting, but more the political type of celebs.....which probably explains why I didn't know them even when pointed out and sitting practically next to meI thinks its called french american, which might explain why the service is not snooty and that there is a slight air of funk in how the food is served...but only slight and only sometimes (they wouldn't want to go to wakey). I'll be back here again soon, probably for breakie next time, although its a bit to expensive for me to be a common occasions (unless I can bag me one of the frequenting lawers ;-) )

0VfPiqjVJ7ASPPI40v6gBQ.text: YUM!!!!!!!Goats cheese tart with the most delectably sensational tomatoes and stunning basil coulis ..... lordy Gets better ....... Succulent, saucy, huge, orgasmically satisfying lamb chops ........ mint peas on the side ..... gooooooooodneessssss me! The portion size was fabulous! I cannot fault a thing. even the price was reasonable for the experience. (reasonable in a posh restaurant sense). Really impressed. Will defo go again to treat someone or myselfor just for a special girly afrernoon tea.... it really is a treat. And we got to eat by Hugh Edwards ...... i mean ... not every day you get to sit next to a welsh news reader! ;)

RMRVqiKQXF0S8eFDNodRRA.text: Great place to take visitors.Go for the celeb spotting. Accommodating to walk-in customers. Service excellent.Food Good, but not mind blowing.Great oysters.

3WEuyBIHb-8ziqaAI2plCQ.text: I went for afternoon tea at the Ritz, the Wolseley and the Langham. Out of the three, I'd rate the Wolseley as my second favorite (or second least favorite is also possible...) after the Langham. The tea was good, the pastries were tasty and the scones were a great mix of flakey and buttery. I'm no scone expert -- but the scones at the Ritz seemed far too cakey while the scones at the Wolseley seemed like the perfect mix of flakey, dense and airy to be a great clotted cream and jam carrier. Another big upside was that the service was friendly, although it was some times a little hard to get a server's attention. Also, we arrived a little late and I was catching up with an old friend -- we had lots to talk about. Too much apparently, the Wolseley asked us to leave and free up the table, which I thought was a bit odd, though understandable.

EV9lOkWFfxo-0mhM6Ub-dA.text: I've heard that The Wolseley is very "hit or miss" depending on what chefs are working. I must have gone on a good night (Friday) because the food was excellent. My place of work employed a chef from the Wolseley who would cook us the most spectacular lunches. The Wolseley is a lesser place without his cooking. Nevertheless, it's not the food that let this review down.The architecture (marble pillars, arches and stairways and  Venetian and Florentine detailing) is beautiful. The building was originally a Wolseley Motors showroom in the 1920s and has been maintained as such. I suggest dressing well to fit in. It wasn't the architecture or atmosphere that let this review down either. The drinks however, are what stopped me from giving them five stars. Nobody in this establishment (including the bar manager apparently) knew how to make a Cocktail Vodka Martini. My table agreed. Despite being as specific as possible regarding the details of my desired poison (extra dry, over ice, one cocktail olive) they still brought me vodka in a cup.Dinner is wonderful. The bar is dreadful (if you drink Vodka Martinis). I hear from others and the posts below that tea is great.

Yda0mRlVTtvJlV-2ugSy1w.text: One late afternoon we decided to give this place a visit and get some tea. And it was fun, I never thought going out for a tea can be something fun

_pdbo5LPs3k6IXFnUBTOjA.text: Why do people love this place so much?Yes, I realize the setting is very pretty, but the food is just ok.  Nothing special at all.  And yet, it's nearly impossible to get in for brunch on the weekends without a reservation.  The eggs benny and the pancakes were good.  Pretty standard fair in that department.  A little overpriced, as everything in Mayfair tends to be.Took my mom for lunch, while she was visiting.  And the same kind of experience.  Had soup and a sandwich, and she a burger and chips... and again, just ok.  So, I guess the bottom line is, if you're looking for mediocre food in a pretty setting, The Wolseley is the place!

P4RMxXe9c4Wjtx8vyOqiVQ.text: One of the things that we decided we had to do in london was afternoon tea. we had a blast - we'd never done it before. we were each given a pot of our own tea followed by three tiers of food goodness.the scones with fresh cream and strawberry jam were simply amazing. the finger sandwiches were quite delightful as well, and all the desserts were so good too (the strawberry rhubarb tart was the best).we did have to wait awhile to try and get someone to give us our check, but we had a great time.

plSIbZlC1A2jLOx34V8jbg.text: I see little point writing an extensive review of this place, because all those wise Yelpers before me have covered it well.Personally it's all about the Champagne Afternoon Tea, it is gloriousness. The tastiest little sandwiches, Chicken Tarragon was super tasty I even swapped it out with a friend. Freshest little cakes, the pistachio macaroons were beautiful in both taste and appearance and would give Laduree opposite a run for their money (unless they come from there). And the warm (well kind of we did eat slowly) scones were divine.Food aside (rarely said by me) the service is professional, courteous and friendly. And the ambiance is like something out of an Agatha Christie novel, I could have stayed there all afternoon.

eCrc3AXNfr049QHC0Gv2AQ.text: Nice food, and delightful afternoon tea.  I really like the clotted cream here for some reason...  Menu is crazy overpriced (probably like a 200-300% profit margin per item) and full of tourists (suppose those things go together), but at least the Wolseley does not compromise on quality of food.  Even a simple toasted chicken, bacon, avocado sandwich is beyond what you can get at EAT or Pret.  Worth it for the experience, at least once.

d8KNEd51ThiIUvrvYaQ6UQ.text: 42 pounds for Afternoon Tea for two.  Ouch.  But come on, I am in London and I have to have Afternoon Tea, so why not go all out and go for the creme de la creme.  Here's the skinny (or not so skinny really):- Pot of Earl Grey - EMPHATIC YES!- Cranberry Scones with Strawberry Jam and Clotted Cream - WINNER!- Perfectly cut tea sandwiches - Smoked Salmon, Cucumber, Egg Salad, etc. - HEAVEN!- Passionfruit Macaron - There were other things on that plate? Yes, but who cares?  Didn't you hear me?  Passionfruit macaron half-dipped in chocolate.  That, folks, is all you need to know.

nGsRXs_BwflKin51SjyuFQ.text: The restaurant is breathtaking when you first walk in.  The ceiling are high and very decorative.  We had just came off a tour so I didn't feel like I was at all dressed appropriately in my jeans and t-shirt.  I definitely recommend dressy casual for this restaurant.  We went to the bar and ordered a drink while we waited for a table. The had a vast selection of wine to choose from.  I got a wonderful Sauvignon  Blanc.  The host was very pleasant and came to find us as soon as our table was ready.  The had a vast selection of wine to choose from.  I ordered the steak and my mom ordered scallops.  Both were very appetizing.  It was one of the best steaks that I have had since I have been in London.  It also a great place to star watch.  I met a bronco player while I was in the bar which was definitely a highlight.  The service and the food were wonderful.  I recommend this restaurant to anyone who enjoys a great steak.

IiOaLZ9LoRsFolwc6AjaOw.text: The Wolseley is very theatral, people in the balconys, you can see everybody, the ceilings are spectacular. A super fine place, breathtalking. A must London experience. Great oysters, the food is just ok.     We ate dinner for the second time the day 250000 people made a strike in Central London, making barricades, they broke the glass of the Ritz Hotel, people screaming thast they were anarchists, making fires and fighting with the police. 81 hurt people, more than 200 detained.

YC8ag5MjJA1P60cIiPWYLQ.text: In my hours-long research sessions while planning the cuisine schedule of my trip to London (museums? shows? don't be silly) I came across one piece of advice that was too persistent to be ignored: you must go to breakfast at The Wolseley. Alright then, I'm not one to ignore advice from fellow Yelpers, let alone the entirety of London dining-out sites.So I came, hopes in hand, for a delicious gastronomic experience. I even skipped dessert the night before in preparation for my croissant basket. The decor is brilliant, as my mother commented, reminiscent of  Balthazar in NYC. The menu required some interpreting but eventually I settled on the bread basket (essential) and the gruyere omelet. Sigh. The basket came with plain croissants, pain au chocolate, and almond croissant, a rich chocolate cakey deal, and one other unidentifiable pastry. It was alright. The pain au chocolate was undeniably the winner.My omelet was...boring. I could have made it at home and it didn't come with any extras. No potatoes, no fruit, no bacon or fat-laden sausage. I was unimpressed.What I will say for The Wolseley is that it is a fantastic people-watching arena. Located in Mayfair, just east of the Ritz, there is an air of importance about its diners. Business being conducted. Socialites putting ketchup on their pancakes. Dirty youth who could only be assumed to be massively successful rock musicians that I cannot identify because I am not posh enough.If anything, go for the atmosphere. Or the poached eggs, which my co-diner thought were "perrrfectly cooked."

2ydQm5B629JUPFN7X61AHQ.text: Worst tea ever! Cannot see what the fuss is about. The sandwiches were dry and sun dried tomatoes do not make an edible sandwich--had a chemical taste. The cakes were also dry, heavily sweet but otherwise tasteless. And the worst thing was that someone does not know how to make tea! Ordered Darjeeling and at first I thought that I had not let it steep enough but after 5 minutes, I realized that there were simply not enough tea leaves in the pot to make anything other than pale, watery tea.  Coasting on its reputation? Who knows. But there are certainly  much better options in London than the Wolsey.

lNbt0PJKdYBDdV3xlr8Oew.text: We happened upon this restaurant after we canceled our reservations at Dinner- because we decided to go to a show.  This restaurant was open and willing to seat us after 10:30 p.m. - we were never rushed and the food and service was excellent.  The restaurant itself was pretty magnificent, as well.  My favorite meal of our entire trip to Paris and London.

G99Goj7qrTpQ4neErI-VJg.text: Hard to not like Wolseley.  High ceilings, very old school decoration, renowned chef/owner.  And you enter the place.  And the environment just welcomes you.  You sit and browse the menu.  You want to try all.  It's that simple.  But you need to settle for one.  So you start to make trade-offs.  And economic theory tells us that every trade-off creates a dissatisfaction for the decision we make.  Apparently we keep on asking ourselves, after the decision, whether we made the right choice thereby diminishing the positive benefit to be derived.I settle for an English b-fast.  It's a big plate of everything.  It turns out I didn't make a single trade-off.The taste is good, ok.  But not outstanding.  Well be it...I would have easily given them a 4 star, if they had not charged me extra money for the 2 small toast on the side of the plate.  My bill would have remained almost intact but the very fact to charge for a mere toast infuriates me.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Ambience... Ambience...

WwocBIxwaHD8QPhoOpm7Tw.text: St James staple and apparently one of the oldest restaurants in London to have maintained a doorman. It's always nice to walk past and see him greeting guests and opening the door. Sometimes the old ways can show us how we should be today.The food there is gorgeous, and the setting, inside an old car showroom, is a grand place to eat. High ceilings, open spaces, and the fixtures and fittings all lend itself to a fantastic eating experience.It's always busy and getting a reservation is a must normally, however, they always keep some tables back for walkins so even if you haven't got a reservation, try your luck. But don't expect joy if you turn up with a party of 10...For me, the Eggs Benedict is a winner for me. They've been perfect every time I've had them.

h7aZHbTB_nzogzQA9-eCAg.text: This was a fun place to get after noon tea. We called for reservations to be on the safe side, and called earlier that day. It was def. a bit high class in terms of the staff but was told attire is casual and can we wear anything. Would be a fun time to dress up though. The finger sandwiches, crumpets, and little desserts were pretty good. Crumpets were the best part. And the best best part was the AWESOME butter. Best and creamiest butter I've ever had hands down. Jam was good too. The tea was very good. We expected to be charged for the second pot but were not. We ordered one afternoon tea plate thing for two, since we had a late lunch. That was more than enough for a light snack for the both of us. There are probably better deals for afternoon tea at other places. But the experience for afternoon tea is what we wanted, and I think we got it!

7NJwxZpYXzV-_oLMDxIE2A.text: Went here for dessert with a friend. We didn't have reservations and had to stand and wait for half an hour but I didn't mind. The dessert was fantastic and the staff were friendly and accommodating. Next time I am in London, I plan to to back (next time with reservations ).

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Hands down, the best dessert I have ever had.

eFFvwb9B7Jv_vLIlH7_K0A.text: Great breakfast in the hoity toity part of London (it's across the street from the Ritz) where I had a great celeb sighting in Bill Nighy eating his eggs.Never had haggis and duck egg before but it was delicious though very very heavy; even more so than the traditional English brekkie.This is a white-glove service restaurant so expect attentive, snap-your-fingers staff. And it seems to be very popular among suits as that's who we dined with when we visited. It's a little too posh for my taste but I'm glad I got to experience it. And btw, love the little toast separator thingie they have in this city; it made me feel like a Princess.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Fried duck eggs and haggis, if you please!

a4TV8iGJQmchNyzQ38d4CQ.text: The escargot leaves much to be desired.  It is noisy, so be prepared to talk LOUD.  Nonetheless, food is pretty good and they fuss over you.

29cXegh_FBKh4RxCHXt7lg.text: Popped in for lunch after arriving in London with my family. We were not blown away with the service. I thought the food was good enough, my sandwich was exactly the portion I was looking for and my parents' sandwiches while much larger were also good. We had a side order of fries and that was enough for 3 of us. Perhaps it's better to done here for breakfast.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Grilled chicken sandwich. Lots of chicken!
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Ham and Cheese sandwich. Just the right size.
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Ham and Cheese sandwich. Just the right size.

mLs2QSWgjmz0Uz-5WLujSQ.text: The first thing I noticed about this eatery is the posh interior design.  Originally, it was probably constructed with the idea of becoming a café. I assume this because of the ceiling design & pillars. The greeters are most polite and our place setting was immaculate. The servers are dressed in smart attire & our original server aimed to please us. I ordered the french toast toppled with blueberries & strawberries.  A side order of scrambled eggs and orange juice completed my breakfast.The food arrived in a timely fashion but it was the second server that interrupted the flow of my breakfast & positive vibes. I was interrupted  in mid conversation with my guest at least 3 times from the server. It was demanding & a bit over the top behaviour.  Attempting to clear our table without inquiring if we even finished our meal yet. I felt a bit rushed...Once we addressed the issue with the server, they continued to ask " Have we finished this....or that... "  To be honest,  our server seemed to lack basic communication & body language intellect when working in the restaurant customer service sector...a bit incompetent.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. French toast toppled with strawberries & blueberries !

iX7uucWsiPPBkCekRLHZBw.text: The moment I walked in, I knew this place was going to be a winner. The place itself exudes elegance and old world charm, and the service adds to it. We had reservations and our friends who are locals booked us one of the tables upstairs. I loved having a bird's eye view of the place and seeing all the busy action below. I ordered the eggs florentine and they were the best I've ever had. The bread wasn't so much an English muffin as it was more of a softer, doughier bread and it was phenomenal. The poached eggs were cooked to perfection- many I had in London were cooked too much. We also ordered the French toast with bacon and again another winner. I loved the table settings and how all the plates served have the name 'The Wolseley' on them. Coffee is served in these beautiful silver coffee pots that make you feel like royalty. As to service, it doesn't fall short. All the servers were attentive to us even though we were sitting away from where everyone was. Several came upstairs to see how we were and if we needed anything and were very quick to get us anything we needed. It definitely made my dining experience one of the best I had in London! Granted it is going to be pricey but I guarantee you you'll feel it was worth every pound- literally and figuratively- by the time you leave!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Gorgeous interior- we sat upstairs for a birds eye view
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Eggs florentine on beautiful plates

OrvTe-WVJxmaShSiHnB4sg.text: A great atmosphere, The Wolseley didn't disappoint. My smoked salmon and scrambled eggs were great, and I felt like I was in a London institution - which I was! Who can argue with a breakfast menu with milkshakes in the first half of it? Especially when it says "with ice cream!" (I'm not sure what else would be in it, but I appreciated the clarification). The Wolseley is fancy. It's old. You'll pay too much, but the food will be really good. It won't be the absolute best brunch you've had in your life, but that's ok. Know that before you go in, and respect the place for what it is. And get a milkshake. Why not.

Rd5O_BIhD5ryRIhdgl9smQ.text: Enjoyed afternoon tea. Would highly recommend the cheesecake. Had a taste of scone with clotted cream and jam. I liked it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Having afternoon tea!!
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Cheesecake was very very very good. Tea was also very nice.
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

efUZMXhvNnsrBIrQRvd_sA.text: Took my friend there for breakfast, we totally enjoyed it. Spacious, charming old school dining hall, immediately gives you a sense of class, but not at all intimidating.  The host and servers were all friendly and attentive. We ordered:- full English breakfast- smoke salmon with scrambled egg and toastThey were both delicious. You see these items on breakfast menus every where, but The Wolseley presented them in a much more elegant way. I loved that they put the smoked salmon around the egg instead of piling it on top, it's much cleaner this way. My flat white was tasty and beautiful, made me very happy! I also like that they have breakfast, lunch, afternoon tea and dinner menu for different time of the day, and the booking is very easy on their website. I heard the afternoon tea there is quite good as well(and reasonably priced). Definitely want to go back and try that.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Smoke salmon and scramble eggs
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. English breakfast
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

qFJ6wfMJokMKePY0AaZArA.text: This is my favorite spot for breakfast in the UK.  I've been three times in the last year and enjoyed every visit. It's definitely best to make a reservation but I have managed to drop in when they open at 7 am for a free table. The place packs up quick and is more or less full by 7:45. Airy ceilings with huge chandeliers, tiled floor, and dark wood provide an ambiance of opulence. Eggs Arlington are my favorite dish with thick cuts of smoked salmon and eggs poached to perfection. If you like chocolate, be sure to indulge in the chocolate gourmand where you'll enjoy experimenting with pouring rich chocolate and steamed milk into a parfait glass to mix to your liking.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast bar at the Wolseley
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast!  Eggs Arlington, double chocolate brioche, espresso, and chocolate gourmand.

avimWnk77mFAri1d6Wgs9g.text: We went here for tea because our Rick Steves guidebook said it serves the best afternoon tea in London. It was fine, but definitely wasn't the best. We had an identical selection of tea, scones, clotted cream, jam, & finger sandwiches in Windsor for one third the price. The setting here, however, is elegant & the service is first rate.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. If you're looking for a class act & don't mind paying a very high price, this is your place.

e4cYaM63VqR5HUfDbJoLRg.text: excellent servicei had the veal schnitzel with fries, one of the best in Londonpacked but fast and smooth service

RbZC4cvIEzofZW1ByywbuA.text: Meant to have a quick breakfast here before trying to pack in a lengthy list of things to do on our last full day in London. We arrived 30 minutes too late so we ended up having a quick lunch instead. The restaurant is beautiful with high ceiling and had a bit of European brasserie atmosphere. The dress code is casual but smart. Our encounters with staff members were great however our server was very aloof with all of his tables. I think he forgot to put in our order because someone else who was not our server came to us to apologize about the delay of our dishes. It wasn't even that long to be honest but he asked if we'd like a coffee or tea while we wait which we appreciated.Food was fine. I had a Gruyere omelet and hubs had the Eggs Benedict. Both dishes were simple and elegant. Reservations are highly recommended. We arrived without one and awkwardly waited for a table in the bar area for a good 20-30 minutes.

qDC1v9Q5B9q382DDSQHh8Q.text: This review is for dinner only. We ordered the salmon and the lamb with brussel sprouts and chips. The lamb was tender and the salmon was cooked well, but it wasn't amazing. I expected more from the Wolseley.The decor is nice but not over bearing. The service was good. It was an enjoyable meal but it was overpriced and not too special.Bottom line, it was good but I wouldn't return.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Loch Duart Salmon and Pot Roasted Lamb

s1_-WHk3CmRepwFrYP6Rhw.text: Went here for my first meal in london and it did not disappoint. Best eggs benedict I ever had. Great flavor and good quality ham. The lamb dish was ok was a bit dry and bland. Creme Brulee was perfectly cooked and glazed.  I would come back to try other things. The restaurant itself was impressive. Great decoration and ambiance. The place is loud, and crowded. Expected for a popular place.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Creme brulee
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Lamb
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Eggs benedict

ZK_bxgdO8VtBJdp_XIr_vQ.text: Exceptional service, great food, and an amazing location. Former auto showroom/bank. Ask for the history lesson when you arrive.

AukDV0qp0YDMedxBTP_tZg.text: Fun, lively, straight forward atmosphere with great food. Great visuals. Old world and new meet in a one-size fits all culinary stapled of London.

GZD81Rl2xxl7wRbLWkWvHg.text: Afternoon tea in London is customary, and the go to place is definitely The Wolseley.  One tip would be to make a reservation.  We went on the weekend, mid afternoon, and the place was packed.  The atmosphere was bustling, and people are definitely dressed to be noticed.  The service was fine, it was very formal, i prefer a bit more down home.  We chose the option of a pot of tea with scones, clotted cream, and jam.  That option comes to $11.50 pounds per person.  The cream and jam were a delicious accompaniment to the scones.  Overall I felt that paying over $25 CAD was acceptable because we were tourists, but i would not  make a pattern of it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon Tea 11.50 pounds

ZpfziRQlC1TrIfsnBOEDhw.text: I was treated rudely at The Wolseley today.  I am staying at the Ritz and thought I'd check out the Wolseley for coffee and pastry before I bring my family for a meal.  I am so sorry I stopped by.  I was waited on by a short blonde woman with a bun on the very top of her head.  If you don't mind being ignored.  If you think it's okay to be be treated rudely.  If you are okay with a grouchy waitress who fusses you out.  This is your place.  Something is wrong with this restaurant - so lacking in customer service.  I won't give them any more of my money.

IYgdW1c6CTS4rzbMSU63xg.text: Touristy but fun place.  From what I could see and experience, this place is best for high tea, meat, and not so much for fish.  I sampled the wienerschnitzel which was fabuluous, but it was just the meat with some fries I ordered on the side.  Others in my party got the lemon sole, and the chicken with bacon sandwich.  Neither of those items was too impressive.  By contrast, every other table in the place seemed to have a tea tray.  We were not seated and had to eat in the bar, which didn't feel too good; the host implied that only those with reservations got seats.  I've got to be honest, this place felt a little fru-fru for my tastes.  So, to be positive, if you do this place, get dressed up, make reservations, and plan to spend some pounds!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Wienerschnitzel

kclDCHjRxkHN_7dELmci7w.text: My friend recommended The Wolseley for their Proper Afternoon Tea, so I made a reservation for the middle of the afternoon and on the day, my hubby and I headed there, dressed in the nicest outfits we brought on our trip! The place was packed, buzzing, with a great atmosphere! The Brits clearly love their afternoon tea, because most of the tables by us were filled with Brits, not tourists. The waiter asked us which tea package we wanted to do, we selected the full Afternoon Tea, with scones, sandwiches and desserts! I opted for the Wolseley Afternoon Blend Tea, and I can't remember which one my hubs got, but basically they were both very good! We're not normally big tea drinkers, but I don't know, maybe it was being in London, or at the beautiful Wolseley, but either way, we drank and drank tea with milk! The presentation of everything was just lovely! The tower of the treats, in 3 levels, was adorable, and the giant teapots with all the herbs inside, and the little strainer, were just so cute! The scones were by far the best, warm, served with butter and jam, omg, I want some now!! There were four kinds of mini crust-less sandwiches, some better than others, but all tasty, and the BEST part, free refills of those sandwiches! The waiter asked us if we wanted more, and I mean, we didn't NEED more, but YOLO, so we got a second helping and ate them all! The mini desserts were so pretty they were tough to eat (jk, not that tough) and my fav was a mini strawberry tart. All in all, this is THE place to go for Afternoon Tea, you'll have a lovely time and will likely not need dinner that night! So plentiful and delicious!

mbFufpjdwZvgQU-nsyfAwg.text: I had my dinner of the last night of 2016 and celebrate my new year on that amazing restaurant, the services was perfect and the Salmon plate  was the best dish over there

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

127lXBVTLaQJ2W_ThNyjcg.text: EN: I was lucky enough to have breakfast at The Wolseley twice last week, both times I was late to my reservation and was seated right away, no fuzz. The eggs benedict are beautiful here, even the pancakes are good and I usually hate pancakes. I really liked the high ceilings and the black and white tile used on the floor, really beautiful place.SP: Tuve el privilegio de desayunar en este restaurante dos veces la semana pasada. Esas dos veces llegue tarde a mi reservación pero me consiguieron mesa inmediatamente sin algún problema. Los huevos benedict y los pancakes de aquí están deliciosos y me encanta la decoración de este lugar.

FZhWX-vYkz2U9vpBQjIwTA.text: amazing place and atmosphere good also for brunch even it is not very advertised for that eggs benedict and black forest cake!! fantastic

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. black forest

zY3OA-J8ozW9FMZYyCZmmw.text: Came for dinner.  Really liked the menu, fairly nice service, lively atmosphere, but the food itself wasn't quite there.  Still, an enjoyable evening.

IXiQ_vRpibX1I9WWGp9w2w.text: I took A here for afternoon tea and came on time for our reservation. We both had a very pleasant break from all the trekking we've been doing. A gets easily tired and I was heavily pregnant, so it was very nice to sit down to some tea, sandwiches, and sweets. We both enjoy afternoon teas and we both did not have any complaints about this one. The atmosphere is very loud and busy compared to Putnam + Mason, which is much more quiet and dainty. This spot was perfect to take my husband.

iOzCXf--7Teh5xyCQ_12dA.text: Okay, so I can't actually afford to have a sit-down dinner here (yet) but I did have a fruit crumble off the cafe menu and it was totally on point. If ordering from the cafe menu, they seat you in the front at casual tables, but as far as I can tell it's a lot less expensive and just as delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Fruit crumble with clotted cream
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

-5Q_35it-kojeB-c_bz8kQ.text: The Wolseley tea room has something for everyone. When my mother and sister are in town, they wanted afternoon tea. Personally, that's my least favorite thing.. with that said, after our walk at Hyde Park, we stopped by Wolseley tea room. to my surprise, they have both afternoon tea and Oysters! Both my mother and I were happy camper. From a tea perspective, their cakes and scones were very fresh and my mom enjoyed the experience very much. She thinks the tea is smooth and really loved the texture of the scones. My son had the fresh mint tea infusion and it was very refreshing. the creme burlee was also light and crispy. Finally, as for my oysters, it was very decent. i wouldn't come here specifically for oysters, but looking at my happy family, I think the place is definitely worth going back!

QPftLrJ2O5z19q6L_2xa6Q.text: Beautiful interior and great place to relax in the near evening hours. Came here for the afternoon tea and enjoyed it. Though the finger sandwiches were a little bland, I did enjoy a majority of them (except the salmon and another one I can't remember). The scones were fabulous with the clotted cream and jam. The little desserts were also delectable to share. The only thing leaving me miffed about this place was the slow service. The person in charge of our table must have clocked off her shift cause we were never able to find her after being served...? We had to bother another person who was busy running around. Took us forever to get the check, then another forever to pay. Very disappointed with the service.

KaglLK2_JHNQxMjO_gcBXA.text: Absolutely fabulous for high tea!!!The environment of the restaurant is very Art Deco and comfortable and the staff is brilliant with their service. We had high tea with one service for full afternoon tea one just for cream tea, but the waiter did not mind if the same table had different orders and shared anyway. The food was entirely WAY TOO MUCH and DELICIOUS!!!!! You can get all of your sandwiches refilled at no charge, not sure about desserts and scones though. Classic tea service with clotted cream and strawberry jam! It's perfect so make a reservation now. Reservations highly recommended, I saw lots of people turned away at the door without one because the place was PACKED all day!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Clotted cream and strawberry jam!
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Raisin scones are delicious!
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea for ONE!

Idc36agGU4ydOfdoKKlVxg.text: We were very excited to finally make it here for breakfast. We were greeted and waited less than 5 minutes for our table. The host was super friendly and let us know that the people at our table were paying. I had booked a reservation several weeks in advance. We waited several minutes before someone came to take our drink order. It took then took another 20 minutes before we received our teas and hot chocolate. Our teas tasted watered down like they didn't use enough leaves and the temperature was warm not hot. When we received our food it didn't come together. 3 of us received our food first and our 4th had to wait another 10 minutes before her food was delivered. The pastries were excellent. My caramelized grapefruit was delicious. However, the bircher muesli was way too thick and had way too many raisins. Both people who ordered it didn't like it. Also the Eggs Arlington was a bit odd tasting because the smoked salmon was so cold it made the hollandaise sauce cold as well. Our server never checked back with us until we flagged him down for the bill. Too expensive for not so great food and bad service. Won't be returning.

1RwkbquWsYmbwRxEK-znfA.text: Order Lobster and Chips, pineapple juice. First meal in London. Based on United States method of cooking lobster: The Lobster was a little over cooked. The portion was too small for the price point. I was not full off of this dish. Pineapple Juice: They simply squeezed a pineapple and hoped it was ripe. Unfortunately the pineapple was not ripe. The display was set up really well. The waiter was courtesy and prompt. The Chips was a bit undercooked. I will give the another shot based on the large menu and the outstanding customer service.

4X-XjDA-eCCA_8YNMqmn8g.text: Scones at top , pastries in the middle - marzipan pistachio something or rather, pear tart, lemon eclair and finger sandwiches at bottom - chicken w pesto was delicious, egg sandwich, two types of cucumber sandwich one with mint and cream cheese , the other a curried version I can do with out, the smoked salmon is so so.The afternoon blend is rather malty and a it on the bitter side for tea. Scones with clotted cream is the bomb!

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Tea service. Wish they poured for you too..
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Scones at top , pastries in the middle - marzipan pistachio something or rather, pear tart, lemon eclair and finger sandwiches at bottom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Plate prep for afternoon tea 25.50 pp

t0jZ3M_wLxRdYufIvwPDeQ.text: Not cheap and very crowded despite the elegant decor. With that said, the Caramelised Pink Grapefruit is possibly my new favorite dessert. I am not a fan of tea in general but my companion loved her Earl Grey. Reservation is highly recommended.

X-yfgX63Dsy6v6Ut95NNOw.text: We had made a reservation for high tea at Wolseley at 15:45. The restaurant is impressive in its decor and was very classy. We were seated promptly and our waitress was great and friendly and explained the menu well. But from there our experience went down hill quickly. The waiter that dropped off our tea was gruff and didn't bother to explain except to cluck at you when you attempt to help him move things around the table so he could set the items down. Our waitress then disappeared off the face of the restaurant without even letting us know, so we couldn't even order more plates/tea even if we wanted to. All around us other waiters were checking in with the tables on either side of us to see if they wanted anything else but continued to ignore us. We had to flag down a waiter to grab our check and get our food boxed, our boxed food came, but our check didn't. Had to check with another waiter, still nothing. It took the third waiter to get us our check and he promptly threw it down on the table without even a comment. The food wasn't even good enough for it to be an excuse for them to be so pretentious when we were nothing but polite. I'd rather spend the extra £20 or so and go back to Sketch than come back here again. Save your money and don't bother wasting it on bad attitudes.

D502q-qPNCULYDQ6WyUCFQ.text: We went here for afternoon tea. good selection of sandwiches and pastries. my husband and I left full and satisfied. I will say that it has a strong seafood smell when you walk in but after a couple of minutes you get used to it. We made a reservation the night before for a Wednesday and were able to get it. Highly recommend!

j3_7iGJKwxPr9EAO9-Qd-Q.text: Quite Grand and trendy, but I feel this place is just missing something. Can't put my finger on it, it just leaves me a bit cold. It is good enough, but there is more hype then substance. Like a super model, beautiful, exciting for 15 minutes, but not always interesting. Not to say this spot isn't worth a visit, and I like the idea of it for an occasion or special night out, the Wolseley does fit the bill for atmosphere. On bustling Piccadilly, the sweeping dining space has the feel of old world style dinning room, but more New York then London.

kpBY_EG3_uy3TY8UKqDE-A.text: The Wolseley is my go-to place when I have friends visiting who want to go for afternoon tea. They serve a very classic afternoon tea, which is great for people who have never had it before and want a typical experience.The service is always good and friendly. They once accommodated a friend's dietary requirement which we had forgotten to mention in advance.My favorite pastry was their raspberry and chocolate tart, really delicious. As afternoon tea can be a bit filling, they offer to take away the leftover pastries, sandwiches and scones in a box, which is great because then we get to enjoy their food for a bit longer.Overall, a very classic but quality afternoon tea, where anyone is welcome despite the fancy decor. I'm always happy to go back there!

-Xf-iFE9_oLiLb6dKkAKRw.text: Came here because I was recommended by a friend.  Great for lunch...we had soups, wine and split a few cheeseburgers.  The food is delicious and the place is a scene.  If you're in LONDON  - GO!Make a reservation!

V-JCVpNwHz1VoE-SsFTH7w.text: I have only been here for breakfast 2 times, but its so cool to start the day here, it have a really vibrant/luxury style.I had pancakes both times and it one of the best ive tried, (i also love pancakes at Locanda Verde in N.Y)

NS5R7kot_N85qUaNxBIhrA.text: It wasn't as good as I was expecting and maybe the four stars is down to poorly managing my expectations. It feels luxurious to eat here & we were celebrating so it wins on that count. Went for brunch with some friends - there were 6 of us - a few of us had the potato rosti, avocado, tomato, mushrooms & a poached egg. I expected something interesting with the ingredients. It was all good but in hindsight I probably should've gone for the egg & soldiers or eggs Benedict. A couple of the girls had smoked salmon with poached eggs and that looked much better. Service was fine - not overly attentive. I'll be back to try something else...

WfdENV3aQg7OMWpiC_4d0g.text: Why not experience afternoon tea at an elegant establishment? We had tea on a Sunday afternoon, and highly recommend making reservations since it does  get busy.The tea, tea sandwiches, scones and small pastries were presented in the fancy silverware. The cream and fruit jam was quite good.I will say the friendliest person was the gentleman who served us the pastries and described each item.Worth to experience once in London. Located near the Ritz Club.

Gvp3bnJludDtxzcDmgZwFw.text: Great service in some fancy surroundings.  We had to wait for a table when we arrived (we hadn't made a reservation), but the wait wasn't too long.  I had a drink at the bar and just took it to the table with me.We were in time for the lunch menu.  I had the 7 hour lamb, which simply fell apart when I prodded it with my fork.  It went well with fries.  My partner got the chicken pie which was tasty and had nice sauce.The dessert trolley looked very tempting, but we were too full!  I might go there again just for a dessert lunch.I recommend this restaurant for visitors to London.

0i7uft8sHXcO4bgmgnPLrw.text: Everything was great, good vegetarian selection and an enjoyable time and atmosphere.

nGPaeIEGZDLn9bssCErhYw.text: The berry pancakes were by far the best pancakes I've ever had in my life. The caramelized grapefruit was fantastic. The English breakfast was good but the eggs (scrambled) were a little funky, perhaps it's because I'm American but they put butter or something in them and they had a strange consistency that I'm not used to. They were a little rich for me but the rest was good. Great quality mint tea and good service.

zXUkEkka9Dn3ga7BYRX9sA.text: The food was great, rustic and down to earth. Nothing fancy and over the top, just good first class cooking through and through. Unfortunately, the service was horrible slow, and when pointing out that my coffee arrived some 20 minutes after my dessert, the waitress basically shrugged her shoulders at me, turned and walked away. After finishing, we sat for another 30 minutes waiting to pay the bill. There are far better places in Mayfair than this.

FfdG6F5CxEoBjUldj6AMMA.text: My new favorite restaurant in London! Great atmosphere and food. Place was an old bank and an old car dealership.. Lots of history in the building. Started with the escargot which was prepared traditionally and really delicious. Others at the table had the chicken and dumpling soup which was surprisingly light and flavorful. Entrees were just as great.. Halibut with sauce was rich and yummy.. They are famous for their wienersnitzle which was fab fab fabulous! Must try

jXD3LGOpEAonFuh1oOTsEw.text: Gorgeous space, good service, decent food, and Anna Wintour having breakfast at the table next to you.The eggs benedict is consistently delicious, but the other day I ordered the poached egg with fishcake and my fishcake had bones in it.  Also good for dinner, if someone else is paying.  You go for the atmosphere, really, more than the food.

Dc5iF7SQ6lhhhFE9Dv1ZJQ.text: Steps away from the Green Park tub station, the friendly and classy Wolseley is definitely a much better choice than the snobbish neighbor Ritz.  No they didn't judge what I wear, after I was rejected by the Ritz because of my jeans and backpack.  Right, I should know better, but I'm just a clueless tourist.I follow the Timeout London guide, and this is an excellent review.  The service was superb.  I was seated right away with a nice window view.  The staff gladly made recommendations on the menu upon my request.  They even switched another red wine for me because I thought it was a bit too acidic .  My dinner was perfect:Calf's liver wrapped with bacon and sprinkled with crispy green on top (£ 18.25)- Tender and tasty, each bites melts in my mouth; Snaps and beans side dish (£3.75) - a bit too salty and buttery, can skip; Glass of Rioja Spanish redwine (£9.75) - SUPERB!! Rich and full bodied, compliment very well with the main dish; English Rhubarb and Apple Crumble (£7.25) - dessert TO DIE FOR. Hot custard sauce on the side, and it is just.... heavenly.  Finished dinner with a cup of Darjeeling tea, and I am now the happiest person :)The total was £47.5 with 12.5% service charge included.  Yes, it is worth it. I am already thinking about going there again for afternoon tea.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom

bBfnwDeQUgonG2ed15m5mw.text: Made a reservation for Friday at 3:00 PM. Showed up at 2:30 to see if there were any tables open early. "No, please come back at 3:00." Three of us had afternoon tea. The sandwiches were very tasty, the cakes were very nice, and the tea was delicious. Very crowded and fairly good service. One nice service is that they have postcards you can get for free and they will post them for you for free. A nice touch and centrally located.

fFz-CGriK6nNO_RWGfmpig.text: No trip to London is complete without a proper Afternoon High Tea. The Wolseley came highly recommended by the concierge team at my hotel (Marriot Theadneedles) and did not disappoint. Service was fantastic without being too intrusive. They made sure our tea was always hot and gave a detailed explanation of the pastries and tea sandwiches. My only gripe was that the pastries were TOO sweet. I would recommend to anyone visiting London.

Nvi_dqsglzuvWApf4Tap9Q.text: I've been here for tea and lunch several times and we've never been disappointed.  The food is good, the service is excellent and the ambiance makes you want to sit and enjoy forever, especially on a rainy London afternoon.I highly recommend you try this place for tea or lunch.

WLzKct1FFXa5l_8DF7s4OA.text: I've only come here for breakfast a couple of times, but I love it. The room is beautiful, very elegant! Service is great. I usually just have some tea and a small breakfast dish so I guess I keep coming back for the atmosphere. I have heard from several people that the afternoon tea here is excellent too.

dhbuI73sq9kmZG5GoLyGsQ.text: Of all the establishments I was able to visit in my one week visit in London. This is the place I miss the most. There aren't a lot of places in San Francisco where you can see and feel a power lunch happening. Granted I did not go during the lunch hour but the tail end of Afternoon Tea, you can still feel that a lot happened during lunch. It's probably smarter to make reservations ahead of time because you'll have to wait in the small bar area. Afternoon tea for 2, was my first official UK afternoon tea experience and I absolutely loved it. Down to the tiny details of the labeled spoons that tell you which is the Clotted Cream or Strawberry Jam. On my next visit to London, I'll be sure to stop by and have a proper lunch.

NRGsm00q5RnC4E02-TVVtg.text: While it's true that even weeks out, reservations are hard to come by, they also take walk-ins.  We walked in without reservations, only minutes before breakfast/brunch ended, and were greated so friendly.  I have to admit, I was already prepared for a snobby "oh, you don't have a booking" greeting, but none of that!  We were even offered two different tables, depending on if we wanted to sit for hours over coffee or not (another table had been reserved a hour or so later).Lovely building, great atmosphere and very friendly service.  Though, we were forgotten a bit in the end when a large table arrived.  Yummy breakfast and good value for money.  Will definitely go back

WrEsooJ2Tuwv7JiwYtsfHg.text: Want the best breakfast in London? Go here. Want to pretend you're ridiculously wealthy, if only for an hour or two? This is the place. Trapped in a dreadful Piccadilly club and need to refresh your refine-ometer with an Einspanner in the dead of night? Yer only man.The Wolesley is a cafe, but not in the style of the traditional greasy spoons or sickly sweet orange frappe chains. Instead, its one of London's only Viennese grand cafes, replete with high ceilings, fine porcelain, tastefully polished brass fittings and a real-life maitre'd. For a reference to the price range, all you need to know is that the Ritz is next door.But that price buys you real quality. Top-notch, finger-snapping service; platters of viennese pastries; a wide range of authentic coffees; an atmosphere of hustling breakfast business deals being struck on the upstairs tables; perchance, even, a celebrity sighting. On my last visit I spied Nigella Lawson, and that can't be bad.Try the pastry platter with a friend, then the haggis with scrambled duck eggs, some fresh orange juice and maybe an Einspanner to finish. And dress nice.

photos.caption: Photo of The Wolseley - London, United Kingdom. Interior

DN6gMee24ML-cz29AYMWBQ.text: Vacations in London fall into two camps: shoestring or splurge.  The Wolseley is meant for the latter.I had lunch (steak frites) here several years ago and I finally had my chance to come back for another dining experience today. This time, it was afternoon tea. For £19.50, you get tea of your choice, finger sandwiches, an assortment of delectable pastries, and scones with strawberry jam and CLOTTED CREAM!  I recommend adding either a glass of champagne or a champagne cocktail to round out your experience. I chose the French 75 (champagne and gin).Other reviewers have mentioned the rather grand space. If you eat here, spend some time to look at the chinoiserie detail.  The bathrooms (through the door to the rear of the dining room and down one flight of steps) are very nice too.  I love the solid fixtures here.Overall, the Wolseley is a great stop for a trip to London. Given the type of clientele, it could be slightly intimidating to walk in here.  However, the service I've experienced has been truly fantastic.  I highly recommend it for lunch or afternoon tea.

FKS10AdMzVAemtKaIhik4g.text: The best car-showroom turned restaurant in the world. If you want to experience one of the best breakfasts in London, in beautiful surroundings, with perfect service, this is the place for you. Star-spotting is possible, but don't stare. The prices are reasonable, and you feel as though you're in a luxury hotel. A place to visit regularly.

THPyCq3dQcbBXfYIABb82w.text: Food was a huge disappointment given how great the location, venue and service was. My chicken was dry and didn't have enough sauce to compensate. Its not that hard to not overcook chicken.

ZY83MaLvMKUW8UXE7eVI3Q.text: The best smoked salmon and scrambled eggs in town;)

IybdWdnmQfeYmUl2p_XpkA.text: YUM!On our 15 day visit to London in '07 we visit the Wolseley twice.  Both times we were happily fed, happily served and went on our merry way.The eggs benedict is phenomenal.  The full English breakfast is too!  The coffee was great... the service was top notch, the ambiance just what we expected.On our second visit, I ordered the roast beef... as an American, I didn't know that British roast beef is actually PRIME RIB!  And it was PHENOMENAL!!! I dream of going back to London for a visit... and I dream of meals at the Wolseley.

KvtLM1L5MHAd5lPY6BOc9w.text: Reading here, I see that much of the praise to date as been lavished on the doubtlessly superb breakfasts (duly noted). However, I'd like to make mention of the stunning afternoon teas with service, scenery and sandwiches to rival its better-known neighbour. I've lost count of the number of friends and family I've brought here as part of their time spent visiting London but can assure you that the feedback has always been extremely positive. With an interior that echoes NYC's Grand Central Terminal, it oozes 1920s charm and refinement without making you feel ill-at-ease. Top that off with phenomenal service and a tray full of delicious scones, petit fours and sandwiches and I'll be talking like I'm an extra in the House of Eliot for days.

94y2CKvow2wz2ciPw6YvQA.text: The Wolseley strikes you as the type of place to go for a classic afternoon tea.  It's got this gorgeous old-fashioned black and white decor inside.  It's really very beautiful.  It's also pretty well-priced compared to the other high-end afternoon tea places (e.g. Lanesborough).  The only thing I didn't like was how they didn't give individualized dessert for two - meaning that there was for the finger sandwiches and scones but you had to share all the desserts together if you wanted to try everything.  The other thing I didn't like about the restaurant itself was that it smelled kinda funny.Still, the tea is excellent, of course.  I also like that it's not overly pretentious.  Highly recommended.

RTsxvmL-QMxGWh-Y00rIqg.text: The ambiance is great but the food is so-so. I've been searching for a good place for steak tartare in London and I'd read some positive reviews about it but I wasn't too impressed. I'll have to try other things on their menu!

NZTCZridI6w6HIrBCdH2zQ.text: when my fellow yelpees say only good for breakfast and tea... listen woman listen, sadly i did not and went for dinner !!!!well in all fairness to myself, I was invited to a dinner there !! I could not really tell my boss otherwise !!Venue: beautiful, very chic, relatively pretty crowd and quite smart ! The lighting is gorgeous and puts one is a great mood !Food: the most important part for me, alas cold and disappointing ! Come on guys bring all the parts of a dish together or closely follwoing each other. My oysters came with the tabasco only and then 15min later came the putter bread and shallot vinegar(and i checked my watch to see how long it took) !!! Now if i was there with friends I would have called my waiter and reminded him, but since I was with the work crowd I did not want to seem picky (which I know I am)I was so angry, but it got progressively worse !!My colleague, asked for a side of mashed potatoes  with his main dish and they forgot ! when reminded they took another 10min to bring it and it was COLD when it arrived !! come on, i know i am particular but cold potatoes are disgusting !!!my steak was mediocre. It was clearly good quality meat sadly it was cold by the time it arrived !I think what is best to be had is the breakfast or tea ! hots meals are definitely not their forte !!

1M62VmrQpJgFdPrw9O-Xow.text: Please come here for afternoon tea.  The scone with clotted cream and strawberry jam is unforegettable.  Forget those scones that are dry and hard on the outside.  The Wolseley will introduce you to a buttery, soft scone that will leave you wanting more....a few more...in one sitting.  I wish I could frequent this establishment at least once a week.  Guess I will have to move to London.

OPYKly2BBbUvrtWf-KzbtQ.text: service was terrible, very inattentive servers. food was good but stingy for the price you're paying. it seemed all pretentious and trying for that classy feel but didn't really make it. will i recommend it? no.

Mwh2A3JfaHd4upVANPKdqw.text: The food was decent, but the atmosphere and attitude self-important.  Granted it was busy, but our waitress was surly and pushy.  I was quite surprised by this considering the reviews. It diminished what could have been a decent meal and experience.  I have eaten at many pretentious restaurants (heck, I used to work in Beverly Hills) but this stepped over the line into borderline rudeness. In fact, when I excused myself from the table at some point during the meal, the waitress mentioned to my dinner partner "Isn't it nice to go out and splurge every once in a while?" She made a wise choice to say this to him and not me.  Yes, were appropriately dressy and we ordered well. Maybe it was because we are American? I can only guess at why she deemed us so undeserving. Perhaps if I had arrived with a more prestigious guest I would have been encouraged to enjoy myself.

TXHUpr_BGHBuE4MeskrC1g.text: First of all I would like to take Rob Hinchcliffe up on his eggs benedict challenge - I think we will find I am the true expert. But I agree, The Wolseley delivers a pretty near perfect egg experience. And when you add to that the decor, the buzz and the overall feeling of being, for a brief moment, at the centre of the universe, I love The Wolseley. I have had breakfast, lunch, dinner and mid-morning coffee here (not all in the same day you understand). And I guess it is still the breakfasts that really count.

_m_pEPhE6SSMlpCYICm0Hg.text: Just had dinner there, and I found it to be very overrated. Although the architecture and the decor is nice, overall I found it to be very theme-y. There was nothing authentic or interesting about it. I ordered the lobster cocktail. The lobster part of the plate was good - but I was completely disgusted by the mounds of pink salad dressing covering it. It was too sweet, to tangy, and just way too much. I didn't even taste the lobster nor the bits of avocado hidden in the salad. For a main course, I ordered trout and puy lentils. I really can't image anything more plain. The trout was simply steamed, and the lentils were not at all seasoned. I hated it. Is seemed as though everyone else's meals looked better than mine. At a restaurant of this reputation and price, that should never happen. The service was acceptable (I've had worse in London) but not at all remarkable. My waiter was a bit arrogant. I dont care how sophisticated a restaurant thinks it is, service should never, ever be arrogant. I had the Wolseley blanc de blancs brut and it was quite nice. The waiter recommended a red wine for my fish which I enjoyed. I skipped dessert fearing I would be disappointed. Instead, I had a cocktail at the bar which was very good (but I was surrounded by annoying tourists).I give it two starts because the space and the decor was lovely. I loved the nice linen napkins and the banquettes. But overall, it felt gimmicky, like a theme restaurant. And the food was terribly disappointing.

UQWG8EKk11Zx8XuOBNjr6A.text: Yes, it is a little posh, but I love nothing more than to get my good weekend threads on and come to the Wolseley to enjoy breakfast or brunch with the girls on a special occasion. This place is just delightful - decadence in abundance but minus the pretentiousness. It is apparently popular among celebrities and the fashion elite but when my boss (who falls into neither of these categories) requested that I book him and a client here for brunch as it was 'just amazing' I thought it could also be the sort of place that I may try as my boss has great taste when it comes to London haunts. When I did take the girls there, we didn't actually spot any celebs or fashion elite (they would probably still be in bed actually), just a group of nice, seemingly normal folk who probably mix in the media circles but keen to keep themselves to themselves. The Wolseley makes fantastic, strong coffee and beautiful freshly baked croissants for breakfast. It also has a coffee room which stays open on weekdays until 12pm.
